GAME: Le Havre
RANK: 34
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Played 1 round demo at Orccon 2009
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I find it hard to say whether I like this better than it's sister game Agricola. Both play very differently, of course, but both require quite a bit of thought to do well at. And the beauty of them both is that having thought it through for one game, the next game will de different either because, the buildings (or cards) are different or because you choose to adopt a different strategy. One of those games that really deserves repeated plays that the "Eurogame ethic" really doesn't allow.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesomeness in a box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The more I play this the less I like it.  The theme is starting to bug me (so ... am I the mayor of Le Havre?  Who the hell is my work crew and why do they only work for food?  Why are all these cattle just sitting on the dock and why aren't they eating all of the grain right next to them?), and the dominance of the build-steel-ship-steel strategy is making for less and less interesting games without a lot of room to maneuver.  I wish the special buildings were goofier.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
To me Le Havre is extremely underrated. I think this is way better than Agricola. There is always something cool and productive you can do on your turn. You can play vastly different from game to game because of the way the buildings are ordered randomly. You can also shoot for points in multiple ways. You could collect a bunch of buildings for points, you could build lots of ships, you could buy a few ships and ship lots of goods, you could make lots of high value goods and only ship small amounts of them, and I'm sure there are more ways to get points that I'm forgetting. There is a decent amount of special buildings to choose from and I've barely seen any of them yet. This is one of the first games I ever bought and it's still great.

Extremely tight resource management game.  balancing food, loans, building materials, and the ever increasing number of building options is tough.  It is actually not a difficult game to play, just a difficult game to play optimally.

RATING: 8.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Worker placement game (yet again!), where you want to grab resources, and convert these resources into points (buildings + ships).

This game definitely shows signs of its predecessors (Agricola, Caylus, etc), but despite not being terribly original, and being overly long, it has something about it that gets it to the table regularly (it definitely helps that my wife really likes it).

Essentially, it's a 1-5 player game, where depending on the number of players, there is a set number of rounds (I usually play 3-players, and I think that's 18 rounds), during which time, you "fill the board" with varying resources, then choose to: 1)grab a resource pile, OR 2)build a building or ship.  Also at any time, you can buy and/or sell buildings.  The goal is to get the most points, and money also equals points.  At the end of each round, you have to pay food, similar to Agricola, and if you can't meet the food requirements (which can also be paid with money), you get loan(s), similar to beggar cards.  The main difference here is that it's not a big deal to get loans and paying off your food isn't as draining as it is in Agricola (not that it's easy).

You only get 1 worker to place, so you always want to do more than you can do on a given turn, and you are often torn between grabbing that huge pile of wood/clay/money etc. or building that valuable building.  Also, similar to Caylus, you use your own buildings for free, but have to pay (food and/or money) when you use other players or the towns buildings (usually).  All in all, not as good as Agricola, but still very solid- oddly enough a couple of friends like this better than Agricola, and my wife seems to want to play this as much as Agricola right now.  Seems like it scales well, BUT it's definitely a long game, which might make it prohibitive to play 5 player games (have only played 2-4 players so far).  Thanks again for making another solid gamer's game Uwe, looking forward to your next game(s)!.

Own the [boardgame=40387]Essen promo series[/boardgame] and the [boardgame=65996]Le Grand Hameau[/boardgame] expansion cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I rate "Agricola" above all other games and love "At the Gates of Loyang" almost as much, but have waited many months for the opportunity to try "Le Havre". I am not ready to hold it in quite the same esteem as the other games of the trilogy, and I'm not sure why. I think it is the lack of tactile components that puts me off. It has the ingenious intertwining actions of "Agricola" with the same lovely artwork, but some of the heart feels like it is missing. That said, this is head and shoulders above most engine-builders and the sheer wealth of options is admirable, with balanced and clever interplay. I think with more plays I could learn to love it, but it's got some very impressive relatives to compete with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There is also a computer version (Java application) available here on BGG.

RATING: 8.75
It's just so stinking quick-moving. Le Havre is simple in design, but rewarding in practice. You're never afraid of making a bad move because you're always able to get something good out of it. That's not to say that there aren't bad moves, but just that the pressure felt in this game is a fun type of pressure. There's a big build to this game as everybody is creating their empire of businesses and ships. The economy starts to expand and by the end of the game you're surprising yourself with how many points you actually earned and with the awesome layout of cards in front of you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
4 plays / 3,4 players

LIKE: Great theme of fish and shipyard, with a simple core set of rules. Not many high-level paths to win, but so many paths to choose from in the beginning to get to the narrowing victory points. I enjoyed the visibility of all the cards to help plan ahead.

DISLIKE: The small tiles can be a little fiddly. it's difficult to distinguish between upgraded/not upgraded from across the table, but homemade player cards help. The game is very long, even with 3 players.

OVERALL: Great game! This was a game that really hooked me onto worker placement. The short game (2.5h for 4 players) is a great way to introduce the game, but feels like it ends too soon. The self-made player mats help keep the chits in order.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Need to play again to get a clearer opinion about it.  Many options and ways to score points.  Definitely a game that rewards repeated plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
For me, this is a solid improvement over Agricola. It plays very smoothly and feels well edited and play tested. The rule set is straight forward - all the action and interest are found on the building cards. The theme carries the game and aids to understanding effective play - e.g. wheat is turned into bread and can be used as food or perhaps sold for profit. The only strike I have against it is the time it takes to play. A 4-player affair easily takes over 3 hours - but the short version can get done in about 2. It never feels slow or dull or repetitive - so the time does move by without complaint. Still, at this point, it's one of my favorite games!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

Con más partidas, mejora muchísimo el asunto, es un juegazo de gestión de recursos! En mi opinión es bastante mejor que el Agrícola y algo mejor por la rejugabilidad comparado con el Ora el Labora que me gusta mucho.

9 -> 10
Le Havre is simply the best resource management game out there. Valid strategies a numerous and the game always takes a new course. 


2015-11-04
To my big surprise I sold this in an auction. Might be that I'll regret it later, but at this point of my life I just felt like getting rid of games that haven't seen any or very little play in the past 3-4 years. It seems that nowadays the games hitting the table are action packed sub 90 minute games instead of longer ones. This is especially true for Le Havre, which I basically recommend only for max 3 players, and still you should play the shortened version unless every one was familiar with the game. If I only had more space to store my games...


2016-10-26
The absolutely best thing about Le Havre is the positive atmosphere around the game. You seem to have an endless number of good alternatives to choose from. But this does not mean that your choices are insignificant or anything. Actually they are far from it. Everything requires careful planning still. You are usually better off if you are following a longer term plan in your game. However, sometimes it is just too tempting to deviate from the path you have planned to take. Thus you are facing many interesting decisions throughout the game.

If there is something to criticise about Le Havre, it would come down to two things. First one is the length. I basically recommend the game for 2-3 players only and still you should consider playing the shortened version. Thankfully the short game delivers almost the same experience as the full game. The second negative that the special buildings in the full game do not seem to have big enough of an impact to justify doubled play time over the shortened game. The special buildings are just too situational often requiring a certain resource generation infrastructure to be up and running before you can benefit from the them. And preparing the infra may be difficult because you do not know which buildings will be available. Thus in most games you just ignore them all together.

So, a full game of Le Havre is a bit long but the shortened game is golden.

My review of the game can be found here:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/498973/maturing-review-le-havre-after-20-plays

RATING: 6
Really went off this game.

I absolutely love the mechanics and the feeling of construction as time goes on.

But I absolutely hate hate hate the feeding mechanic - I play games to have fun, not to be punished by the unrelenting system. This is also the reason I'm lukewarm on Agricola. It just feels like a cheap mechanic.

I also loathe that the same sets of cards come out in the same order every time. This is where Agricola excels, but Le Havre sucks.

RATING: 9
Very good game also, teaches a lot about resources and money.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Another win on the heavy strategy side for designer Uwe Rosenberg.  After numerous plays, I'm not sure that I would still reach for this one when Uwe's later masterpiece, [I]Ora et Labora[/I] is available to play, but this still feels different enough from [I]Ora[/I] to warrant keeping both.    

This doesn't seem to have as many varied paths to victory as other Rosenberg titles, and is much more susceptible to an aggressive starvation-type strategy (here, it involves taking numerous loans given that interest is capped at one franc per round regardless of the number of loans).  Still a solid entry, if perhaps not quite up to [I]Agricola[/I] and surpassed by some of Uwe's later titles as well.  I'm not sure the aggressive loan strategy will necessarily win every time, but I have found that the aggressive loan player emerging victorious tends to cause a certain amount of angst among other members of my playing group.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think Le Havre is a wonderful game.  It seems complex and busy with bits but is really quite simple.  The whole game can be broken down into two actions...take resources or use a building.   The depth and complexity comes from understanding the interactions of the buildings and planning ahead.  The first play may seem a bit daunting becaue you are still learning the system but after that it realy clicks.  By my second game I had a very good grasp on the flow of the game aned was eagerly planning my strategy.  It allows for a lot of variety on how you attain victory.  Being a Rosenberg game it does have a similar feel to Agricola but is quite different.  In Agricola, it seems that unless you have a perfect hand the only way to win is through generalization of your farm.  I don't have as many plays of Le Havre yet but it feels like there are many more ways to victory (of course there are common elements everyone must follow).

Updated from a 9 in August 2010
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An interesting game of worker placement and building/ship construction.  Similar to [GAMEID=31260] in a few respects (e.g., food requirement, action selection, blocking other players), but more economic since it includes buying/selling and a lot of goods conversion (upgrading).

I like it.  It feels tighter in some ways, potentially harsher than [GAMEID=31260] but more flexible.  Need additional plays to really pin it down.  Game length is an issue, though it should become less prohibitive with experienced players.  Rating may improve with additional plays.

Rating bumped from 7 to 8 (4/27/09).  The more I play this, the more I want to play it.  My first 4 plays have been of the shorter variety (a 3-p, two solo's & a 4-p).  I'm liking it more and more, appreciating the different strategies or, at the very least, the different directions.  I suspect this one will shine even more in the longer variety with the special buildings.

Rating bumped from 8 to 9 (5/08/09).  I like this one [i]much[/i] better than [GAMEID=31260].  There is a definite progression to the game due to the expanding "tech tree" and increasing number of options as buildings are constructed.  There are a few different strategies to consider.  Food, and entry fees, can become a severe limiting factor, but there are a few ways to anticipate this and plan accordingly.  The biggest downsides are game length and having to use the short version for intro games.

Further comments (5/29/09).  The long game is *MUCH* better than the short game.  There's a greater sense of development and resources in the early portion become more critical.  In addition, the special buildings make the game more diverse and differentiated among plays.

That's another interesting thing -- the game can vary a lot among plays, and not just from player choices.  Order and arrangement of the building piles, order of the 7 turn supply markers, the special buildings at work -- these all combine to produce very different, diverse games.  I want to play more long games.  I am [i]really[/i] enjoying this game!  (It's better than [gameid=31260]!  *gasp*)

More comments (6/29/09):  The long game is the only/best way to go.  I'm now teaching others with the long game.  Much better than the short game.  The special buildings have the potential for dictating, or at least suggesting, new avenues to pursue.  While shipping & building are the two dominant strategies, there are so many flavors to pursue and options to consider that I'm not losing interest at all.

Plano-type boxes are a must for short setup time.  Check out the sewing section at your local craft store for small boxes.

Negatives:  Play time is a bit long for the game.  Fair bit of downtime on other players' turns.  Don't play with the AP-inclined.  Relatively steep learning curve -- lots to learn, assimilate and assess.

Still, I really like this one and I don't see that changing any time soon.

Additional comments (7/08/09):  Teaching this game is difficult.  There's a lot to cover and new players' eyes will likely glaze over at the 5 or 10 min. mark.  Unfortunately, there's not much that can be done about that.  In addition, experienced players will have a dramatic advantage over new players.  There's a distinct learning curve that some people may not traverse or may not be willing to traverse.  I think there's a great game on the other side, but not all will agree or be willing to play this one again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[31.08.2011]
Nach mehreren Spielen in verschiedenen Besetzungen kann ich nur sagen, dass Le Havre eines meiner Lieblingsspiele ist. Wiederspielbarkeit ist durch die immer wieder unterschiedliche Reihenfolge der Ressourcen gegeben, und durch die drei Baustellen-Stapel, die in immer wieder anderer Reihenfolge Gebäude zur Verfügung stellen.
Eigentlich kanppe Ressource ist die "Aktion", die man vor Allem mit vielen Mitspielern nur 1-2x pro Runde hat.

RATING: 8
Juego complejo de gestión de recursos. Conocido como el sucesor de Agrícola, realmente tiene poco que ver con este. Es un juego largo, con un despliegue complicado, hay que andar eligiendo cartas dependiendo del número de jugadores y del modo de juego.
Una vez metido en harina el juego es divertido y profundo, aunque es cierto que hasta que no se conocen los diferentes edificios, se va un poco a ciegas. 
Para muchos es de los mejores juegos de gestión de recursos, yo creo que no es la panacea pero no está nada mal jugado con la gente adecuada.

This gives me everything Agricola did not. Might just be my favourite game. Best with 3.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Well, three plays into this one and I can see so much potential. I think it is mechanically easier than Agricola to understand, which I like; however, the options available in this game increase at a much faster rate than Agricola.

Unlike Agricola where you want more actions, Le Havre has you wishing for more turns. Sure the game is longer than Agricola, but by the end of it we always wanted to a few more rounds so that we could accomplish what we wanted to accomplish. Great theme and I can definitely see this game surpassing El Grande in my "Always Want To Play It" category. Bonus points for offering a "short version" for those times when the full game isn't possible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Le Havre is in my opinion superior to Agricola. Yes it is a worker placement game where you have only one worker, but the game makes up with it with the sheer number of choices you can make. And those grow the longer you play! Amazing depth of strategy and the ability for the game to change everytime you play. Really need to have your thinking cap on for this one. Really shines in the 3 to 4 player range and with the special buildings. It is a bit long though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I prefer this game over Agricola and to some extents to Puerto Rico too. Le Havre involves more planning over time and thus a much more complete strategic view of the game in its entirety from beginning to end. I love the variety of actions a player can perform and the multiple combinations of actions. The fact that one player's cards are playable by the opponents as well makes the game more balanced and complex. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I quite like this design; the tension has a different flavour to that of Agricola's, and the decision spaces feel more like you're medium-long term planning. Tactical is absolutely not the way to play this game. 

That said, I feel like the normal game can outstay its welcome, especially at 3 players. For two players who know the system, the normal game might play well, but for any other player counts or for newbies, I'd go the short game each time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Le havre is like Agricola, except without the good parts and the bad parts made worse. The game is not as tight as agricola. It requires a huge investment in terms of getting familiarized with the cards and card combinations. The game is wayyy slower than Agricola because you have only one worker. The markets are horrendously incomplete, imagine playing settlers of catan except without the inter player trade, so if you wanted an ore you pretty much have to wait till you mine one or exchange four for one.  There isn't any reason at all for me to play Le Havre when I can play Agricola. Le Havre is just an exceedingly poor immitation of the original Agricola.

RATING: 8
The buildings are what make it for me (with some pseudo-randomized availability each game), and the 'worker placement' is just different enough from what I've seen elsewhere that it feels unique. 

The design is pretty satisfying, but there can also be some strong frustration in feeling backed into a corner without a good option for what to do. The funkiness of navigating a decent plan in Le Havre can occasionally leave me a little annoyed. Other times, it makes the game exciting. So it can go both ways.

Shame, as the core game is pretty fantastic.

RATING: 10
1-5(3)

UPDATE: With three it's great. Loans come into play much more readily (and to great effect) and there is genuine contention over the different strategies. Two to three actions per round feels about right and the game becomes a really rich experience. Le Havre is very much a winner.

--------------------------------------------------------

UPDATE: Played again and I really enjoyed it.  It's got a different sort of tension than Agricola, but it's a constructive sort.  Only played with 2p and want to get more involved (impossible as that tends to be).

--------------------------------------------------------

I'll play this any time, but it lacks the tension of Agricola (in providing food).  There are a lot of cool mechanics at play here, but I never really get a feeling of where I'm at in the game, and some buildings just don't seem like they'd fit in.  I'll need to play more to get a better feeling for this.

RATING: 8.5
Just played this at Kublacon with Lyman & friends.  Very similar to Agricola but a lot more screw-you actions.  We played the full 5 players games and I was the only newbie.  Fairly easy to understand.  This time lot of interaction since you may have to use opponent owned property to do something.  More of a brain-burner than Agricola since you may have to change your strategy if someone else blocks it by their actions.
Picked a copy from Game Kastle booth at Kublacon 2009 for $70.

RATING: 7
I only played the short version, but it took more than three hours to play, which is clearly to much for what it offers.

Basically I liked this game, but it can happen that you lose the game only because you can't bring your cows to the butcher ... one of your opponents keeps it occupied turn after turn.

On the other hand it is quite a clean game, not filled with fuzzy mechanics as in many other eurogames.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent resource management euro game. Lots of interesting choices for the players. You have to construct buildings, take care of feeding your people, collect goods, built ships and 'manipulate' your resources. Many strategic paths to follow and it seems that there is always a back-up plan. Money can be tight. The rules are very easy to teach, gameplay is easy at first but things get more serious turn after turn.  Real brain-burner, love it. The special buildings provide some welcomed variety.

Very enjoyable game.

RATING: 8
The only Uwe Rosenberg title I have played so far that did not grab me. The game was very good but didn't go far enough for me. One of my favorite concepts in worker placement games, is the notion of player owned spaces, and to my recollection this was the first place I saw it. The problem was that the cost of using spaces was not significant enough for me. I wanted it to be a very tough decision whether using some one else's space was worth the benefit to them and it never was.

RATING: 5
Update: It's not just the frustration factor. I really feel the cleverness of this game is overwhelmingly locked in to how the system operates, as opposed to any moves or choices players can make. However I do quite like playing it as long as it moves at a fair pace - which means the shorter game and never five player.

One action!?! I've waited 15 mins for one measly action!?! 

I don't know; it is intriguing, but ultimately I think it will turn out for me to be one of those games where the built-in frustration factor outweighs the pleasure from seeing my position (slowly) develop, and I don't care much for that level of frustration.

RATING: 9
Le Havre is a magnificent game, because it is great in its simplicity. You only have one worker, so it's not very difficult to learn, but you really have to think ahead. There are several ways of playing, so you always have options. Great for solo play as well. I believe it is one of the best in its genre.

RATING: 8.5
I find far superior to Agricola in every way. I never thought i'd like it before i played it. It feels far smoother than agricola and it is far less random and more strategic due to the absence of hidden cards that only one player can exploit. The best thing is the lack of point scoring for generalising as in agricola. Here you can specialise all the way and any way you want. 

The only problems i found in the design are the terrific dependence on everyone playing correctly and the massive AP it induces. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
May 2011:  Complex and headache inducing.  Admirable design and mechanics, but for me, it just leaves me slightly cold thematically. Building buildings and ships once again. Sigh.

August 2013:  After playing this a second time, how I feel about this game is a bit of a mystery to me.  Clearly, it is well-designed and seemingly bursting with thematic elements like coal, iron, fish, cattle, ships and buildings that affect these elements in logical ways.  

Yet, surprisingly, this game leaves me feeling so cold and detached thematically.  I really feel like I am merely playing a grinding, repetitive series of mechanics and resource conversions to merely create victory points.  Additionally, I feel very little interaction or competition with the other players.  After two plays, I simply have zero desire to play this game again, so I have to downgrade it to a 6.  Very respectable design, but just can't fake any interest in it.

RATING: 8
Yes. There are a lot of components. A LOT! And yes the set up time can be up there with Arkham Horror. But this is a good game. With each round you feel as though you are building up your own industry (sometimes standing on your friend's shoulders to do it). It also plays quick and there is always something you can do. Did you opponent take the franks you wanted to build that Smokehouse? Fine. Just use his slaughterhouse to make some meat and sell that next turn. You're never blocked out in this game. And if you decide not to pursue some aspect of the industry you aren't penalized for it. By the time you are finished with this game you really feel like you've built something.

RATING: 8.5
Le Havre is clearly a relative of Agricola's. It's got worker placement, slowly growing pots of resources, resources that change values over time, and an ever-increasing urgency to supply food, food, more food! For some reason, though, Le Havre scratches an itch for me that Agricola doesn't quite. I've only played twice, and I'm fully willing to admit that this may change with more plays, but I think the game is a winner.

Played one short solo game (87 points) and one full two-player game (which ended in a tie, 176 vs. 176).

Bought direct from Lookout Games; own 6 of 8 promo special buildings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I rate this game as a 10 for the two player and possibly three player game. The solo version is also a nice game, but your only goal is to push your score beyond your previous highest score, which is also nice but lacks a bit of tension. As a four player game it is too long and you feel like you get to do much less throughout the game (eventhough there are a few more rounds) hence I would not recommend this game with more than three players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like this game, it has a lot of the good elements from both Caylus and Agricola, but it misses out on a crucial element present in both of them: Variable turn ordering! The game needs a building that can manipulate turn order, or some sort of offer that does the same. Without this, the game is pulled back into the realm of Puerto Rico, where even the most skillful players can lose just because of turn order. I definitely prefer the longer game to the shorter (more brutal), and both always feel a bit too long; just something not quite tuned and perfected about the game, beyond the turn order issue. Will definitely play, but it's missing out on what could make the game a 10 in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 6

The game have many brilliant mechanics that works really well together. I like it that the game have instructions printed on both board and cards, you don't have to refer to the rules to set it up every time. It is Caylus meets Agricola, and the result seems better then both.

RATING: 7.9
With 2-3 players, this game is significantly less brutal than Agricola while having a lot of the same sort of mechanics. (With 4 players, it gets quite a bit more brutal, and the low number of actions each round starts to feel frustrating.) The game feels quite different with different number of players, due to more buildings being available depending on number of players. I'm going back and forth on my fear of the game starting to feel too scripted soon; will let to have experience tell.
I think I prefer the short game over the full game, as the full game lasts significantly longer, without significantly deeper gameplay. Unfortunately the short game doesn't get the benefit of the variation in the special buildings...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A wonderful Uwe Rosenberg resource management/conversion game with multiple avenues of victory. If I had to distinguish it from his other titles, I would say this game feel quite relaxing and forgiving. Each turn, you always seem to have plenty of good options. And while other players can "block" specific buildings, it tends to only create inefficiencies rather than dictate the outcome of the game. 

It's a very good game and one that euro/Rosenberg-fans should check out. 

[Update after 12 plays]: After a dozen plays, I no longer find this game relaxing and/or forgiving. What changed? Essentially, I got better at valuing the decisions in the game. Like many games, Le Havre is about picking the most advantageous path; But unlike many games, the valuations of those paths are constantly in flux and dictated by other players decisions. And that is where the skill lies. Often pile of goods will lure you into a particular action and it will be a red-herring... something you won't have enough time to convert to money. But other times, you may get fixated on a particular path and ignore lucrative opportunities, which may be taken by your opponent instead.

I simply can't get enough of this game and still, after a dozen plays, nothing seems obvious, repetitive, or boring. My only hesitation with this game is playing it with higher player counts because of AP. But with 2-3 players, it is wonderful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Was surprised how much I enjoyed this one - I really don't like Agricola and At the Gates of Loyang was okay - but this was relatively easily to understand and played at brisk pace. I suspect is because the worker placement is so restively it's not hard to identify what are you probable best moves. The regular food upkeep costs seemed a bit too harsh for me, especially at the end - but that could an artifact of misplaying the harbour cards.

One problem: the game seems a bit too quick with the 'fast' variant, but seems hideously long with the 'full' variant.

RATING: 8
Az első játék utáni benyomásom röviden: nagyon jó, de nagyon hosszú:) Bevezetésként a rövidített két személyessel játszottam (fejenként 28-szor kerültünk sorra), a tiszta játékidő 3 és fél óra volt, pedig csak 18 épület van ebben a variánsban, a teljes 5 fősben van vagy 40, és ott is 28-szor kerül mindenki sorra, de ott 5-en:) Biztos pörgősebb a játék némi kártyaismerettel, mi is a vége felé kezdtünk belejönni. De ez egyben azt is jelenti, hogy egy profi Le Havre-s ellen egy kezdőnek esélye sincs szerintem... A játékszabály nem bonyolult, negyed óra, de komplex döntéseket kell hozni, már ez az egyszerűsített változat is bonyolultabbnak tűnt, mint az Agricola, de személy szerint nekem jobban is tetszett. Sokan panaszkodnak a nyelvfüggőségre, pedig szerintem az ikonok sokat segítenek. Mély, jól letesztelt játékról van szó, mely a szerző bevallása szerint a Caylusból és az Agricolából építkezik, nálam élményre a kettő közt foglal helyet. Rosenberg talán legjobb játéka, de egy 5 fős teljes játéknak csak úgy ülnék neki, ha lélekben felkészültem a hosszára:) A kedvencem valószínűleg nem lesz, de top10-re még esélyes:)

RATING: 9
Mitol is tudok szeretni egy jatekot...?
Leginkabb attol, ha azt az elso percetol az utolsoig elvezem - es jobb esetben ezt latom a jatekostarsak arcan is.
Ez a jatek - szamomra - sajnos erre keptelen!

Jo otletek sokasaga fedezheto fel benne - viszont a jatekido hossza mindent "lerombol"... (4 jatekos - tobb, mint 3h) 
Megeri ez a jatek a raforditott idot...? - megitelesem szerint hatarozottan nem!!! 
Lassuva, vontatotta, es unalomba fordulova valik egy ido utan. Az egyre tobb felepitett epulet - es az altaluk vegrehajthato akciok - altal, egyre attekinthetetlenebbe valik a jatek.
A felhasznalok kore is eleg korlatozott, hiszen ez nem az a jatek, amivel meg lehet szerettetni a tarsasjatekok vilagat az azzal most ismerkedokkel.(nem is kell minden jateknak ezt a szerepet betoltenie, de...)
Tovabba jelentos hatranyban van az a jatekos is, aki nem ismeri a kartyak kepessegeit, az azokkal kialakítható kombináciokat.

Tehat vegyesek a benyomasaim...

Mindenkeppen pozitiv azonban az "egy jatekos" lehetoseg!
Szolo valtozat: Azert ez teljesen mas, ez igy nem tarsasjatek - de kihivas van benne. (probald tulszarnyalni az eddig legjobb eredmenyedet - nekem most 181 pont) De ha nincs jatszotars, legalabb egyedul is lehet vele tarsasjatekozas erzetet kelteni.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
From reading comments:
A deep game with no luck but with a random setup of building that provides re-playability.  Rewards specialization, which Agricola does not.  People can use others' buildings with a fee, like Caylus.  Worker placement mechanic.  Buildings have a lot of text and special things that they do for end game VPs and midgame perks, like Puerto Rico.  The game is on the long side.  Learning curve is steep.  Don't play with 5 people.

Conclusion: [b]Try before Buy[/b]. I already have Agricola so I don't need to go rush out to purchase this game.  

Dec-26-2008
First game.  The game is pretty long.  Excluding the rules, the game lasted 3 hours with 1 experienced player and 3 newbies.  The game is certainly harder than Agricola since there are a lot more resources and buildings that can be used.  Because of this you have much more things to consider and decide if using those buildings and/or taking those resources will pay off.  Just like in Agricola actions is the most important resource and maximizing them is key.  Do NOT play this game with AP prone people as both of you will be frustrated.  The game is actually pretty simple to play but to play well is really hard.  The theme is decent, building up the dock/city of Le Havre.  We played it twice and felt like I was dabbling in everything.  I would like to play next time and see if I can specialize on something and still do well.  Even though the game is pretty long, I am intrigued enough to explore the game.  Unfortunately, my wife did not enjoy the game as much and said that it was overwhelming for her.  Even if I end up liking the game a lot, I don't think I'd get the game until she likes it; thus the rating.
Initial Rating: 7

RATING: N/A
05.01.02.02
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The second game in the Rosenberg's "Harvest Trilogy" is another wonderful resource management masterpiece. When you breed Caylus with Agricola, you cannot be disappointed with the result!
But while Le Havre has some traits of its parents, is also quite different from them.
Where Agricola is a game of scarcity, Le Havre is about abundance. If Agricola forces to do a little of everything, Le Havre needs specialization. While the number of different choices is quite constant in a game of Caylus, the range of possibilities in Le Havre grows steadily during the course of the game.
A truly wonderful game by the genius of Uwe Rosenberg.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
good economic game that is a bit long, and not really innovative in any way. I felt a little like I've done this before already, but I would gladly play more.

[edit] second play, still fast start rules, and suddenly this felt a lot more strategic when you have some idea what the buildings do

[edit...3] loans are there to be taken, no matter what the rulebook suggests. avoid them and you lose. begining rounds of the game are centered around marketplace, a pity you can't try different things from get go.

I like this game quite a bit, but am very surprised it has such a widespread appeal, what with downtime and game length..

RATING: 8.5

The build up to the last few rounds where your engine spits out victory points is quite satisfying. The variation in the buildings allows for each game to feel different, especially if you play at different play counts. While I think I prefer the card-driven strategy of Agricola, my wife prefers this one quite a bit more. Aside from shipping goods, the theme is barely tied to the game play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My roommate owns the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Instead of placing multiple farmers on different action spaces (ala Agricola,) in Le Havre you get to place just 1 worker.  There are a TON of building choices to choose from (in the late game) so choose wisely.  

As stated, Le Havre has a TON of buildings.  Every time a player builds a building it is placed in front of that player.  Depending on the size of the playing area, it can be challenging for new players to see all of the options available.  I am probably going to remedy this somehow with player aids or maybe even a player board ala Caylus.      

The downside to Le Havre is that the constant replenishing of cardboard chits feels more tedious than the replenishing of wooden bits in Agricola.  I'm also not a fan of the double-sided chits.  I feel that players are more prone to unintentionally making mistakes.
 
The expansion, Le Grand Hameau, adds additional special buildings.  Gameplay is the exact same, but variety is always a plus. 

Last thing to touch on is which camp do I fall in, the Agricola or Le Havre camp?  Well, if I'm playing a 2-3 player game, I prefer Le Havre, whereas I prefer Agricola with 4-5 players.  

2 players, 13 plays!
3 players, 7 plays!
4 players, 8 plays! 
5 players, 2 plays!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
math trade

RATING: 8.99

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The test of time will tell if this game is upgraded to a 10 ranking.  I have only played the game twice, but I love the simple game mechanics and the deep and nuanced strategy.

1.3.2012 - Now, in light of playing Puerto Rico (another resource, economics type of game) Le Havre is no longer my favorite in this type of eurogame, thus the reason the decrease in ranking from 9.5 to 7.

2.2012 - Game traded for Power Grid.  Le Havre 6th spot on the BGG confuses me a bit.  I can see the appeal of wide open choices, but the game mechanics seem so loose that they didn't provide an satisfying game experience after a few plays.  I wanted more from the game.  Then after playing Puerto Rico, I knew that it was not going to get to the table ever again.  Both games are resource efficiency/production games (like any good Euro) but PR does it better.  Therefore it truly is a game I could take or leave  (Rating Edit: 2.8.12 - 7 to a 5)

8.2012 - I have seen the light.  After giving Le Havre another try via ios/iPad, I have discovered the depth and richness of Le Havre.  Since trading the game back in February, I acquired Caylus and have played it a handful of times (about equal to the number of Le Havre plays).  The reasons I originally liked the game, as described in my 1st post regarding this game, still stand.  The simple mechanics of the game make it very easy to understand what you can do on your turn.  Figuring out what is the "best" choice with the simple things you can do on this turn is what makes this game shine.  I'm addicted to the game and cannot stop thinking about the different strategies (coke/steel vs. grain and cattle vs. shipping line, etc.)  I defer to JohnRayJr "Landmark Game" for a superior description and review of Le Havre.  http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/503185/a-landmark-game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
1st play and confused as hell. Straight off the bat this game has heavy flavours of Agricola; harvests and the need to produce food. Token placement on buildings to make them function. Strong whiff of Caylus with buildings bought by individuals which draw a rent from other players when they wish to use them.

However, even after a debrief we all seem to be still scratching our heads. The rules give a heavy hint that you need ships to win. Our winner by a very clear margin (105 vs 79 in 2nd place) never bought one nor shipped a thing.

Five players mean that very often a player in a 5 person game gets only one go per turn. With a need to create food to avoid loans, more often than not this one move is utterly predicatable. A 4 or even better, 3 player game would reap more turns and therefore have to be more fun.

Tokens placed on buildings just to to block them off. Especially the shipping line. Why is shipping so essential? Finally the game did seem to take a long time, after a long time to take in the rules we didn't hang about but it took well over 3 hours.

At this stage I have significant reservations.

Third Play: The penny seems to have dropped. The second play seemed to drag but after playing with people on the third time who knew the rules and had played before the game took shape. I now think this one has legs and will stay in my collection.

Its a slow burn, don't give up after 2 games there is a very good game in there trying to get out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It was long, I got my butt kicked by people who knew this game better than I did, but I enjoyed all 3 hours of it.

What I liked about it, it was like every turn it was discovering something new and exciting to do.  ...and even though it was 4 players, I really did use most of everyone else's turn thinking about what I would do.

My only problem I had, and it's a minor one, is by the time I realized I made a very grave strategic mistake, I just didn't have the game left to make it up.  ...which is either good or bad.  The strategic mistake is that I just didn't put the money into more advanced buildings when I got the chance to do so.  Bear in mind, it wasn't that my 'engine' didn't have the buildings, it was that *I* didn't have the buildings for the opportunities presented to me.

...and for as much as I say this, what I really really liked about it, was it had the economic engine feel to it, but it didn't have the "When do I go for victory points and when do I go to feeding-back into this engine?" question that a lot of economic games have.

To address some comments I read on other geekbuddies list:

Someone mentioned that "it's another game where you build an engine and grind it out..."  that didn't work with the guys I was playing with, at all.  I tried, and fell on my face.  ...and it wasn't that they out-engined me, either.  Most of them made 1-2 big plays, neither were like the other.

The other thing, is that gameplay can be so RADICALLY different from game to game, from buildings you would like coming out late, to hearing about someone hording the wood and basically not allowing anyone to build anything.

So I have to say, great game.

08-20-13 Rating downgraded to a 7, maybe even a 6:  I played this on the ipad, and there is a definite path you must follow in this game overall...get energy, get steel, get points.  Yeah, there are certain ways to get said steel and energy will always be interesting, but in this adventure the other players are never anything more than a temporary nuisance.  It's an IQ test and 3-hour exercise.

An interesting phenomena is that it took about 15 games to get to this point of seeing the same path over and over again, which if I had actually used the board game with people, would be about 35 hours of game time... which is still a fantastic play value.  I think much of the rating has to do with few plays where you think, "I really can do anything in this game.  This is amazing, it's so deep!" until you see that you actually end up doing close to the same things every game.  At least one load-up of cattle and a trip to the abbatoir...or equivalent fish/grain.  At least one trip to the shipping line.  Then it's makin' boats 'n buildings any way you can.

I think of like the old Police Squad episodes.  There would always be the joke, "Cigarette?  Why yes, it is." and a talk with the shoe-shine guy. "Maybe this would refresh your memory..." and he would take the 20 bucks. in every episode.  They would be different, but the same.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Iniciar una conclusión escribiendo que en [url=http://ballearicus.blogspot.com.es/2013/06/le-havre.html#more]Le Havre[/url] me gusta todo, desvela en la primera línea que a este juego no le encuentro en la práctica ninguna pega. Sinceramente no se empezar de otra manera. Creo que estamos ante el modelo a seguir de cómo se debe diseñar un juego, para todo rango de jugadores y diferentes niveles de dificultad.

Puedo concluir que es un juego muy bien pensado y muy testeado, que se adapta y se  metamorfosea como un guante al rango de jugadores y a la exigencia de nivel de dificultad requerido. Además, las sensaciones de juego son totalmente distintas en función de estos parámetros (dificultad y número de jugadores) ya que los edificios, que son la salsa del diseño, están reglados y varían en función de estos parámetros, (no de forma aleatoria como en otros juegos que se retiran al azar), sino de manera concreta, dando lugar a escenarios específicos y calibrados en base estas premisas.

RATING: 8

So if you don't have the patience to get it to the table a few times, it's probably not for you.  Especially given how LONG the game takes.  However, there is definitely an interesting game of optimization going on, and it is interesting to explore if you have the time.  Not for the faint of heart.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Absolutely superb engine building / industry game. Haven't got anything else like it. Staggering amount of options which only increase with more players (although the actions of other players will change the efficiency of various paths to money). Feel like I'm still getting ideas on new potential strategies eight games in. 

The rules are easy to learn but the underlying mechanics will take a few games to get a grip on. The beauty is that you are given a lot of space for you to make your engine work, so you can have a fun time even if you don't win. It takes a while to play, which I thought would be a negative, but time flies away very quickly and it feels like its over before you know it. I don't think the designers could have compressed the game any tighter without taking away the freedom of choice which distinguishes Le Havre from other games.

RATING: 5.5
Worker placement game with a great need to optimize the very few actions you get in a game. Unfortunately this can lead to AP and slow the game down. Le Havre allows specialization where Agricola did punish it. Interaction possibilities between the different buildings seem endless. Game lasts way too long in my opinion for the gameplay it offers. Maybe it will speed up with repeated plays but somehow I doubt this.

Game scales horribly between different number of players. 5 player game is not comparable at all with a 3 player game. Game did not get any better after more plays. Traded away.

RATING: 9.55

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game is a significant improvement over Agricola, because it starts the game with considerably fewer options.  So players are able to become comfortable with those few things and then slowly learn each new ability as it arrives.  This slow build takes away a lot of the new player confusion that can arise with Agricola.  However, this game takes that feel of trying to dig yourself out of a hole to another stratosphere.  I can see what needs to happen in order to get over the hump in this game, but I still have no idea how to make it happen.  So I just find myself getting frustrated.

Perhaps the more annoying aspect of this game for me is simply the fiddliness of it all.  The piles of chits being restocked every turn, the mess of chits that you have to manage, and the annoyance of turning one chit over to create a different chit makes for so much chaos that it just seemed downright chaotic.  Again there is a massive learning curve here, as in Agricola, and it can be frustrating to have your score doubled by a pro.  My only other complaint would be that theme is extremely bland.  It makes sense, for sure, but it really doesn't interest me at all.  I'd much rather play this again than Agricola, but I doubt I will ever suggest it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The food aspect is still a bit odd to me, and I'm not entirely certain that it really fits in the end (aside from as a payment to other players for building use).

There isn't as much processing of each individual good as I might like to see (a bigger chain).

This game makes me want to play other, better, games about production and refinement (Neuland, Roads and Boats).

It's a bunch of "take 10 of one good and make something out of it.  Make something else out of the remainder of that and another good you happen to have."  Takes the problems present in Agricola to the extreme.

RATING: 9
Only one play so far and it is definitely good, very good. As good as Agricola? Better? Not sure yet. Certainly it has the same feeling of masses of options and a shortage of turns - of wanting to do so many things but only being able to do one.

It also has the same feeling of watching your opponents and trying to choose the strategy that will benefit from what they are, and are not taking. You can go all out for short term benefits or plan for the longer term. Definitely want to play it again. Several times in fact.

7 plays and I still enjoy it a lot, maybe not so much as Agricola, it can occasionally drag a little with more than 3 players, but a lot.

Ez egy olyan játék, mellyel bármikor leülök játszani. Egyetlen gondja van, hogy elég hosszú a gondolkodási idők miatt, de van olyan kör, amikor nagyon gyorsan pörög a játék. RATING: 8
As of right now this is my favorite Uwe game. I much prefer the way the tension comes from being the most efficient and getting buildings from other players, rather than having to just worry about surviving like in Agricola.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Update: Yes, this game is way too long.  For a game where every turn is basically take a pile of resources or use a building, it should not take 2-3 hours.  It's so damn repetitive.  And lets not forget having to add resource chits to piles AFTER EVERY PLAYER TURN.  On more than one occasion we have had arguments over whether we had stocked the offer spaces.  All I can say is, KILL ME NOW!

The special buildings are more like Agricola cards than I cared to admit; too many of them, a lot of them will never be used and you only draw six and use even fewer per a game.  Unfortunately, Le Havre needed some variability as the game's strategy is very basic.  Certain buildings are much better than others.  Most games revolve around setting yourself up for cokery and shipping and I still haven't seen anyone use hides to good effect.  Special building should have been that element that suddenly turns fish into something usable.  Instead, even if a good fish building is in there, you may not see it until late in the game when it's far too late to properly use.

At this point I think Agricola is the better game despite being more complex and having its share of flaws.  The brutal battle for resources in that game is just a lot more engaging than the dry optimization of Le Havre.

--

Very strange to see Uwe Rosenburg on a roll of high profile hits.  Considering that prior to Agricola his only notable game was Bohnanza, to seem him become a prolific designer of heavy gamer's games is unexpected.

Le Havre is somewhat similar to Agricola, having many types of resources and again running on a worker placement system.  However, Le Havre is definitely a more tightly designed game than Agricola.  I suspect that the predilections of most gamers would lead them to prefer Agricola because of its empire-building and the neat graphical representation of your farm's expansion.  Le Havre's theme, in contrast is far drier and the nebulous nature of property ownership and the lack of exciting visual cues of your exploding wealth does not excite like a well-developed farm in Agricola.

Some seem to want Le Havre to emulate Agricola's incredibly harsh beginning where food is a precious resource.  I am not sure that fits the theme of Le Havre at all and in fact the whole food thing never made too much sense to me in this game.  Which is not to say I don't understand it's purpose, which is to keep this from being a very staid optimization game by injecting repeated and urgent need to spend actions on food.  I may agree that the need for food is ameliorated too much in the later rounds, which contributes to a somewhat tedious endgame.

My main complaint centers around the length.  As noted, with food no longer pressing, the endgame devolves into an exercise in calculating which set of actions nets you the most points.  Thus, your last impression of the games does nothing to improve the perception of a game that has long run its course.  The short game is a more appropriate length, but you lose special buildings and some normal buildings and the former really add to the game.  Yes, among the special buildings are a few duds, but it's nothing like Agricola's cards.

In summary, I am not sure Le Havre justifies the length of play given it's unimaginative mix of mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Heavy yet dead simple. Take an offer or enter a building. Buy or sell buildings and the next guys turn. I feel worn out at the end of every game. And yes, that is the sign of a good game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of my favorite games of all time and my favorite Uwe game. The mechanics are simple but the depth of decision making is vast. There is pressure to do many things and lots of options at every turn. You never feel that you haven enough time to finish everything and the order in which the buildings come out each game has a HUGE impact on everything. I marvel that this game is simply a worker placement game with a single worker. So brilliant and for me the ultimate example of streamlined and deep design. Some complain that the shipping is too overpowered, but of course it is overpowered...the game is about shipping! If all players are aware, then the fierce competition for resources (coal, coke, iron, steel) is phenomenal and the tension to see who can time things better is palpable. A wonderful game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not at all the same constant fight for survival as in Agricola, instead resources is abundant and one has to build the best engine possible with the buildings available. Really like this game as either a 2 or 3 player game, but will not turn down a 4 player game either. The only thing missing is some more expansions to give it even more variety.

RATING: 4

Maybe if you had a group of really experienced players, this wouldn't be an issue. Maybe. I'm not sure how to get to that stage without a bunch of awful games though.

RATING: 7
This economic game created by Uwe Rosenberg is a brain killer. Rules are clear but game is complex and challenging. 
If you like games like this You should give a shot. Playing this I always feel like under the huge pressure because I have to plan my moves precisely for the whole round (!), one mistake and my strategy for the specific round can be totally destroyed.

- it shouldn't be the first contact with euro type games
- created for experienced players (box does not contain such information), newbies can quickly discourage themselves to this type of game.

- playing time (120-200 minutes)
- no fun in this game, just heavy strategy all the time
- lack of scorebook :(

**You can try this game on tablet or smartphone - it is availible for iOS and Android. It is the same like in real & costs much about 5$.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After a couple of solo plays I quite like this game!  It's interesting and rewards good planning in the solo game.  I'm looking forward to playing with other people, as building blocking and resource grabbing look like they'll be very important.

I really enjoy this game.  Something about it just draws me in.  It's very strategic, rewards planning and efficency, but also requires you to be adaptable and creative at the drop of a hat!  I've played several times with other players now, and I will not be playing solo again.  I'm not much of a solo player to begin with, and I cannot see the point of going back to this without the challenge of another player or multiple players. I do like how the game adjusts itself to accomodate the number of players so well.  Brilliant design!

After 21 plays I'm still loving this game.  The number of options is tremendous and the subtle interactions and timing decisions have a long term impact on the game.  You need to be able to manage a number of different facets at a single time (food, ships, buildings, resources and evaluate the impact of what doing something now as opposed to trying a wait longer) yet work it all into a cohesive long term plan.  I'm still learning to try and work the special buildings into my plans on a more consistent basis and do get caught ignoring one of the facets from time to time.  Just an amazing game and one I'll continue playing for a long time to come.  Best with 2 to 3 players, acceptable with four.  If you want a five-player game I would not recommend Le Havre.

My first 10 rated game.

If you've been around GCL at all, my love affair with Le Havre should come to you as no surprise. It's a brilliant mix of planning and adaptation with a liberal dash of little choices having big long term effects. The end game is generally similar, but there are so many different paths to get there, and the game really rewards aggressive play (in the form of blocking) tempered with restraint (you can damage yourself more than your opponent if you're too aggressive with blocking). Even after 79 plays I'm nowhere near done with this game. I would like to play it more with 3+ players, but my group has now told me that they won't be playing this or Agricola with me anymore, due to the difference in experience, so I'm not sure how that's going to happen.

RATING: 8.5
This is a great resource management game but to rate or understand this game, I think you need to have played it at least three times.  At first play, it is not apparent what you need to do to succeed and win.  Players who first try it will find it quite open-ended and daunting when the starvation factor escalates.  Le Havre is quite elegant in it's design especially with the double sided chits,and card setup.  It takes a bit of time to setup but with a good storage solution for the chits, this time can be halved.  With the included Le Grand Hameau expansion, the game variations are almost endless.

RATING: N/A
1st multilingual edition NIS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is from the same designer that gave us Agricola (Ewe Rosenberg), and there are many similarities. Commodities accumulate and players choose between taking a stack of goods that are raw materials for building or producing food, or building things with the materials you've collected. All aimed at accumulating wealth (=VPs). You need food and several methods for staving off hunger (need to take loans) are provided. You have a worker that bounces about the table as a means of recording a specific action you've chosen.

The theme is the hustle and bustle associated with a trading port like Le Havre, so is a somewhat more sophisticated (industrialized) model than the agrarian Agricola. I agree that the theme is not as well realized, but the familiar tension of having to choose between many things, all of which you would like to do, is still very much there.

I enjoyed the first game I played but also agree that five players is very challenging, not to mention long! I'm not sure you need copies of both Agricola and this despite the very different themes. Enjoyable enough, but it seemed like more of the same to me, and a little dryer for reasons I can't quite put my finger on...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Longer cousin to Agricola. different randomness than agricola, more control and more likely to suffer from AP. 

Not sure I'd want to play with 5, and even 4 is pushing it (takes too long).

Update - current play group have got burned out on Le Havre quite quickly. Play length is the main factor, and concerns over certain buildings. Rating dropped.

Unlikely to see much play now, on the trade pile.

Update - played it again, and liked it less, I think I dislike the way you can (or can't) apply a strategy, you can't go in deciding to do X, and even picking a route to victory early on isn't that viable as it's possible to have a vital building blocked. So given the length I find the annoyances overwhelm the stuff I like - overall much prefer to play Agricola. 

*** Traded, unlikely to play this again. Just too dry and mechanical, and the AP ... Agricola is similar enough for me to always want to play that rather than this. Rating dropped, again. Quite surprised how quickly I burned out on this one :(

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An economic engine game set in a french port.  Le Havre could be classified as another multiplyer-solitaire title and you wouldn't be that far off the mark.  However the "puzzle" Le Havre presents isn't as easy to solve or as deterministic as it is in other lesser titles like Puerto Rico or Agricola.  In other words, when I played Le Havre, I didn't feel that my choices were obvious nor forced by the actions of the other players.  The game gave me a lot of latitude in choosing how best to grow my shipping concern.  It's this opaqeness of its puzzle and the latitude it offers that makes it an enjoyable game for me.

Le Harve rates a solid 7 in my book due to it's gameplay and the fact it's a very friendly 2p title.  Just make sure you address the food issue first thing every turn and you'll have a good time.  Definitely the best of the Agricola. Le Havre and Loyang trilogy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Inclusive with Le Grande Hameau expansion and some self printed player mats for the storage of the goods!
Try the advanced version with 2 Francs to pay for 2,3 or 4 taken loans (depends from number of players!) Maybe played with a small modification in use of the Grand Hameau Cards. Every player gets two personal GH cards in his hands in a 1st turn whitout harvest! Only one of them can be later be bought, when a player sell his own previously built or bought building to the city. The other GH card must then be discarded and is out of play.

RATING: 10

Something's very satisfying about converting resources- smoking fish, slaughtering cattle, baking bread, making steel etc.  Lots of variety from the cards and always tons of options on your turn.  Similar to and not quite as good as, Ora et Labora- my favorite Uwe game.  Awesome and very fun.

1-5 | (3) | 150 min | 12+ | Uwe Rosenberg
For some reason I thought Le Havre would be too similar to Agricola, but after just one play I liked Le Havre a lot more. Not only is the design very elegant (lots of depth with very few rules): everything flows smoothly in this game. I also love the fact that you can specialize.

June 2010: First impressions can be deceptive. The fact that goals are shared in Agricola means there is more competition and interaction. After some more plays, Agricola tops Le Havre, though admittedly not by much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A solid follow-up to Agricola. Uwe does it again! A geekbuddy said that it doesn't have the same out-of-the-box appeal which I agree with. I think this game has a steep learning curve. And it is certainly a gamer's game and not meant for casual gamers.

The game does tend to progressively bog down as the number of available actions becomes overwhelming. However, after a few plays, the buildings become familiar and gameplay should speed up.

Wouldn't want to play with 5.

I also own the complete 12 expansion cards from Essen 2008.

Edit: After 5 plays, it seems that a dominant strategy is to go for the craft buildings. First player advantage that is not scaled. Also, the game slows down as it progresses because of the increasing number of available options.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Tight and heavy optimizing game. I generally don't like games like this that take very long time to play and have down time between player turns. In Le Havre the beginning goes smoother but the later rounds can drag a bit. Five players is definitely too much and with four the game lasts easily 4 hours. That's about one hour too much for my taste.

Nevertheless I'd play it again and it's a good game for those who are more into such games (like Agricola etc.)

RATING: 10
A solid game, and in some ways I like it more than Agricola.  However, I also end up feeling like I've just been WORKING for a couple of hours after playing this one.  Not sure that a game should be so exhausting.   The psychology of having to battle to break-even is a tricky one.   Agricola feels the same way.

Jan 2011:   After a few more plays, rating up to a 9.  This is a game that although I'm not in the mood for it all the time due to game length, I do find it very engaging each time we play.

Sep 2011:  Rating changed from a 9 to 10.  Still really like this game, and think that it's probably the best of its class.  There seems to be enough different ways to win that it really shouldn't get stale for a while.   Would love to see some more expansions for this that don't necessarily complicate the game, but maybe replace or add to the basic buildings.  

Dec 2011:  My favorite game right now!

RATING: 8
I thought I didn't like this game because I tried the iOS app and found it uninteresting. Wow, have I been missing out all these years. The app is a terrible way to learn this game, as the whole game is predicated on being able to clearly read all the building cards (which is incredibly hard to do on a phone). 

This is a very interesting, refreshingly different game from Uwe's other worker placement games. I like that it's not nearly as punishing, with far more choices on your turn than in, say, Agricola. There is very little blocking, but the game feels different every time because of the timing of the building cards. Good times.

RATING: 8

The choices are tough because there are so many good things available every turn. The only bad part is that the game can get a little too long, specially with inexperienced players as they learn what all the buildings do.

RATING: 9
Ignore the comments that this is too similar to Agricola.  Other than the worker placement mechanic, the game feels completely different. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terrific fun! The solo game is ok, but the 2p game is fantastic. Its similar to Agricola in feel and tension, but there's a much longer building track. There's definitely a learning curve to this game too -- you have to know the buildings, and you have to think both tactically (what resources do I need now) and strategically (what do I want to do in the next round or two). You have very limited actions and need to think very hard about what to do with them. My wife and I enjoyed this immensely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Obviously derives from the same roots but, so far, I'm inclined to like it more than I did Agricola (although I'm not sure if it's actually a better game) as it offers more options as time goes on, whereas Agricola feels like the opposite.  Agricola provides more options each round, but there are less and less available to you as you use up your actions.  The difference then may be that Le Harve feels more expansive than restrictive, which for me is a good thing.

RATING: 9
J1
C1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played this one again recently and liked it quite a bit, so up the rating goes again. I think 4 players might be the sweet spot; you get to use all the buildings, and the pace improves a bit, as each player's turn is a bit shorter but you have more options. Definitely not a game for the overly contemplative, as it's a touch too long to start with, but it's not too bad. Play the short game the first time out.

It's true that the endgame is all about Steel and Coke. But the nice thing about Le Havre is that there are a lot of ways to get there in the early and middle game, and quite a few special buildings can change things up in interesting ways (in general, the specials that are targeted at the mid to late game are far more interesting and game-altering than the ones targeted for the early game, which has a lot of variety already, to the point that I'd consider editing the deck).

---

This is still a game I'm torn on. It's fun and interesting, but like Agricola, the variability is less than it seems. Also, while playing the short game is an appealing option to bring the playtime under control, you also lose the flavor of the special buildings, which are a key element in giving the game some variety and a little edge.

All in all, it definitely feels like it's not all there, and the length is very problematic. I still like it; but it's not a game that's ever going to come out a ton.
---
My general feeling on Le Havre is:
- The sweet spot is probably 3 or 4 players;
- The "full" game doesn't add a lot over the "short" game, and probably isn't worth the extra 45-60 minutes or so it takes to play. The full game gets a bit repetitive.

In general, I think Le Havre is the better and more elegant design when compared to Agricola, but Agricola is way more thematic and has the better nebulous "fun factor". I wish the food situation was just a little tighter in Le Havre, to tighten up the pacing a bit and keep the players under pressure, especially in light of the relative painlessness of loans.

I definitely feel the balance here isn't quite right. You can't win without Coke/Steel, and loans are definitely not nearly punishing enough.
---
As my enthusiasm for Agricola has been fading a touch, and as I've been ramping up on Le Havre, I actually feel like Le Havre feels like the more solid, if somewhat less flavorful, game, so it might outlast Agricola. On the other hand, it is a bit long. Not sure on the ultimate verdict yet, but I like it so far.
---
Hey, this was pretty fun. I ordered it with some reservations, since Mr Rosenberg isn't hugely reliable and my enthusiasm for Agricola was cooling a bit. But Le Havre was fun - like Agricola, it's in the "like Caylus but doesn't suck" category. I don't know if it will ultimately hold as much interest as Agricola, as the theme gets very little traction, and it feels like it might get a bit repetitive, but I'm glad I took the chance and picked it up.

I'd recommend taking their advice about 5 players to heart and playing Le Havre with 4 or fewer (2 worked well) your first few times out.

RATING: 6

Buy this to turn into that, now get this so I have some energy to turn this other thing into something else so I can buy a building which allows me to.... bla bla bla.  In the end, I thought it was pretty decent, but nothing ground breaking or innovative.  I think in Agricola's case, the theme is really what made it fun, and Le Havre really lacks that element that makes it fun.  More of the same cube pushing that ATers always complain about, except it's chit pushing in this case and not extremely exciting chit pushing at that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Updated 5/26/10.  

I've played this game quite a bit now, primarily 2-player, and I think it's time that I acknowledge that I've been letting the game slide on Agricola's coattails for too long.  Le Havre is a very good game, with a design that I admire, but it is not a particularly "fun" game, and I suspect that it needs a dedicated group of regulars to really shine.      

Caveat: I have one 3-player game and zero 4+ player games under my belt.  I actually think the two-player game has more tension as you can anticipate your opponent's needs better and jostle/block/screw more effectively.  Also, the added actions per turn allow for a little more engine-building goodness before the harvest.  I'm open to playing with 3+ again though to get a better feel for the game. 

As a simple overview, Le Havre is a game where you get resources to build buildings that produce more resources or better resources, or that convert resources into upgraded resources...all of which is a long process to buy or build ships that you use to export your resources for profit. 

Le Havre appears to be an engine-building game, but unlike, say, Race for the Galaxy, you are building an engine that is available to everyone (at a minor cost).  I used to love that the buildings are open to all players.  Over time, I've grown disappointed, though, as almost every building gets built every game.  Thus, it doesn't really allow for specialization, like an engine-building game ought to.  So it lacks a little oomph.

Some people have complained that the game lacks replay value because some items (steel and coke) are more desirable than others.  I haven't encountered this issue, and the two-player game especially allows players flexibility to adapt on the fly and try unusual strategies.  Subtle things like randomly distributing the harbor tiles every game also help prevent the "standard opening" problem of games like Puerto Rico.  That said, I'm not particularly good at games of this sort.  My typical scores in the long game are in the 220s to 250s, where expert players say that 300 should be the target. 

Other concerns: (1) No catch-up mechanic that I've discovered.  This isn't a game with a runaway leader problem exactly (everyone can use all the buildings), but disparate skill levels can ruin the game because there is no advantage to being behind.  (2) Time, hence value.  With setup and cleanup, this game just takes so long and has so many rules that I'm not sure it will hit the table with many of my friends.  The more I play with my few experienced friends, however, the bigger problem Concern #1 presents. (3) Fun.  Right now, I'm loving trying to "solve" the game, but the activity of playing is not always particularly exciting/enjoyable.  The long game especially can drag.  (4) AP.  Don't say I didn't warn you!

On notes (2) and (3) above, I waffle on whether I prefer the short game or the long game.  On the one hand, the first few rounds of the standard version are essentially just collecting resources and maybe building a building or two.  On the other hand, the long version introduces special buildings, which definitely helps keep the game from getting stale.  Perhaps more importantly, it has a sense of engine-building and specialization that is missing in the short version.  Right now, I'm leaning back toward the long game (but it is LONG).

I do think that the resource tiles are unnecessarily fiddly (and I love fiddly games).  I finally got some storage boxes, and it helps, but still... 

The verdict:

Le Havre is one of the better games I've played.  It's well-constructed, well-designed, and very interesting.  It's also more accessible to us economically-challenged players than, say, Power Grid or Imperial.  Still, there's something that nags at me.  I feel as though I'm supposed to like it more than I actually like it.  I guess that's another way of saying Concern #3 above is a pretty big concern.  Only additional plays will tell whether the rating holds up for me personally, but as of today, it's a fading 8.

RATING: 7
Another solid economic, goods-conversion Rosenburg Euro. The game does have a nice escalation as players add buildings to their tableau during the course of the game. Le Havre is also much more forgiving than some other Rosenburg games, like Agricola, when it comes to feeding your workers. The game did feel a bit too sandbox-y for my taste as there is so many things to do. The game also does run a bit long at higher player counts. Definitely a 2 or 3 player game in my book. Nevertheless, it's a solid game for fans of Uwe.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Uwe Rosenberg does a great job implementing the shipping / manufacturing theme of Le Havre - I like building "economic engines", so this game is right up my alley.  I love the variety of buildings and the ability to sell buildings and ships at any time.  I especially like how strategic investment in buildings that other players want to use can provide one with a source of income, in addition to saving one from having to pay entry fees.  The worker placement aspect works well and the ability to continuously block a particular building at the expense of not being able to do anything except take goods or buy / sell seems balanced.  The only thing that might be a bit off is the scaling of the food payment required at the end of each round.  Oh, and fiddling with the hundreds of tiny tiles can be somewhat annoying.  Still, one of my favourite games!
