=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game! One of my favorite of all time - I basically like everything about it.

It is such a hard game to master as there are always sooo many things you want to do, but you can only do one measly thing (or more if you want to buy/sell buildings), and that is extremely frustrating - in a good way! 
I guess this is one of Uwe's characteristics as it also plays a big part in Agricola and At The Gates Of Loyang - I must say that I really like frustrating elements (which can also be found in good games like In The Year Of The Dragon etc.)

I guess you need to plan a little ahead and have some sort of strategy in Le Havre, but in our first game we got along fine without knowing the buildings, which I guess will make it an even better game in the future when we get to know them (update: yes, it is an even better game now!). 

Ships seem to be important and it's probably very hard to win without owning a single ship, but if everybody knows that, I guess there is no problem. And even if you build a ship or two or three you sure aren't going to win just because of that! There is so much going on all the time and you need to make some very important decisions each turn - it's just lovely!

My only concern is the (strategic) replayability; yes, there is definitely some variety, but most games tend to be about getting a lot of coke and steel and ship those goods. It's hard to win without doing that, at least that's my experience after playing Le Havre ~20 times.
Also, I don't like that getting a loan (or several) is not that bad; I think the penalty for getting those should be increased.

I guess we have to compare it to Agricola, another one of Uwe's games, and my personal favorite, like many do... However, to me, Le Havre honestly didn't remind me of Agricola at all except for the facts that ressources accumulate until somebody grabs them and that you need to have enough food at the end of a round - and that is where the (lovely) frustrations and your planning come into play! 

It takes more time to play compared to other games (2-2.5 hours with 3 players, though I've finished a 2 player game in just a bit more than 1 hour), but the good thing is that there is not a lot of downtime between turns, at least in the first half of the game. 
You basically move your ship and grab some goods or place your worker, and it's the latter which can be a tough decision as to where to place him, especially during the end game when there are so many options. Overall, though, the gameplay has been really smooth in my gamegroup. 

I will probably only play it with 2 or 3; the reason is that with 4 or 5, you only get one turn in some rounds which I think can be pretty brutal and hard to plan around. Also, there are so many other great games for 4-5 players which will hit the table instead of Le Havre.

All in all, Le Havre is a fantastic game which I'm sure I will be playing a lot in the future!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
More fun than Agricola as players can develop in any way they like rather than having to work towards the same well-rounded but ultimately inefficient farm. Timing is everything, particularly towards the end. The downside is that as more and more buildings become available, players with AP may slow the game down to a crawl and it's a long game already. Familiarity with the cards (or just the ability to see the minute symbols on them from across the table) would surely help with planning.

RATING: 10

One other plus is that it is less stressful than Agricola, while still have a risk reward system.

RATING: 8
It's one of those games where 3 hours later you look at your watch and expect only an hour to have passed.  The game moves along at a nice zippy pace leaving you with only one or two actions to do per round - so it's good that there are 20 rounds to get your goals accomplished.  It feels like Agricola in that you have build your point scoring machine while still having to worry about feeding your people, which can hinder your plans for most of the game.  However, it does feel less punishing and doesn't force you to dip into every area of the game to have a competitive score, which is a welcome change.  Even though I still prefer Agricola, the pace and ease to explain the rules make this one worth trying out.

RATING: 6
Rated 7 after one play. But admittedly, that's a bit difficult, as this game requires multiple plays for a fair rating. 

A good friend/fellow gamer kept good-naturedly hounding me to play this game. "I hadn't played Le Havre?!" Nope, largely because I knew this mega-resource 2+ hour conversion game would take some time, and I was probably lazy. Now that I've played it once, I can guess it won't be my favorite, but it's not awful.

Things going against it are the play length and the fact that there's a bit of solitaire play going on. Plus, I tend to enjoy games that offer a harsh system instead of a "playground" of options. 

However, things going for it are that the resource conversion options are actually fairly thematic. If felt different to pump out fish or bread vs. coal or iron. Although a first play left me ignorant to the various buildings that later emerged, the game offers a nice story arc. And lastly, I dig the fact that on your turn you're basically gobbling resources or choosing a building. The only drawback is the dizzying array of choices (though I'm sure that gets better with familiarity). 

Bottom line -- I'd play this again and see if my opinion improves with familiarity.

Update: Check that initial rating. Bump it up to an 8. After playing it the night before, I'm still thinking about it and possible strategies. I'd like to try this as a three player game.

Update: OK, so I played a three player game, and this drops to a 6, where I think it will stay. Between the plays, I played a couple of games of Agricola and Homesteaders. Both are resource heavy games, and both I ultimately like better. Homesteaders is the closest comparison, with a number of resources, buildings with different abilities, and expanding options. However, Homesteaders offers an auction that is more engaging, and it plays in half the time.

RATING: 6
(6-4-10; initial impression after first play) What this game does, it does very well: it provides a very intricate and robust exercise in resource conversion. It does not feel tight by any means, but that is not necessarily a negative. The vast tableau of building options is quite overwhelming and, besides what appears to be a late-game run for the big VP converters, there isn't a ton of competition for buildings. The build-up of the resources on the offer spots becomes an embarrasment of riches, and the temptation to chase the big piles needs to be fought. This is not to say it is a loose game. It just allows for a incredible amount of creativity to build a VP engine. Unfortunately, efficiency engines just not being my thing, this will likely never be a favorite. Regardless of the level of interaction that might be achieved by serious players, I can't imagine this game moving too far beyond an exercise in playing more against the game than against other players. And for a game that can take a considerable amount of time, I don't see jumping at the opportunity to play this too much. 

One issue that I found iritating on the first play was the very little opportunity to make money off buildings. As the scale of the game grows, the payments to use building seem paltry. Moreover, it felt like some of the buildings are really only there for the VPs. Of course, there are probably good uses for just about all of them that I just didn't get on my first play. Not surprising.

RATING: 8

2nd play. Stays at an 8. It's a deep deep game. The mechanics are great and it plays very smoothly. I just don't know quite what to make of it yet. Very much looking forward to play #3 to see what else I can figure out.  

Trade interest extremely low. Don't feel like I should move on from it, but will trade for certain highly desired items. 

Traded away. In the end, it was just more work than I cared for, without the type of reward I am looking for. It's a great game, but its not my game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Sweet Jesus, this game is boring with a capital B...and an uppercase 'oring', thanks in part to the utterly deriative theme. Sure, there's strategy involved and a lot of decisions to make (particularly as more buildings come into play), but interaction is largely non-existant - you can't even reasonably deny people from resources like in similar games, for gods sake. Everyone continually loops round a straight 'track' with different resources on each spot, and only the player whose turn it currently is can decide to take the resources there or not. The closest you'll get to interaction is buying a good building first, or blocking others from using a building while you're in it.

In addition, the game is absoloutely painful if anyone suffers from AP, even with only three players. Mind you, even if everyone takes their turns fairly quick it still goes on for far too long, with lame ducks potentially forced to sit through an excruciating 1 to 1 1/2 hours for the end to finally come. At least, say, Race for the Galaxy has the decency to end quickly when one or more people are in 'lame duck' situations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:tobacco: :) :D :D :) :what: So I've long maintained that I prefer Le Havre to Agricola, but I'm forced to rethink a little bit. The acid test: I have the iOS versions of both, and even allowing for the fact that iAgricola is marginally quicker and more polished visually than Le iHavre, and even allowing for the fact that Agricola's the new hotness for me the play stats tell a story: over a hundred games on the farm vs. maybe one in the harbor. Them numbers don't lie. One-nil to the 'Gric. Top 10 adjusted accordingly. 
Regardless of the relative merits of the two, and the inevitable urge to compare them, I would definitely say that (dis)liking one does not imply (dis)liking the other. Obviously, I like both, but they are different experiences.

Agricola is a leaky boat in a small but choppy lake that a snake has just gotten into; you know exactly where the shore is but you've got a lot of bailing and snake rasslin' to do before you get to shore. Le Havre is a sturdy vessel in a calm blue ocean with no land in sight, no map, and a busted GPS; you pretty much have to commit to a course of action and hope like hell you're going in the right direction.

[UPDATE: I have subsequently started picking up games of iOS Le Havre (and a face-to-face game with the actual bits) after a long period of neglect (and burning myself out with the aforementioned hundred-plus games of Agricola) and reminded myself of why I like it, though Agricola still shines a bit brighter. But both are nines for me, solidly, and which one I play depends on mood more than a head-to-head comparison where one comes solidly on top.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
More and more I'm learning that I like games where on my turn, I make decisions that I hope will encourage my opponents to make decisions that are in my interest too. Agricola has a small amount of this because differentiation is so strongly rewarded: action selections are a kind of bid ("stay away from this path and we will both profit"). I didn't see any evidence of this in Le Havre, which doesn't make it a bad game, but it does help make it one I'm not really interested in these days.

Other things in Le Havre that make it lousy for me include the unreal amount of information and lookahead that players need to process to play well (our 4-handed game was at least as computationally demanding as 5p Agricola), the dumb, tedious refilling of resource spaces every turn (also bad in Agricola but more annoying here because it happens 140 times instead of 14, literally an order of magnitude more even if each restocking here is only a couple of chits), but above all else the art.

Le Havre has such bad interface design that it makes Agricola look like Go. The game is an absolute mess on the table. The cards have lovely Where's Waldo art on them but print important information in tiny, hard-to-read font in colors that are not always that different from the background. The icons for resources are barely OK when they're right in front of me and are certainly not OK at any distance. The difference good presentation makes, especially in a 'hard' (information-heavy) game like this, can be huge.

RATING: 8

1. It was just too long (especially for newer players and people who I would play boardgames with)

That, to me, is more like a job than a fun thing to do. 

BUT, I rated this game an 8 - these two points are moot and they are my personal experience only. The game as a whole - is a pretty awesome game. You should definately play it a - it is balanced to perfection and make sure you make the most of the special building cards :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In collection since 2013
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is yet another take on the worker placement game, though it emphasizes that element a lot less than its older sibling Agricola. Like Agricola, it's rather difficult to explain quickly though. Suffice to say that each round there are 7 player turns. When a player's turn comes up, they add some resources to the available spaces, and can then do two things: 1) take resources from one of the available resource spaces without placing or moving their only worker. 2) Place or move their worker to an open building spot. Buildings starts out seeded in a limited fashion in town and can be later built by players. They do the usual worker placement stuff: make basic resources which can be refined into more advanced stuff for some trouble, some of which can be sold for VPs directly (in this game via the purchasable ships with the use of shipping lines or via some VP creation shops) and some of which can be used to put up better buildings which score a load of VPs ala Puerto Rico but which also have in-game uses. Like Agricola, this game has a food pressure element. Unlike Agricola, there are no significant random elements that are not shared by the players. The buildings that are available for sale are sort of randomized, but the order they will come out in is known. This appeals to me.

This game is like Caylus in that players are sometimes tempted to spend too much time looking at what the buildings actually do versus how much they're worth. A major reason why you want to put up anything, at least for the first part of the game, is because it is giving you a very good VP return on your chit investment. The coins and food you have coming in when people use them, like Caylus, is a sideshow. The ability to use your own for free is certainly more powerful than in Caylus, but paying attention to the VP value should still be a high priority. That said, there are certain combos that can be very useful to have (i.e.: buildings that feed off of having certain symbols, easy access to a favoured terminus building or any pairing of buildings that helps refine base materials into finished goods at one spot and then sell it at the next) and keeping that in mind can also be useful...this is a definite plus over Caylus where I think the building ability really is almost pure fluff most of the time.

The main flow of the game seems to be build up stuff with an eye on putting up one or two buildings, use those to create a critical mass of something, and then use that something to either cash in or put up valuable buildings and/or ships. You don't need to own all of the buildings that you plan to use regularly, but it definitely helps because of the lack of continual entry fees which can really make otherwise useful buildings unalluring, especially when you're relying on loans to cover end of round costs.

Overall, I think this game is a good take on the worker placement genre, though it's more loosely in that genre than most that I would slap the label on. I like it quite a bit more than Agricola (my #2 game in this style), and that has made me drop my rating for that game a point. One thing that is challenging here is that it has the opposite tension of Agricola, and it seems to always catch me when I play: the temptation to try and do too many things at once. The game constantly presents you with seeming gifts, but if you take them all, you'll never have enough time to do anything. Unlike Agricola, figuring out one or two good ways to produce VPs in this game is crucial, and deviating from that single-mindedness will slow you down and leave you eating the dust of the person who is staying on task more effectively. It's very important that you have a use for all of the chits you're gathering...I see many new players left with extra crap at the end of the game and they are forced to just use the Bridge over the Seine to get rid of it all. Avoid the temptation, find a strategy and stick with it and you should be rewarded.

In terms of length, this game is considerably longer than Agricola, at least if one plays the full game. I can see why some people like the short game, because it eliminates a few of the silly early turns, but the players in the long game seem to develop a larger collection of buildings, and the overall story arc is more full and interesting. I would be reluctant to play the short game at this point, though the long game is definitely in the over 2 hour range, which some people will find too much for a game of this type.

Upsides: interesting variety of ways to approach it. No randomness outside of the setup phase and special buildings, which are, for the most part, usable by anyone anyway.

Downsides: analyzable as a result. The kind of game that encourages study, and where those who have studied will mop up those who aren't as knowledgeable. At least it's not on BSW, which will likely keep people further down the learning curve, thankfully.

The bottom line: this will likely appeal more to the hardcore Euro crowd who dislikes randomness and who is annoyed by some of those elements in Agricola. It is not as accessible though, and will be very unforgiving of player skill disparity. Like Caylus, it is probably a little too long for what it is. I like it more than Agricola currently by a fair margin: I like the shared random cards of Havre vs. the personalized random cards of Agricola and I also like the scoring system here that doesn't reward spreading out into every area every game like Agricola does. 

Repeat play also seems to confirm what I initially suspected, this game gets better with additional play. Part of this is because you can become more familiar with the buildings, the other part is simply having a better feel for what you can do with the different things you're collecting and how to manage your stuff. One initial impulse that players have is to actually try and keep up with the feeding perfectly at all times, and that, overall, seems to be a mistake as well-timed loans are often worth much more than they cost and are the quickest way to accrue large piles of stuff. In general, AP seems to be decrease with experience as well, as it is easier to evaluate what the pile of chits that you've collected should be turned into. Solid work by Rosenberg though, definitely one of the best of 2008. It also scales down extremely well and is a particularly excellent 2 player game. The extra actions you get at the lower scale actually make me favour it more at the 2-3 scale. The game is also shorter while giving each player more actions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An excellent building game, with a lot of strategies, different paths to victory, small downtime and good replayability

RATING: 8
Resource management game with lots of difficult choices (as is true with the best types of these games).  Escalating food requirements in each round keeps the pressure up.  Have played with 2, 3, and 4 players (and solo), never with 5.  The "sweet spot" seems to be with either 2 or 3 players.

I find this game interesting to play, yet can be highly frustrating at the same time.  I sometimes think that the "Harbor Watch" special building should be a regular building, perhaps even with three players.

RATING: 10
WOW! I love this game. Its a different vibe than Agricola (I miss the cards) but also has similar concepts.

A building and shipping game in its core, it has very deep strategies and very little, if any, luck. If you didn't like Agricola only because of the randomness the cards added, this is the game for you. It is a bit more of a "gamer's game" than Agricola, and if you like Agricola you should like this game as well.

Worth owning both.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent game! I prefer it to the basic Agricola because it is more flexible. There is more than victory path and there is more flexibility in pursuing certain victory path. I have not given Le Havre 10 because, firstly, some of the special buildings are too situational. The buildings are one of the few elements that keep the game fresh but too often they have minimal impact on the gameplay. Secondly, I find the theme of Le Havre somewhat strange and counterintuitive. Why do I have to feed my workforce at the certain point of time? This makes sense in Agricola (harvest represents time from autumn to spring) but not in Le Havre. Why does grain multiply in my warehouse? Why does a single grain token multiply but not a single cattle token? Surely the cattle marker does not stand for just one animal given the scale of harbour business? etc However, these issues are really minor gripes.

RATING: 9
Wow. Very pleasantly surprised. Only because I like it much more than Agricola. This almost feels Knizia-like in its math progressions. This hit all the right buttons for me, starting with the great bits, and great rules. I love how turns are so simple. And you can sort of see what's coming up, and make some plans, but the thing you might want could be blocked by someone going there first, but there are plenty of options usually. I love how you don't really need to understand the cards to play the first game. So it's almost trivially simple to explain and get into. There's a strong temptations to get "stuff". In my two games so far, both times I've ended with tons of extra resources. Seems like learning how to fix that would be a good thing. We played with 3 players, which just from the feel it seems the best number. The 3 hour playing time is well exagerated, if people are focussed. This is NOT Through The Ages long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's interesting to read through the low-rated comments for this game. Many do not truly understand what kind of class Le Havre belongs to, so their remark becomes just as artificial and constructed as the game is.

Le Havre is, at its heart, [i]resource conversion[/i]. Pick up one resource, transform it into another using simple rules (and possibly another resource); then spend that converted resource on something else. In Le Havre you have two options: another resource or points + privately owned (but publically usable) resource conversion rules. There is little snowballing; it is not an economic engine; it is not worker placement (because only one resource conversion action can be blocked per player). Where is the challenge in this conversion process: managing blockages and shortages caused by other players (for example contention at a resource conversion rule to turn iron into steel, or contention to decide to go for that rule or the stack of fish to avoid a penalty at the end of the round), and squeezing more points out of your conversion process than your opponent. Yes, resource conversion blocking does have a similar feel to being excluded in a worker placement game; but it's a side effect in Le Havre, not the main intent. The main idea is to simply come up with a conversion path which works better than that of an opponent. Making the issue difficult is that the path is not really decided upon prior to the game's start: it evolves along with the actions of the players. The trick is in recognising tactical opportunity more than in developing strategic paths save very obvious ones.

It is then clear why there is so much debate on which of the two (actually, three) 'harvest trilogy' games is 'best'. Many would not even consider Loyang, even shun it, but it deserves a spot still the same. Agricola isn't about resource conversion but worker placement, although it does share the resource [i]taking[/i] as well as the breaking effect of food on the player's own little empire. Agricola's strong point is in recognising synergies of a [i]personal[/i] set of cards which allow the player to 'work around' the limitations of the shared worker placement actions. Then Loyang: a simple resource conversion game, but makes resources privately held in addition to featuring no brake; instead the players are simply required to perform the absolute best they can. Action cards are drawn from and bartered against a common pool, and become privately held for a short time; there is with the exception of one action no limit on how many actions a player can take in his own turn. So which is best? For me, Loyang. The braking effect of Agricola and Le Havre feels annoyingly artificial, introduced just to give players pause about the balance of their actions. You don't get rewarded for exceeding the game's demands here: in Loyang, on the other hand, you [i]are[/i]... Because, quite simply, you'll do better as a whole! Loyang is also the simplest to set up and explain, featuring a modest deck of action cards. Yes, there is a disadvantage too: ultimately, less replayability.

In any case back to Le Havre. Personally, I think that it is mostly the game's length that kills it for me. There really is too little interesting stuff to do, and too much battle against artificial emotionless food numbers, to fill the length of time it takes to completion. Le Havre is all about becoming frightfully good at pushing lots of buttons operating complex machinery: one of my least favourite ways of being entertained. I want to creatively out-think my opponents, and that's not something that happens here. The game is simply too tactical in nature... And although such titles have a place too in my collection, they should definitely have a shorter playing time.

What I also find an issue already is the game's presentation. It is annoying to peer at others' tableau of cards trying to read what the cards do. You do remember a part of what is in front of players after a while; but sometimes you realise that you're playing in too complex a fashion because this-and-that card would aid you considerably. I gather it's even worse in Le Havre's successor, Ora & Labora. It does not make me want to go out and play that game, to be honest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My rating for the game reflects the fact that I tend to steer away from fiddly games.  And this one, with all it's little bits certainly qualifies.  While I like the game, it falls into another game category that I tend to stay away from: games where your ability to play is really enhanced by knowing what the various cards do.  For you to play effectively and even have a chance to win, you must pay close attention to what buildings other players have built and, even more importantly, you need to know how and when to take advantage of those buildings.  Maybe if I played this game frequently I would care, but seeing as the likelihood of that happening is low, this game is one I will pass on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Le Havre is a mainstay in my apartment as a go-to for game nights. I usually get beaten by my friends who are more experienced in strategy board games. Even when I know I'm bound to lose, it's a fun game with a scoring system where it's just satisfying to try to beat personal bests.

Sometimes the rounds seem a little predetermined, but there are many ways to utilize your strategy to yield the most effective results.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Le Havre is simply an awesome game - especially with the integrated Le Grande Hameau!!!  I like the game with 3 or 4 players best.  This is another heavy thinker Euro style game with amazing replayability.  The build up of the available town buildings creates a cool build up dynamic and forces players to really think about timing issues and best build up courses of action.  This is also a game that grows on you after five to ten plays as you want to keep coming back for more and more.  I love the game play mechanisms and the tightness of the game - "if only I had one more turn or one more move" - the game keeps you on edge constantly with very little downtime!!! Le Havre has made my list of Top 20 euro style games of all time.

RATING: 10
Like:

-The exponential gain of wealth throughout the course of the game.
-Multiple paths to victory.
-The length of the game fits the weight of the game very well.
-The board and cards are brilliantly designed to make playing the game intuitive.

Don't Like:

-When my unruly stack of cow chits scatter all over the place.  Read: the little cardboard goods are a pain.
-There is not a ton of variance from one game to another.  Once you have established your wealth (mid game?) you can run with a similar strategy every time if you wanted to.

RATING: 6
Engrossing game, with interesting interlocking paths of how-to-use-resources. I'm immensely glad that rules for a short game were included; I feel like it'll be much more manageable time-wise (and fun) once we have a non-trivial number of the short games under our belt. Even the short version can easily run too long if players don't take turns promptly. 

My current rating is for the short game - the longer game may boost it a bit, as I suspect the depth-to-time ratio will be better.

EDIT: I'm now tired of the short game. I still enjoy the longer one, but rarely find it worth breaking out given the length.

RATING: 9
Probably my favorite of Uwe's.  I just like it being card driven and quasi-deterministic.  The whole using other's buildings is neat.  You always have options.  I mean a lot of options.  This game is an exercise of finding a way from A to X when B, W, and D are roadblocking you.  The standard game might run long, but hey there's special buildings aplenty.  Chances are I won't turn a game of this down if offered.

RATING: 10
A seemingly wide open game which can frustrate the first-time player into wondering what to do. The game offers several paths to accumulating money and I like the exponential growth of it towards the end. The fixed number of actions provides a framework for playing the game and also induces a rhythmn to game play. I like it two and three player and avoid higher player counts. It can take long to play with new players, but the experience is great. There's enough player interaction (blocking, mostly) to cause your best laid plans to fall behind. An excellent game for an afternoon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Le Havre is an interesting game. While it is not as immersive as Agricola, it is possibly a better game. The suffocating hardships of Agricola are not to be found here, but rather the players are just trying to choose the best options out of many good ones. The theme does come through somehow - "I'm just a poor boy with 5 francs and a piece of coal in my pocket" - but in the end building a farm in Agricola is much more immersive. That said, Le Havre is a good game that I recommend to people interested in heavy, positive eurogames.

RATING: 7
There's a lot going on Le Havre; possibly too much. I like that there are many different resources that can be used in a variety of ways to achieve your goals.  The game is long, though... far too long for the amount of fun you'll have.  Also, I just don't understand how the mechanic of "feeding" fits in with the game.  Mechanically it works but it just doesn't fit the theme and simply serves as some sort of outside force you have to deal with while trying to build up your cash and goods.

Ultimately it fixes some of my issues with Agricola but introduces new ones.  I'll certainly play the game but I doubt I'll ever recommend playing it.

RATING: 7
I liked this a lot at first and preferred it to Agricola, due to its lack of what I saw as the card based luck factor in the Gric. Over time, however, I found that that I grew tired of it for the same reason: basically, a lack of variety.  Even though each game of Le Havre isn't the same, it *feels* the same to me, and the turns feel repetitive and fiddly.  I thought getting the expansion buildings might help, but they don't come up enough to make a big difference. In the end, it's ok, but I have no desire to play anytime soon...I think Uwe's other games, including Agricola, are simply deeper and more satisfying.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
$40 BGG
Le Havre is a game of construction and development in which players compete to achieve massive gains over an era spanning 60-70 years. You can become an industrial baron, a shipping magnate, a freshly minted aristocrat running Titanic-era luxury liners, or anything in between. You start out with a little cash and a small stock of coal to use as energy, and from there it’s a matter of which resources you grab and what you do with them. The one constant in Le Havre is abundant opportunity. The challenge is making the most of it. 
The first of a family of games and has expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A very adequate follow-up to Agricola.  This game isn't nearly as good as Agricola, but it's about the same depth and has enough different rules and concepts going on that people will like it.  It'd be interesting to see how well (or not well) this game would've done were it *not* the Agricola follow-up...  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Very similar to Agricola regarding its mechanics (same designer), altough, in here, there is not so much stress about feeding one´s population.
The game flows according to its theme and with some nice and logical ideias. In spite of beeing a crucial and important element in the game, the building tiles require some previous knowledge of their features, so that one can really enjoy the game, as reverse to Agricola, where those tiles are less and more easy to perceive. Besides, the mechanics behind the tiles unlock is ingenious but also not so easy to get at first plays.
In Le Havre, a player has usually just two or three options to do on his turn, but they are all almost always good options, the trick beeing to pick the one that is just slight better than the others. This is a nice ideia because it allows all players to develop their "companies" without sudden shortage of goods, like in other games of this kind.
Overall, i think this game drops just a litle behing Agricola, on account of the relative difficulty in perceiving the tiles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Cannot play this enough.  Tried a 5 player game and it took a while....  2 player is fast and furious though and well balanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Un juego cuya mecánica se explica en 10 minutos, y que proporciona a los jugadores una cantidad de caminos hacia la victoria inimaginable. Esencialmente se trata de un juego de gestión de recursos, se juega varias rondas (dependiendo del nº de jugadores), cada ronda son 7 turnos, y cada turno lo juega un sólo jugador, al final de la ronda hay que gastar una cantidad fija de comida/dinero que va siendo mayor a medida que avanza la partida. Los jugadores se verán obligados a "gastar" turnos en conseguir comida, y "utilizar" el resto de turnos en mejorar su posición en la partida consiguiendo dinero y/o edificios que son los que dan la victoria. Aquel jugador que sea capaz de jugar más turnos dedicados a su "economía" o que los utilice con mejor criterio será el que gane la partida. Un juego apto para no jugones, y genial para los jugones ... el pero ... prepara 3 horas para jugarlo ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Huge number of choices each turn, which (like Agricola), escalates each turn.  One of the best resource collection and engine-building games I've played. So many different paths to pursue here for VPs. Truly an economic game with some worker payment (food) thrown in to keep players honest.  

Lots of opportunities for AP, but quite a rewarding game.  Edges out Agricola in both gameplay and setup/maintenance.

Definitely needs some containers in which to place all the resource tokens. Otherwise, the board becomes a mess during game play. 

I'm happy to find that the short version of this game is almost as fun as the full game (just miss out on the Special Buildings), and it's nice to have that as a very playable option in half the time. 

Edit 3/11/16: I'm starting to get a little burned out on this now. I feel like I've explored it enough after 25 plays. Less interested in playing it, although I still find it a fun game. Just lowering my rating a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In a way, this reminds me of Roads & Boats.  You build up an infrastructure, which other players can use, with a variety of resources which can be converted into superior forms.  It can also be played solo. 

Edit:  After a few more plays, I've upped my rating from an 8 to a 9, and I've only played it solo.  I'd really like to play it with others someday.  (Since writing this, I have played multi-player.  After doing so I raised my score to a 10).

There are some really brilliant and innovative design elements going on here.  First, I love how each resource has an improved version, and you just flip the chit to indicate this.  Second, I like how buildings can be bought with money, or built with resources.  The back of the cards contain information that makes set-up a breeze.  I also find it refreshing that money = victory points.  

This game has been occupying my thoughts in a way that no other game has for quite a while.  So far the best solo score I have achieved is 335.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
- Number of games played: at the time of writing I have played 6 2-player games

- Gameplay: 4/4. Le havre is a very intense worker placement game that will burn your brain to ashes. Player interaction comes in the form of blocking the opponent from performing his preferred move and by being first at grabbing the best resource stockpiles and buying and using the best buildings. In case you love Agricola, I think you absolutely need to give Le Havre a try. Surprisingly, Le Havre is not Argricola with merely a different theme pasted onto it; it really has a different feel to it. Personally I like it even more than Agricola, because of two things. First, you get enough time to accomplish what you were planning to. Secondly, every turn you need to choose between several good alternatives.

- Absence of luck: 4/4. There are a few random elements in the game, all at the time of set up: the order of the resource replenishment, the starting player, the order of the buildings and the selection of the available buildings built by the town. However, I can't see how they might determine the winner.

- Duration: 2/4. With 2 players a game can be played in 2.5 to 3.5 hours, which is long, but it certainly doesn't feel long when playing. It is just long enough to allow the players to finish their plans.

- Theme and looks: 4/4. Le Havre is good looking and the harbor theme is well integrated. It lacks the cute meeples like in Agricola, but I don't see how they would have been able to fit everything in the box.

- Set up/clean up time: 3/4. I'd say it takes 10 minutes to set up and 10 to clean up for a single person, so with experienced players all giving a helping hand, it can be done in 2 times 5 minutes.

- Learning curve and documentation: 3/4. Really easy to learn, with not too much tiny rules to remember. Everything is quite straightforward and the rule book is clear and even contains a sample game.

- Like: rewarding gameplay, luck free, perfect 2 player game, nice theme, highly competitive, enough player interaction, suffictient variation

- Dislike: longish
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Le Havre is much more forgiving than Agricola, the game to which it is most frequently, if dubiously, compared. You can borrow if you fall short of food. (In fact, doing so is a viable strategy, at least for a few rounds.) Also, if another player snatches the resource you're interested in, you probably can use a building to get it instead, and, if a building is unavailable, there'll be plenty of other useful resources to choose from.

RATING: 9
[December 2016 -9]
What a great game when it comes to all the choices you have during play. While it can start a little slow and limited, it quickly ramps up and you always want to do everything in one turn. It's  another one of those winners in that the basic gameplay is very simple, but the sheer amount of avenues and strategies you can take seem endless. So far, no games I've played have been alike, largely depending on the style of play from the players. Interaction is light but just enough to keep you interested, along the lines of Puerto Rico or Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[2011-07-21 Rating: n.a. -> 9.5]

Le Havre is just great. The game itself is dead easy to explain: Each round, after adding some resources to the map, you can either take one pile of resources or you can use one of the available building actions. In addition, you can also buy and sell buildings or ships. And when a round is over, you have to feed your workers. Money is as good as actual food for this purpose and it's even better to own a ship as it will give you some food automatically.

Repeat this procedure for a set number of rounds after which every player counts his money and the richest player wins.

While this short description outlines the rules of Le Havre, it doesn't even give you the slightest idea of the fun you can have while playing this gem. It doesn't mention the narrative arc of Le Havre where in the beginning you start with nearly nothing. Your choices what to do are very limited and focus around the resources you'd like to take. Somehow you manage to start your business and suddenly it's more about the building's action and the ships you need so desperately. In the end, you're hopefully not struggeling anymore but trying to earn the most cash possible with each of your actions. Best of all, this all happens in an "open world" setting. As this games offers a lot of possible strategies, there is a lot to experiment with.

But all this fun comes with a prize. First, the game is long. A four player games lasts about three hours. I do enjoy this experience but I know that it can be tough to find people to join you on this ride. 
Another thing is the complexity of the game. In my first games, I didn't have the slighest idea how to play this one. You are facing a plethora of options and it's completely up to you to evaluate them. This can be overwhelming. I took the time to discover Le Havre using the excellent Java version that is available [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/42763/jlehavre-1-26]here[/url]. But I know, not everyone wants to invest that much into a game. Although, this is one of the games that's totally worth the effort. If you like complex economic games, give Le Havre a try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only played a few times but really love it so far.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is THE Game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Un gros jeu pour joueurs, au matériel superbe et au gameplay très simple et fluide pour une profondeur tactique et stratégique maximale !

La multitude des possibilités de marquer des points rend ivre de plaisir mais au final, c'est la frustration de ne pas pouvoir faire tout ce qu'on veut qui pousse chacun à programmer minutieusement chacune de ses actions, tout en s'assurant d'empêcher les adversaires de mettre en oeuvre leurs plans.

Les règles sont d'une simplicité enfantine ce qui permet de le proposer à des joueurs occasionnels. En revanche, la maîtrise des combinaisons de cartes viendra progressivement après plusieurs parties.

Je trouve que le jeu révèle tout son potentiel avec les règles longues et à 3-4 joueurs.A 2 joueurs, c'est bien aussi, mais à 5 ça devient le bazar.

Le Havre est à posséder absolument !

Plaisir enfin retrouvé sur iOS iPhone et iPad, d'autant plus qu'aucun site en ligne ne le propose pour l'instant.

RATING: 10
Downgraded from a 10 because it bothers me a little that  more of the special buildings don't come into play. Which begs the question, if there were no special buildings at all, would I rate it a 10? Probably. But there ARE special buildings.

EDIT: It's great that there are so many special buildings. I'm just not playing this game enough. (Every other night = enough.) Re-upgraded to a 10.

EDIT: LH varies greatly across player counts. My rating of 10 is for 2p. 

Ratings by player count:
1p= 6 (Feels more like practice for the game than a game. I don't really like solo play in general though.)
2p= 10 (You know what your opponent must do; they know what you must do. Massive tension as you plan turns ahead.)
3p= 7 (Nothing gained by the addition of a 3rd player except downtime. The ability to plan ahead is greatly diminished. Offense is no longer a factor: if you directly mess with one player, you and that player will fall behind.)
4p= 5 (Ridiculously chaotic. A shadow of the 2p game.)
5p= 1 (unplayable)


Must try David Jones' 'No Shipping' variant:

"Setup your game as normal with the following changes:

1) Remove the shipping line from the standard buildings and replace it with the football stadium. Shuffle and and deal the three building piles as normal.

2) From the special buildings deck, remove the following:

Baguette Shop (03)
Clothing Industry (05)
Diner (16)
Forest Hut (10)
Furniture Factory (26)
Patisserie (19)
Steakhouse (32)
Tavern (28)

Leather Industry (21)
Brick Manufacturer (34)

3) Create a "fourth" building pile as follows: Put the Leather Ind and Brick Mfgr on the bottom of the pile randomly. Shuffle the other eight special buildings and place them on top. You should "fan" the row as you do the others so that you can see which buildings are due.

Rule changes:

1) At the end of the round, if the city is going to build a normal building, it ALWAYS builds the top card from the fourth building pile. If the city builds a special building, take it from the remaining special deck as you would in a normal game.

2) Just as with standard buildings, the top building of the fourth pile can be purchased at any time on your turn."

EDIT: I've now played the No Shipping variant a couple of times and it works every bit as well as the standard rules. Such a great addition to one of my favorite games!

RATING: 10
Not as heavy and cumbersome as I thought it would be after having spent half an hour getting the rules explained to me and looking at the cluttered board. Actually it's quite an elegant game as it takes the best parts from several of the other heavy Euros. Take something and convert it into something more valuable and then do something with it. Nothing new here. I like the fact that turns go really quick and that you only have one action per round. Not as AP prone as Agricola for example. 

Negative parts include the long playing time. It took us 2.5 hours to finish a short 3-player game. I dread to even think of how long a full game will take.

All in all a game I'll gladly play at least one more time. The jury is still out.

Update: This game gets better with each play. After having played the full game I'll never go back to basics again. 

Update 2: Better and better, now a 10 rating even. To me LH > O&L > Agricola.

Update 3: Finally managed to get a decent score in this game, 230 points in a 3-player game.

RATING: 9
This is the kind of heav game that makes you glad you play games.  Caylus + Agricola.  Working to build power buildings that anyone can use and then taking actions that others can't then take themselves.  Yummy.  However, Agricola has many of the same points, and also adds more replayability with the multitude of cards.  So this game has to lose a point in comparison.

Update 8-9: This deserves this point back.  Agricola's variability is all private.  You have the coolness of the cards, but nobody knows.  In Harv, the random order is pretty cool, and the special buildings are pretty cool (when not broken), but their being in the open makes the interaction make up for the lack of sheer quantity in Gric.  Gric is still more fun because you also have a little player mat farm, but this is a 9.

RATING: 7
Avoid the "simple/quick rules" unless you just want to run through the mechanics.  They don't give the game enough depth to really warrant using.

I do like the full game.  Early on, the game goes by quickly as you acquire resources.  But by mid-game, once many buidlings have been built...the game presents a lot of decisions.  This game rewards a precise, narrow focus unlike Agricola where you want to do a little bit of everything. Unlike many worker placement games, this one can be a bit overwhelming as there are so many cards/buildings to view, analyze, and choose between.  As I've become more familar with the buildings this has become easier, but be prepared for a big learning curve. I'm not sure about the variability of this game.  The goal seems to be to setup for shipping high value goods or purchasing luxury liners.  Need food?  No worries..take loans to do cover that.  It will conserve your actions.  The special cards are a must, but do they really change the game?  The ones that have come out in our game rarely have much of an impact.  Football stadium being a notable exception.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Order through Lookout Games. Got confirmation e-mail on 11/03/2008. Sent on 11/06/08. Received on 12/13/08.

Le Havre is an interesting variant on the worker placement genre that I quite enjoy. The decisions are interesting and challenging, and I really like how it "feels" like a port is being built out as the game progresses. It is not quite the thematic tie-in that Agricola has, but it is still a nice experience. The single action per turn and the ability to buy buildings without spending actions adds some nice twists to the strategic potential of the game, and I still feel like I am learning things about the game 4-5 plays in. The Special cards are interesting. A lot of them seem to open entirely new strategic dimensions, but it seems like a shame that they aren’t just "there" to be played like the other buildings. I understand that the primary reason for this is based on the timing of particularly buildings emerging. Just throwing Special cards into the three Building Proposals piles would prevent crucial buildings from ever emerging, but it would be nice if there was more of an ability to build strategies around which special abilities are available as opposed to just taking advantage of the ones that become available. I suppose that adds a nice, little tactical element though. 

Ora et Labora is strictly superior to Le Havre, and has replaced it in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players are running a French harbour, trying to amass wealth.  Players on their turn seed the play area with a few goods, then take a "main" action - either pick up goods or place their worker piece to action a space.  Then players are allowed to build/purchase buildings.  Repeat that for a couple of hours, feeding your (who?) at intervals along the way.  Most cash and purchases wins.  Simple to play, but disguised by a rulebook that makes you chase important concepts throughout, rather than presenting it logically.  Game play rapidly bogs down as more buildings become available (allow plenty of table space), but this should free up with experience.  Lots of Caylus in this, as you try to set up a victory point conveyor belt.  Fun solo variant, but watch the setup bug for the buildings.  Lovely art, tons of counters.  Solid effort.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent worker placement and resource management game.  At the most basic level, a player can either collect resources or do something with them each turn.  Much of the challenge is efficiently alternating and sequencing these two options.  The entire game is a multi-step process of gathering resources, upgrading them, and/or using them.  Each player must do this over and over again, many times during the course of the game.  At the same time, players must be prepared for the upkeep phase each round.

Despite the fact that there isn't a whole lot of variation to this general pattern from one game to the next, replayability doesn't seem to suffer.  The game incorporates several features to keep things somewhat interesting: the order in which resources accumulate, the order in which the standard building cards are dealt and who ends up with them, the special building cards that appear, and of course the actions of the players.  All of these elements lend enough variation to keep the game challenging and hold the players' attention.

The game has a very definite and deliberate progression, and staying on top of it is the key to winning.  It takes a few plays to understand how this works.  I am happy with the short game, but I have played the long game as well.

RATING: 3
There are some neat things going on here, but this isn't very much fun or clever. It was a moreso a chore of scrambling to feed a growing population. Most of your precious actions go to unglamorous stuff like butchering cattle. The interactions here are also minimal; if someone is parked on the action you need to do then you must do something else (a la Caylus). Otherwise it's pretty much cube farming with 20+ goods.

Also the greater issue is that decisions feel  obvious and inconsequential. This is unlike Puerto Rico, where a very small menu of choices plays faster and also has greater impact.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the most exquisitely engineered game I have encountered.  From the precisely measured game sequence for each player count down to the helpful tips on the backs of the cards, this game was clearly underwent exhaustive development and tuning.

I think I like Le Havre a little more than Agricola, largely because the game gives me more of a feeling of opportunity than desperation.  However, this game is surely at its heart a grinding exercise in optimization, and the fundamental soullessness at its core will likely keep me from ever loving it.  However, I can still enjoy it quite a bit. 

My favorite feature is the way that the special buildings give each game its own set of scoring potentials, so that you need to be agile in your strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Contains Le Grande Hameau mini expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Big opportunity cost game.  I love it!  My favorite Rosenberg, some important worker placement but mostly THE GOODS.

"Do I smoke my fish now? Seems safe.  Almost next round, and then I'll have 3 actions to do what I actually want." 
"Pleaaaase don't move your worker onto that wharf.  Unless you mean to upgrade it.  Wait, you have no brick. I am boned."
"Good lord that's a lot of wood.  I really want that wood.  I would have to take 2 more loans at the end of the round, but someday I will thank myself for taking 12 wood right now."

If you enjoy saying these type of things to yourself for 3 or so hours, buy this game immediately.  This is definitely a Rosenberg game but it is a welcome departure from Agricola / Caverna while still keeping many of the interesting mechanics and feeling very polished.

The good:
- THE GOODS!  Interesting upgrade chains for goods, a variety of goods, makes all actions feel useful in some way.
- Various paths to victory, the road less traveled can many times be rewarding.
- Scales interestingly from 1 - 5 players, almost feels like a different game from 2-3 just with the number of turns present.

The bad:
- With enough plays I could see a victory formula emerging that players rush towards, limiting strategy exploration.
-  "Spreadsheet-ness" may turn some off, lots of calculations and possible AP.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
After carverna came out, this dropped to 4th favorite in the Uwe rankings.  It does a lot right, but still manages to irritate me.  

This is one of those games with tons of available actions, and no time to do it all.  How long will you let the offers build up before grabbing them?  Do you want to try and build a building now, or wait till you can get more advanced things?  There are so many choices, you have serious potential for AP.  There's also the Uwe standard benchmarks, where you have to pony up resources at specified times.  

I like the way it has basic buildings that are always present, and special buildings that are available game to game.  I just think that the balance is off, with tons of basic ones coming out in pre-scripted orders and only a few specials.  This means that there might be some cool interactions, but the game is going to be dominated by the same relatively boring set of combinations.  You're always going to have a shipyard, but probably not a brick factory or sandwich shop.  

Other than that, there isn't much attraction to the game.  It becomes an exercise in churning resources around, converting them from type to type, and cashing them in for points.  It's not terrible, but Agricola has the cards over it, and Ora has the landscape building and placement challenge.  It may see some more play, but I won't be advocating it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

FL T

RATING: 9.5

I think this is a bit heavier and takes a bit longer to get used to, but it's amazing once you play it a few times.  I probably played it a dozen times in the first week on the iPad and still want to play more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't think it'll replace Agricola, its a bit more calculation heavy since everything is out in the open and there are more types of transactions that can be performed to build your economy. Certainly more wide open - you don't feel as constrained . I found it felt like some mix of Agricola and Brass, with some Caylus thrown in. That said, I did like it, though I'm sure some people will find it too complicated and dry.
 
Despite the confusing rule book, its not that complicated in practice:
On your turn you put out 2 types of resources (of which there is a around 8-10 basic resources, and that number of upgraded resources).
Then you have a chance to pickup resources, or buy/build a building (similar to caylus - you also get to charge a fixed rent to use it), or place your single worker on a building to take advantage of its ability.

The trick is combining your actions to meet your goals. That makes your turns a little static, as you've essentially planned them out way in advance. For example - I wanted to build a steel ship. That meant the next 5 turns had to be spent:
-getting iron
-getting coal
-converting coal to coke
-converting iron to steel using the coke
-spending the steel and coke to buy a steel ship
 
There are always multiple ways to do things - so unless two other players were competing at the same time in the same order... it seemed tough to really get put off track - at least in the 4 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Finally got my hands on this thanks to my friend Adam so I could see what all the fuss was about.  While a tremendously fascinating game, I think it suffers the same problem that games like New York 1901 have in that your success has a bit of dependency on where you sit at the table.  However, unlike that game, there is such a wide decision tree once the game opens up that the issue is mostly negligible towards its conclusion, but holy crap will you ever feel it in the first few turns.

That aside, this is a game that I would play again - multiple times, even - but not one that I would introduce into my library.  The underlying gameplay is so mathematical that I would only have a very select few people that I would invite to the table to play it with.  That in no way is an admonishment against Le Havre - I just know my friends and you can't give them this kind of opportunity to sit there and work it out or you might as well just watch a movie while they take their turn.  As the game goes on, your options widen even further, so you can imagine the impact.

Like those friends, I like Le Havre.  I like it a lot, even.  I just wouldn't want it to move in with me.

RATING: 8
It's all about them buildings. Find an engine and go with it, but like any Rosenberg game, make sure you can feed your people at the end of each round. There's a lot of good tension with how to spend your limited actions each turn/round.

I enjoy the game quite a bit (though less than Agricola), however it can get same-y after awhile so I try to space my plays of it out.

Also, I've only ever played with two and I have no desire to ever try it with more.

RATING: 6
UPDATE: After some time, the flaws in Le Havre have started to get to me and I feel like this is one of my least favorite Rosenbergs.

We really enjoyed this one. The theme doesn't draw you in as strongly as in Agricola, but I really like the flow of the game and the choices available to you -- it feels like there are more options available to you in Le Havre than in Agricola without the clunkiness of Ag's occupation and minor improvement cards.

On the other hand, Le Havre doesn't draw you in as much as Agricola because of the theme. The whole farming theme has more of a draw that buying and smoking fish, but maybe with more plays, Le Havre will generate more interest.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is very interesting.  The designer states it's a combination of Caylus (making buildings and then using them for actions) & Agricola (accumulating resources, harvest and feeding).  Uwe has also tried to make it similar to Agricola in that it plays 1 - 5 players and there is a lot of variation game to game through the order of the building cards and the 6 special buildings in the game.  Le Havre is unfortunately like Agricola in that it also has a lot of bits that are constantly being moved around but also trying to see what buildings each player has is another chore.  The game also doesn't scale well with the number of players the game supports.  I find the two player game is too harsh to the players with food requirements and the five players would take far too long to get through.  Le Havre is in the minority of games that plays best with three which is good. I think Le Havre is a decent game, but Ora et Labora is pretty much Le Havre 2.0, rendering the original obsolete.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

3-player is a lot of fun.  Not sure about anything else.  Similar concerns as Agricola.

RATING: 5
iOS, against AI

The more I play this, the less I understand the attraction. Like, where is the fun, man? This is a point salad with a theme stapled on, and an exceptionally expensive one, given URs penchant for cramming as much stuff into a box as possible (unless you bought the digital version, which is also expensive, just ). 

The quality of the product is above reproach, but the underlying logic of the game fails to satisfy. Perhaps the fun is in other people playing along?

RATING: 8
Great game.  Almost perfect information.  With 99% of the information known, it makes it easy to feel like you can make plans and control your own game.  There seems to be a variaty of decent options in order to gain points.

Very much like Agricola, but your actions don't feel anywhere near as bad.  You always get to do something productive, instead of bad or worse in Agricola, it's typically good or better choices.  Really no diffeance, but it makes the game feel like your constantly doing well, instead of in Agricola where you always feel like your sucking wind.

RATING: 8
2-3 players seems ideal for this game, although it is fun with more.  The rules are simple, but strategy is complex; expect your first game to be a learning game, and to want to go back and make different decisions the second game.  It's long, but I've never had a problem with long games.  This game has a quality I like in a game, which is to examine the structure of the game, and derive a strategy based on it, and then attempt to execute/adjust along the way.

RATING: 8
This game takes a lot of what I don't like about Agricola and really minimizes it. Namely, what I don't like about Agricola is that about 75% of your decisions are pretty forced. You need food. You need more family members. It takes a lot of work to get to those places. Le Havre has requirements you get to, but the way you get there feels much more open, especially because of the introduction of currency. My only qualm is the length. It's a long one. 

Expansions Owned: Le Grand Hameau

RATING: 7
While there is an element of worker placement here, the main thrust is by far in identifying efficient conversion paths (regardless of who owns the points along the path) and hitting them more than your opponents. What made the game so opaque for me is that the value of things – and therefore the direction to go – is not certain till midway through the game. 

You spend the first part of the game just collecting things, buying a building here or there, but nothing too grand going on, and this can give a sense of floundering. But then as the game develops you identify a path for how to make some money and/or satisfy your food needs. I find this especially true with the special buildings as they offer some pretty specialized paths.

Resource conversion games aren't in my wheelhouse but if I were to recommend only one, it would be Le Havre.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Unlike Loyang, Le Havre also plays very well with 2 or 3 players.

RATING: 6
I understand why this is considered a good game. Mechanically, you can see there's a solid design process behind it. Also, feeding your workers is a pain; the most efficient solution to this problem seems to be building ships... amd I hate games where you can do a lot of things, but one of those things is essentially mandatory. Also, I think that the theme is not really there at some points: if I am a town developer or whatever, why the hell am I harvesting grain and herding cows?!

RATING: 10
After my first play, I rated this at 8.75.  After subsequent plays, I've placed this at a 10.  The depth of strategy is better than any "euro" I can think of.  You NEED to be thinking and playing several moves past your current turn to be able to have a hope of a win.  

Single player is more of a practice mode.  Two and three seem to be best.  Four and five are not at all recommended.

However, there is much less competition for buildings and spaces than Agricola. I can't see it coming out very often, but with more advanced players it is quite a joy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm struggling to rate this one, as I cannot decide if it is a work of genius or broken.  The fundamentals of the game are fantastic: move your boat, add items to the offer and then take 1 action.  It is so simple and easy to teach but contains phenomenal depth.  This is in part due to the random selection of special buildings that will become available over the course of the game, along with the changing order of the standard buildings.  The components are excellent and although the rule book has a few quirks it is well written and illustrated for the most part.

However, there are 2 fairly large elephants in the room: the issue of ignoring one of the key mechanics in the game, hunger, by abusing the loan system, and the power of the shipping coke strategy.  With these 2 aspects in place seasoned players will strip the game down to the same experience every time it is played.  Ignore food, take loans and then build towards shipping coke.  This can also mean that new players who are not aware of this strategy will be destroyed, meaning they may be reluctant to play again.  For the first few games I got a rule wrong whereby everyone was paying 1 interest of each loan they had, which seem natural and somewhat preferable to what is in place by default.

It seems a shame that such a multifaceted game can be reduced to a few key decisions due to the perception of there being only one correct way to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I certainly preferred Le Havre to Agricola, I felt much less frustrated by being blocked, and felt there were many more choices open to me. My first play, and the mechanisms are simple enough, so it all hangs on knowing the buildings/ships and how to exploit them efficiently. Which is always a mark down in my book, since the experienced player automatically has the advantage. If you like this sort of game, you will like Le Havre. Not really my cup of tea, but I'd certainly prefer player this to other such games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Swap this for that, then build, buy, and ship! Excellent design with good variability. [b]I own this and plan to keep it for years.[/b]

My rating history: 8|6.|8......|10|8....

Played 19 times with 1-3 players.
1p: 4
2p: 6
3p: 6



2011: My first two plays left me a little dizzy and unsure of myself.

Plays #3-15: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
May 2014: Having re-discovered the joy of playing Agricola, I've been looking into Rosenberg's other games, and been wondering if I'd like Ora & Labora. My main concern is the main mechanic: resource conversion. So I played Le Havre again to see if my opinion of the mechanic has improved. Well...it hasn't. Yet. But I have a feeling it will. I think the key with complex conversion games is getting a handle on all the parts. Until you do, you're just dizzy and lost. Just spitballing here, but I see a ceiling of 8 for this, and maybe 9 for Ora et Labora.

Play #16: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Mid-May 2014: Up to an 8 as I see what the special buildings really add, and start to get a handle on the game. Taught this to three 6th grade students, and they LOVED it. (Short game.) I was shocked as I assumed this was too brainy/mathy. I'm still of the opinion this will stay at an 8 for me, and still feel Ora & Labora is the one I want.

Plays 17-19: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
NOV 2014: Still a lot of fun, and I'm discovering more styles to play the game with. Last one was wood denial and wooden ships, then ignoring food while setting up an Industrial engine with two Special Buildings. Really fun. Kevin is really enjoying this one.

Best solo scores:
282 using Fish Restaurant for $, then late game Smelter for steel rush
260 using Football Stadium and Fur Industry

As a curious sidenote, Le Havre fell out of the top 10 rankings at approximately 10:30am PST on June 1, 2014.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros
-Very straight forward euro game, simple actions but enough choices and strategy required
-Theme is appropriate (even if somewhat dry - but that's taste dependent)
-Players can choose between full or shorter game length
-Special buildings and design of how standard buildings appear add lots of replayability
-Can be played solo or up to 5 players

Cons
-Rulebook was poorly organized. Every paragraph referenced another page or rule that will later be described. Main offender was that it didn't differentiate between buying and building until the last page.
-Loans are counter intuitively desirable
-Adding resources to offering each turn can be tiresome
-Idea of needing boats to ship is hard to teach newer players (my opinion) - has been argued that there aren't as many viable end game strategies

Other
-I wonder if they could've added alternate turn tiles (the circular ones that dictate what resources to add to the offering each turn).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Clean concept, but 16 resources, money, food, energy, buildings and 20 serialised turns make this extremely long and AP-prone (plus you need to keep feeding your people). Play with 3p, no more.

There seems to be a lot of depth with timing the purchase and sale of buildings and exploiting loans.

I prefer Homesteaders for my resource management in a shorter playtime, but the cash manipulation in Le Havre seems significantly deeper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's not that Le Havre's decision tree is so deep - it's so damn WIDE.  In that respect first games take forever, but once you get over that hump things really start to pick up and the game just shines.  There are so many avenues to pursue.

I love that in this game you get to create an engine and really crank on it for a while vs. the usual where the game ends just as you're getting it built. It's surprising how much just the little variations in building order can totally change the game and the special buildings are just enough to spice things up.

RATING: 9
Build your economy in tiny little increments with lots of resources to work with and many little buildings and systems you can leverage / manipulate while trying to keep up with having to feed your people.  

It has a wonderfully balanced system with so very many things you can/want/need to do, but never enough actions. Managing those actions and developing a linear path to victory is the key to this game. 

Love, love, love the scope of the economy. Love the balance and design. But wish I was better at micromanagement and that it wasn't quite so long!

Rules Complexity: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

Luck Factor :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::star:

"Take That" Conflict: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Theme Integration: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

RATING: 7
[b]Design:- [/b]:star::star::star::star::nostar:  [i]Economic engine with progressive development.[/i]
[b]Execution:- [/b]:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:  [i]Card-based design feels more like a CCG.[/i] 
[b]Experience:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Challenging but quite processional.[/i]
[b]Presentation:- [/b]:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:  [i]Graphically pleasing; let down by redundant components.  Quite possibly could have been a card game.[/i]

Disappointing after the hype.  Really should have been just a card game (perhaps with a slack handful of resource counters thrown in).  The game is challenging, but often I feel more like I am playing against the game machine rather than other players.  I can see some interest as a solitaire; however there are other games that do this better when there are multiple players.  I need to play more to see if anything improves; so far I'm finding it better with four than with three but considerably longer.

RATING: 10
Awesome game which improves on Agricola on every level. Multitude of upgradeable resources, varied buildings, and (a specialty of Uwe Rosenberg) the constant shortage of time in accomplishing your strategy.
Lively game board and a naval theme which fits the mechanics.
Great with 2 players; make sure you've got 3 hours to spare.
If you enjoy economic worker placement games with LOTS OF RESOURCES AND BUILDINGS, it simply doesn't get better than this.

RATING: 8

So there's probably less replay value here. Still, Le Havre remain a very good game thanks to the well-tuned mechanics that clearly allow multiple roads to victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First I have to say that I prefer this than its older brother Agricola. Why? Probably because of the thematic, probably because in LH, as the game progress,  players must improve the resources in order to build more complex buildings... The only problem that I found in LH is that if it is played with 5 players, the game could be too much long and heavy to carry on till the end. In fact, I think that the better number of players for this game is 3 (but it also works very good with 2 players).

As good as Puerto Rico but more complex and harrowing (in the geekier sense of the word), better and prettier than almost all games of the "managment resources" family. One of my favorite games ever!

Its components are beautifully designed, its mechanics are complex but simple at a time, and the sensation of fatigue and anguish near the end of each round makes this game an authentic challenge and a real future planning exercise.

What else can I say: an awesome piece of gaming-art, and an undoubted MUST HAVE for all strategic board game lovers!!! Get it or repent of your bad decision!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Easily the best economic game I've ever played, beats out Puerto Rico in my opinion.  There are many resources, buildings and variable game situations, but the game is so easy to pick up and understand.  Very well designed and very fun building up the town over the course of the game and reaping the rewards.  Don't play with more than 3 players though, as your action count will tank and wait time will explode.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At times, Le Havre feels more like a puzzle than a game as players try to optimise their resources in order to have made the most money at the end of the game.

Of course, it's an interactive puzzle. During the game players build or buy shops, factories and the like which provide certain actions. You can also use other players' buildings but usually have to pay a fee when you do. Additionally, only one player can occupy a building at any given time so it's quite possible to block other players, at least for a while.

Making the best out of your resources is quite a challenge. In addition to just maximising your profit you also need to feed your work force, and since there are only 7 actions per turn you can never do everything you would like to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
