RATING: N/A
{"sleeves":[{"59x92":110}]}
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game. After owning Agricola, this is the second game I have in my possession of Uwe Rosenberg. When you play Agricola and Le Havre it is obvious that they were designed by the same person. Mainly these two games use the same kind of gameplay. However each game has it's own specifics and both games can therefore be played without getting bored.

Like Agricola the options within Le Havre are numerous. You can get commodities, use these well, choose from different sorts and types of actions and plan your strategy real carefully.

Interesting is the option to use buildings which are build by you opponents or building which were build 'by the game' (sometimes against compensation). This feature isn't present in Agricola.

The game can easily be played with two, three or four persons, however we almost always play with two players (because we think it takes to long to play with more).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Received in mail 4/29/09 from Boards & Bits, along with my second copy of Small World. Because of Small World, it might be a while before I get this one to the table.
First play - 5/18/09. 4 of us learning it. Game started at 7:30, ended at 9:30. We all were scrambling at the end to feed our people. Really liked it. Anxious to play it again. 

Temporary Rating - 9. I seldom rate a game after only 2 plays, but this one is exceptional. It might make it to one of my rare "10's" with more plays. I don't see it dropping any time soon.

Word of advice - this is a game of efficiency. In a 3-player game you get exactly 28 turns + 1 final action. In a 4 or 5 player game you get only 21 turns plus an extra action. Thus, you need to make the best use of your few turns. However, you can always buy & sell as often as you want w/o it counting as an action. Thus, if you can get extra Francs you can get more accomplished on a turn.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is one smart economic game.  There is this initial freedom to try different paths to victory.  I feel like the special powers of each building usually matches perfectly to their real-world counterparts.  As well, paying to operate building effects feels very natural in an economic sense, and thus Le Havre thematically works well, as far as Euros can.  One can get bogged down by the decision making that has to go on, and a 4-player game goes on for a rather long time.  If there is one thing today that keeps me from loving this game as much as I did when it came out, it's the sheer amount of open information. Players can easily get lost in the mini-maxing. And well-seasoned players pretty much spend the whole game employing standard combinations, and their game becomes more about good timing than freedom and creative play.  Thus, the game can become too calculating and even boring with those who just "go through the motions" (where again, all the tension lies with timing).  Le Havre is  a game that could lose its fresh appeal if played too often, but it's an excellent Euro to go back to occasionally.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a totally awesome game. I've had this thing for probably 7 years and finally played it on 11NOV2017. Wow! Just totally fun. 

What I don't like about the game. 
- It doesn't have a solo with win conditions; only a beat your own score
- I've read where you can game the game using using Le Havre: Le Grand Hameau expansion deck, but assuming you don't use that deck for solo play, then it's probably a little more fair. Knocked it down a couple notches due to solo play
- The game makes me feel restrained from resources, which gives me the squirms, and I'm not sure I like that. 

What I like about the game:
- The rules are top notch
- The icons and information on cards and the board really helped to make the game easy to get into.
- The components are top notch, great boards, and cards shuffle nicely
- The game plays really smooth, and while the other person is thinking about their turn, you can be doing yours
- I love the building aspect of it and the way you can combine purchased buildings to make a bit of an engine

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
On my first play of Le Havre I was won over by what seemed an interesting evolution of the worker placement game and at the depth the game appeared to offer. 

 In reality, I feel this game is a meticulous exercise in efficiency and demands too much time for what the game really offers.  There are a ton of micro decisions one must make over and over again, which aren't always interesting or seemingly helpful,and not to mention repetitive.

  Agricola could be knocked for the same but it is shorter in gameplay,the theme is much richer and each decision truly feels it has an impact. 

 Le Havre also seems to have a turn order timing issue, which can really make the drafting mechanism much more profitable to some than others - much more so than in Agricola.  

I also felt that it took at least three or four moves to do a "real" action [something games like Bombay get slammed for(which only lasts 30min)], and with the limited turns in the game, plus the time investment it just compounds all the other things I find faulty. 

 Will I play again? Yes, but I don't feel compelled to. Plus I don't really see the depth in the play.  Le Havre is part of the catalyst (Brass is another) for my turning back the clock to much less convoluted designs and wanting to play games that have real depth and less moving pieces.  I miss the old Euro designs.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Superb worker placement/resource processing game.  I don't play it much anymore due to time constraints but I still find myself wanting to get it to the table. I grew up near barge canals in France so the theme carries a personal nostalgia.  After learning about some of Uwe's background, I'm beginning to feel a kinship for many of his thematic settings.  We're on the same wavelength in that department.

RATING: 10
Le Havre is probably the heaviest game I have at this time and although I have a physical copy, I've only played the iOS version so far. Incredibly tight game where every single decision is meaningful and important, but where the 'good' moves and 'great' moves aren't always instantly obvious. I would love to play this multiple times with a consistent group so that we could all learn and improve together, as having experience in the game seems like it would give an incredible leg up while teaching. Aside from the time it takes to play, this is one of my favourite games at this time.

RATING: 6
This game makes me wonder whether online tools like BSW are changing how designers create games.  This game seems like it would be much better played on a computer interface than with an actual board.  There is a lot of housekeeping piece movement, and there is no great way to keep track of all the visual information on various cards that land in front of each player.  Perhaps when surface computing technology becomes ubiquitous I will play this more.

Rules Reminder: Loans can only be taken out when you cannot meet interest payment or feeding demands, i.e., when interest or the end of a round is triggered.

Rule Update: For an X player game, if you have X loans or more, you must pay 2 francs in interest each round.

If it weren't for his other games I would rate this much higher, but I can get the same fix elsewhere in a more palatable fashion.
I flip between OeL and this as my favorite Uwe game almost on a daly basis.

RATING: 9
[b]Le Havre[/b] [i]Uwe Rosemberg 2008[/i] 
Along with Caylus this is in my humble opinion the best euro game design in the market, with almost no flaws and a lot of ellegance. Le Havre has many different tactical options and variations, and many paths to the victory, more that other games in its genre like Agricola or Puerto Rico. Very well tested, easy to teach and hard to master: this game is just excellent. I recommend it strongly for two to four players. For five players the downtime and lenght is a bit too much for my taste. Superb game and along with expanded Agricola the best Rosemberg´s design up to date. By the way, both games are different enough to share room in your shelves.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game.  My only problem is the length and finding people to play it (this feels like a theme for me).  I think it's a very hard game to score well in during your first couple of plays.

The nice thing about this game, vs. Agricola, is that you don't feel like you're just getting beat up if you're not winning.  The food pressure is much less, and you can always just take loans.

I wish there were multiple strategies in this game besides "ship iron" and constantly work those avenues.  I sort of envision the game as being a little better if someone could realistically deviate from that.  Much more though, I think the game is about who can do that strategy the best and most efficiently.

Either way though, it's an awesome game, and I would recommend this game even at the full MSRP.  Le Grand Hameau adds some nice flavor, and at some level, I wish it added more.  If I can get enough people to play it to the point of understanding the game, I'd like to toy around with removing some more standard buildings and replacing with some more special buildings.

I will say - 5 players, as the box suggests, is not really an option.  2 to 3 is what that game was made for.  4 would get pretty ugly too I think.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Caylus done right.  More options, more variety, more planning ahead, more permanence to your moves, more of a progression from the beginning to the middle to the end game.

Le Havre's biggest achievement is in perfecting the "microturn" concept to an extent that hardly seems possible for a game of this depth and complexity. Nearly everything that happens in the game is sewn simply and seamlessly into each individual bite-sized player turn: resource growth, changes to available actions, choice of action, effects of action. The only extra regulation happens in the painless harvest phase after every seven player turns. Pay a few food, maybe grab a cow or a wheat, flip a card, and you're immediately back into the player actions.

I would play Le Havre more often if it were a bit shorter, and if it allowed for a wider array of long-term strategies. The late stages of the game are especially predictable, and can feel somewhat tedious.

I've tried the solo game a few times recently, with scores of 315, 398, and 418.  The last game was with a bad setup - Colliery on the very bottom of one of the building stacks, and no special buildings that were usable.  I now feel like I've mastered the solo game, but fortunately the strategies are very different and more dynamic in the real multiplayer game.  [Note that the Marketplace has been changed, in the solo game only, to only allow 4 goods maximum.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The people I play Le Havre with feel exhausted when it is over. It is hard, without 10-15 plays under your belt, to analyze the myriad options and decide what the best move is. This would get better with many plays, but as the game plays best with 2-3 it is hard for me to teach enough people to get anyone to play that many times.

The food upkeep seems scaled back when compared to Agricola, but it can be a beast here as well and makes a non-boat strategy daunting (especially at first).

I love the special buildings but wish they had more impact on the game. Definitely not as fun as the variety offered by Agricola's Occupation and Minor Improvement decks. I think I like Le Havre more, but the constantly changing strategy offered by the variety of Agricola's cards keeps the ratings for the closer than they would be otherwise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This was much better than I expected. Sure there are many things going on in this game, but still it doesn’t feel convoluted. Instead it feels open in that you have so many options each turn that it can be hard at times to choose. That doesn’t mean that I feel that all options are the same, but instead lead you to different tracks of your strategy. This is not bland like most of the worker placement game; this economic game is a rich gaming experience. If you don’t like fiddly games with lots of conversion of goods this might not fit your taste, but for me it’s sublime.

I have played the game with any numbers of players and liked it best as a three player game, but it works well with two and four too. The solo game is mostly for learning the rules as the game’s dynamic changes as there is no tension in the game. Five player games are a little long so I suggest the shortened version for that, but generally it works better than I imagined.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The third game took 5 hours, but I was playing with a Dr who needed to read everything.  I still had a great time even though it took so long.  In the game I played; Brick, Wharf and most other means to progress were near the bottom.  It became a game of scarcity until things finely broke open.   I think the randomness of the building placement makes the game different every time. It seemed like a completely different game from the first two.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Le Havre is fantastic. It's simply an awesome game. A classic design that is simple to learn with few rules but incredible depth. However, Le Havre is a bit unique. First, I have little desire to own it. That's because as great as the game is, it feels a bit more like a resource conversion simulation (i.e. math problem), then it does a game. The pros are that every game plays out differently as you never know when you are going to be facing the agonizing chocie of taking resources, or using a building action. It's not like you can say going into the game, "I'm going for a wood to charcoal strategy tonight", like you can in some games. Every decision is critical and you have to be on point all game long. But that also gives the game a bit of a clinical and antiseptic feel. Plus, it's fatiguing to play. There is a bit of "fun" factor missing for me. As a result, it's a game I need to be in the mood for and a game that I can see hitting the table occasionally, instead of being a go-to staple. I think the game is wonderful...in small doses. I want to rate this higher based on pure design excellence. I just can't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A little disappointed. Long for what if offers, with some real usability problems in the way cards are laid out -- I found myself craning and squinting a lot to see the build cost of cards on the other side of the board. Looks a bit of a mess as you play, too, with those resource piles in the center of the board. The endgame reminded me just a little of Civilization (in a bad way) as everyone tries to maximize that very last build. For the effort I think I'd rather play Agricola twice, but if I'd never seen Agricola I'd probably think more of Le Harve. In the end it may not be fair for marking this game down because it isn't as good as Agricola, as the same can be said of nearly every other game, as well. Will play again but won't agitate for it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is a very good worker placement game where you try to have the most money at the end of the game.
At your turn, you can take goods at one of the dock or use one of the available buiding to improve goods, sell goods, build your own building or ship.
At the end of the week, you need to feed your workers.
A game last several weeks.  At the end of the game, you add the value of your buildings and ships to your cash, the player who has the most money wins.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
 If it works great with 2-players, and varies enough from game to game, it could become my favorite game.
Intense, engaging and quite fun and satisfying. There are so many paths you can choose from game to game, and there are tough choices to make turn to turn. 
Every game is like a fluid puzzle, where you're trying to get your town up and running, buying buildings, feeding people, shipping goods, building ships. There's never enough turns to get everything you want done, so you have to choose where you're going to suffer and where you're going to thrive. The difficulty is working all these plans around the plans of your opponents. Dealing with all this is fun because your opponents have to deal with all your moves too. All buildings are open, and special abilities are there for all to see. Because the building order changes from game to game it's a different experience each time. It's a puzzle I'd like to get to the table more often. There's a lot of replay value here for me.

RATING: 7
Played in the "fast" mode. 

After the harrowing experience of playing this iron maiden of a game, I felt utterly exhausted. 

In the end you have too many things to do and not enough actions for the half of what you ought to do just to survive. In theory this would make for an enticing experience where you have to make always the BEST move every time you play.

The fact is, and I discovered this by playing the game, that there is a fine line between games that give you difficult choices, and this one where you're barely able to keep afloat. The former is fun, the latter is stressful and it is a long frustrating experience you are going for. 

I don't know you, but I prefer to reserve stress and fatigue to a job, not to a game. 

On the other hand you cannot admire enough this implacable vice that crushes you slowly and inexorably.

RATING: 10
Awesome game! My girl loves this kind of games and after 10 minutes of playing she exclaimed, "Wow, there are a LOT of choices here!"  :)  Well, there you go. The game is simple, move your boat, fill some resources, take an action. That's it. But... yeah, BIG "but". 

There's so much you can or could do, but you need to plan it right otherwise, you won't be able to do things that you should've done when you could've. And if you don't make the right choice you have to think hard to figure out what to do when you woudn't have done it in a first place. Great game. We played the short version and even though it took us over an hour, it seemed to go fast. Almost too fast, as the 7 actions go quickly. 

I think this has become one of my favorite games thus far, along other games of course.  :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I can see why other people like this one, but it is just not for me. It has many similarities to Agricola, which can be both good and bad.

Generally, it is a resource optimization game. Every turn you are increasing your capacity in something just a little bit more, so that you can buy just a little bit more, so that you can produce just a little bit more, and so on. Rinse and repeat. 

That would be fine if it finished in about an hour and a half, but doing this for three hours just killed it for me. It didn't help that I made a poor decision on my first turn that hindered me the rest of the game, but I don't think that is all that soured me on it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

We've mainly played the long version, we will likely try the short version more often.
I have added a variant, using the Construction Building, to get more Special Buildings into the game - I think it works well.

What I like most though, is that on your turn there are lots of choices.  The beauty is that all of your choices are pretty good as opposed to many games where you have to choose between the lesser of 3 or 4 evils.

RATING: 9.5
Only beaten by Agricola and a few other games. Really good, worth buying.
The design seems simple, but the amount of thought you have to put into your decisions after a few turns is incredible! The fact that those decisions early in the game will determine what course and how successful you will be later in the game is great! So if you made a mistake early in the game, it won't be the fault of the dice nor some random card, but only your own.

Really, really buy this one. You cannot go by this one, you need to at least play it a dozen times in your life.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Heavy-weight economic game with strong emphasis on optimizing supply and production chains.  This one really requires a player to have a long term strategy.  Which resources do I need?  When do I need them?  Which steps are required to get there?  

Furthermore this game is unforgivable: make the right mistake at the wrong time and your entire development will be severly screwed.  Interaction is low, optimization and analysis-paralysis potential is high.  Compared to it's brother Agricola, Le Havre is definitely more complex, has less luck and is far more strategic.  But it is also far more complicated in terms of inter-game-dependencies and it feels rather technical.  

All in all this not really for me.  I like complex games but this is too stressful and lacks the nice thematic touch of Agricola.  And I really cannot imagine playing it with slow players.  So: Clever game but no more than 7.5 out of 10.  Sorry, Uwe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Sehr gut, aber nicht mit zu vielen Spielern spielen.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
EDIT/UPDATE: I've now played several times, and with more players... the game just doesn't get old, and leaves all players (even -- or ESPECIALLY -- the losers) with a feeling of "Wait, I want a rematch... what if I just did that one move differently?"   You always feel like your fate is your own, and was in your hands the entire time (even if it means -- which it does -- that you have to vary your tactics and your plans and adapt to what is best when your turn arrives.)

I stick by my 9 rating for 2-player game because it is just too easy to buy and to enter buildings, and to avoid using other people's buildings. That is not the case in a 3 or 4 player game, so in the case of 3-4 players, this game is basically the most balanced, perfect game I have ever played. This is now my favorite 3-player game, hands down, and probably my favorite for 4 players, as well.

PS. The iOS version is quite nice. I bought the original boxed version (well worth it, esp. with free expansion deck included), and then bought the iOS app to take on the road and for camping trip. Well worth the $5.


ORIGINAL REVIEW: Great game. My wife isn't into most games, but I love them and don't have many gaming buddies to play with, so we're always on the lookout for a game that will be "just right" even for 2-players (but also playable with other amounts of players.)  Not such an easy-task.

Le Havre is a great game. The rules provide enough complexity to really make you think, plan ahead, use some psychology, and consider multiple strategies... yet they are simple enough to quickly grasp and not bog down the game mechanics.

Even though the "harbor" theme is very similar to other agricultural-style games (Agricola, Seeland, etc.) we really like the theme more than the farming ones. Something about boats just feels more fun than farming does, and the artwork is just colorful and whimsical enough to enforce that breezy feeling.

Components are great (even coming with ziplock bags for easy organization! I love German eurogames) and the rule-book is better than most I have read (perfectly organized and arranged so that it made sense the first time -- good examples, clarifications, and very little need to refer to it later)

I have only played 2-player, so I can comment on the + and - of that:

+ Turn pacing is fantastically balanced. Doesn't take too long to wait for your turn (and, being a eurogame with almost zero luck involved, you can take the time to really plan out Plan A and Plan B strategies when your turn comes.) Allows enough time to think and feel like you are really making some weighty choices that turn -- which you are; every decision counts. But the nice thing is, no single early decision is going to ruin your chances later in the game. You always feel like you are in the running and have a chance to catch up (or fall behind), although late-game choice become very, very critical.

- The "entry fee" to use buildings seems like it would be great to become a real estate baron, but with 2 players there were almost always alternate sources to get goods and materials, and the fact that people can pay less food than gold means the entry fees amount to almost nothing. That's a shame, because I feel it could be one of the most strategic and interesting aspects of the game.

- It seems a little ridiculous that you pay the same interest every turn regardless of how many loans you have. It means that if you are going to carry one loan, you might as well carry a dozen. I started buying up many properties and thus was consistently short on food; no problem, just take out another loan!  I had 5 or 6 loans for most of the game (buying up everything in sight in the meantime), while my opponent was almost debt-free... and yet I ended up winning by a significant amount at the end of the game.  I think we might establish a house rule to pay ONE PER LOAN every time interest is due.

- Feels like it would be a better game with 3 or 4 players. Most games feel like they were really designed for the magic "4 player" number, and some seem like they were designed for 2 with extras being added as an afterthought. This one is different, because I really feel like 3 PLAYERS might be the magic number, but I won't know until I try.  Competing for buildings to enter isn't very difficult with 2 players, but would be a lot more strategic and psychological with 3 or 4. 

It's not a PERFECT game (and I think it will play very different -- but just as balanced or moreso -- with more players) but it is a FUN game and we will definitely play again soon. We might add a few house tweaks to the rules (maybe for entry fees or loans) but I'll need to play a few more times to see if that's necessary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[EDIT] And it seems to have told me that Le Havre is too long and repetitive for its own good. There appears to be one dominant strategy, that of shipping coke, so every ~3 hour game feels the same. 
As for solo, I'm not sure how it compares to Agricola. Agricola works solo largely because of the cards, whereas the only variability in Le Havre is in the order of the buildings and which specials come up. I doubt that will be enough to hold interest.

RATING: 6.5
Since many ppl call it the better or gamer's version of Agricola, I wasn't that excited, as I don't like Agricola. I played it by now and I really don't see why ppl call it that way. This is a completely different game, including the feeling of it and it's much better, too. Still, I don't need the game right now, but I may buy it some day.

Sure, it's not bad per se, but one of the best games? No and never. Other games that convert things into points are less fiddly and get ignored without a reason.

Way too fiddly and more on the boring side of gaming.

RATING: 10
UPDATE:  Another full game with 4 (3 new).  I took nearly 4 hours, but I still enjoyed every minute of it.  

I've played 2 full games and 1 short game, and it is an instant 10 for me.  I like it much more than Agricola, and want to play it more than any other game right now.  If it works well as a 2-player game, and varies enough from game to game, it could become my favorite game.

Lots of tension, lots of difficult choices, and a lot of balls to keep in the air.  Nice planning for end game points, and there always seems to be a back up plan.  Very small incremental turns, but long term strategy (always seem to have 3 or 4 plans at once) and the opportunity for big plays.

The three player game seemed to be much tougher than the 4 player version.

Early cows seem to be a necessity, and by far the most efficient means of getting food when the Abattoir comes out.

I like that you can invest your money in certain buildings (the $4 start building for example) that have no entry fee, but increase your bonuses for other buildings at the expense of liquidity.

Excellent game and a sure buy for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent engine-building, worker placement, resource management game that takes mechanics introduced by Rosenberg in Agricola and refines them beautifully.  It's this elegant synergy that makes Le Havre, for me, a much better gaming experience than Agricola.  

There are variable (seemingly endless) paths and strategies to success, which rewards flexible thinking and pre-planning. Le Havre, for this reason, is slightly more forgiving. Not to say that a misstep or miscalculation won't cost you victory, but in Le Havre a less than ideal play won't bury you in the first 20 minutes and leave you watching everyone else break away and excel for the remaining 2.5 hours of the game.  

It can get bogged down with analysis paralysis - but there is a speed curve during the 20 rounds of the game, and it moves more quickly with experienced or repeat players.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What initially looked like a confusing mess at Essen has, after some organizing and a couple dozen games, turned into an incredible game.  

The decisions are often tough, the player interaction is fairly high for a euro (via blocking or taking goods based on your opponents' needs), and time is not bad (less than an hour for two experienced players).

The more I've played the better it's become.  Highly recommended.

RATING: 7
I don't like that this game's final winning score is over 200 -- but now that I know that, maybe I'll play better with that goal in mind.

The absolute key to this game is efficiency of your actions.  You should get huge piles (like 10 chits) of raw materials (e.g. clay, coal, iron) and then convert a whole pile in one fell swoop (e.g. to bricks, coke, steel).  Another key is to get ships as soon as possible, because they will help you pay for the food that you owe at the end of every turn.  You shouldn't have to be scrounging for fish by the end of the game... ships should supply most or all of your needs.

In the middle of my first game, I exclaimed, "This is like Caylus -- except you ONLY HAVE ONE WORKER! ARGH!!"  

I first played a 2-player game, and it was enjoyable.  Since you get either 3 or 4 actions per round with 2 players, then you have a real chance to plan a turn out.  However, there were so many actions I wanted to accomplish, and if I took one (say, mining for coal in the colliery), then the next step (say, turning coal to coke in the cokery) was often blocked by my opponent's worker (on purpose).  I thought this would be harder to deal with in a 3- to 5-player game, where you get fewer actions, but it might be okay because more buildings come out, so there are more options available.

I started by trying to feed my people entirely without taking loans.  But building a money and food engine isn't enough -- you sometimes need to skimp on food to get some important building materials.  The key thing to remember is that not matter HOW MANY LOANS you take, you only pay ONE FRANC PER TURN (not 1 Franc per loan) in interest!  So take lots of loans (like 5-10), but pay them back at the end else it will cost you many points.

For most of the game, wood is critical for building buildings and powering refineries, so taking wood (and starving other players of it) is a great step.  Clay is also important, and later, all big buildings are built with brick, so building the brickyard is a good idea.  Obviously, don't forget ships -- iron ships go a long way to help you feed your people as well as to provide efficient shipping (3 energy for three goods).

But mainly, it's important to set up an efficient economic engine and stick with it.  So, get the Colliery and the Cokery, and other things that people (and you) will want to take because they're so efficient to use.

Need to play many more times to get the hang of it... I never seem to learn my lesson, and end up playing defensively and with too much attention to not starving rather than paying attention to efficiency.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is my favorite of the Harvest Trilogy - why? I love games which promote creativity and openness (which is why I love Kramer). Where Agricola and Gates of the Loyang provide strong game tension via needing to feed your family and satisfying your customers, Le Havre provides multiple paths to victory AND the space to explore them. Granted, like Agricola and Gates of the Loyang, there is also a narrative that needs to at very least be heeded (e.g., you need to start "parental planning" early in Agricola). In Le Havre, this could be the meta-narrative of naval and production progress - it usually does not pay to be a "harbour hero" (i.e., a player who acts tough and thinks that they can get away with not building a boat in a game about a harbour). However, one does not necessarily need to stay on track (e.g., you don't have to get into the mid-to-late game coke/steel engine building) but it is worth doing a little mental math to make sure that your breaking from meta-narrative is profitable.

My favorite break from narrative was the time in which instead of being a harbour master, I retired from that profession roughly mid-game to focus on my love of pisciculture (and marketing). Yes, I started a zoo, which I stocked with fish caught through the fishery and even displayed some livestock I had acquired along the way. The demand on the zoos was so great that I had opened an Entrepos - an early Pets Are Us if you will. While other players were stoking coals, I was showcasing aquariums. AND IT PAID.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Guess this is simply not my type of game. Feels very long and repetitive, and hard to find any long term strategy. No matter what you do, there are a lot of good choices, but primary focus throughout the game seems to be building ships, which makes the progression so predictable.

Maybe I need to play it a few times more (I have 3 plays), but how this game can be in BGG top ten, is beyond me. There is either a lack of depth or I am missing something. I play games to have a good time, and there seems to be no FUN in this game - it just makes me want to go back to my economic games and train games. 

I will try a few times more and hope to be able to increase the rating.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My son and I really enjoy Le Havre.  My wife would consider it an "okay" game.  I think she finds the 3+ hours it takes to play a little long.  And 3+ hours might be a little long, but it definitely does not feel that long during the game.

I think the game has a smooth flow to it, and there are always a lot of choices.  It is similar to Agricola in that obtaining food is always a big priority -- and that other players can interfere with your plans to obtain said food (or other resources).  However, with Le Havre, there are more options to obtain food and more choices in regards to resources and building projects.

My guess is that if you enjoy Agricola, you will enjoy Le Havre, but it is possible you will like Le Havre even if you are not an Agricola fan.  I am big on Agricola, but I actually enjoy Le Havre even more, as the mechanics are different and there are more purchasing choices.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An interesting game, and very definitely the kinder & gentler sibling of Agricola, Le Havre is less of a "fight to struggle for points while surviving" contest, and more of a "increase wealth potential while gathering food" game. 

On a first, solo shortened 2-player game, it starts at a 7, but because it truly is kinder & gentler than Agricola, it may climb less high but get more plays, especially with family members.

Definitely a keeper, and a nice game, less dry than often reviewed, but still a management/growth game like it's agricultural older brother.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
(12/16/2008) Initial play. From the same designer as Agricola, Le Havre borrows a number of mechanics and slips on a modern theme. Basically a gather resources, upgrade resources, build or buy buildings/ships, and generate income/victory points game. Le Havre feels more sequential, since you only have one worker, versus the two or more family members in Agricola, which feels more like random-access, and multi-tasking. The theme definitely works, where one gets the feel of moving from colonial to industrial revolution to modern times. With three, it seemed to go fast, with little downtime, but our first game still took four hours. I suspect it will be longer with five. It is yet another fidgety game with lots of small counters, like Agricola, but fun nevertheless--maybe a different kind of fun. In Agricola, you're trying to survive, while in Le Havre, you feel like an entrepreneur/businessman just starting out at the dawn of the industrial revolution. Neat game, can't wait to try it again. Initial rating: "8".

Update (4/22/09): I shudder now every time Le Havre and Agricola come out--a brain-burning, frustrating pair of games that I can't seem to get my head around from the same designer. Great games for sure, but I dislike playing them, because they are not relaxing for me--I'm stressed out at the end of each. Power Grid has the same kind of stress, but it makes sense; Le Havre doesn't "click" with me. Maybe a couple more tries...

Update (06/18/10): There are people in my gaming group that love this game. I avoid it like the plague. Hold a gun to my head and I will play, reluctantly and disgruntled. Downing to a "6".

Update (08/06/10): Someone held a gun to my head, so I played (just kidding, but I did not want to be the party-pooper), and I did okay. I think I realize why I don't like this game, as there are a ton of buildings to figure out, each with a special ability that supposedly makes life easier. The food situation in this game starts as a slow simmer, but becomes a rapid boil, where if food production hasn't been established early, then you're wasting actions on gathering/producing. This is the part I still don't get, but I am willing to try.

Update (08/14/10) 5 plays: I am playing better, where in a 3P game scored 200, but a newbie scored 219, and the veteran scored 245. I concentrated, and did well, in building a majority of the buildings, but got destroyed in steel production, shipping, and luxury ships. I am convinced that I dislike this game, because of the way it makes me feel at the end. I still don't get it.

Update (11/12/10) 6 plays: Tried it again after a hiatus of three months, and I did not enjoy myself. I was completely lost with an ever increasing decision tree (which I don't like), based on more buildings (and options) being built, and their associated complex interactions. I didn't enjoy the fact that a player sat on a building that I needed for half the game. I could never grasp the concept that I can pick up resources AND buy a building, or even to sell a building to get money to do something else. Then there was the ever present feeling of dread of being slowly simmered to death (the relentless increase in feeding). I am simply not clicking with this game, and I am no longer interested in investing anymore time in trying to figure it out; I'm done with this game. Dropping it to a '3'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Now we've had 6 games (4 of them full games) I feel able to rate this. 

We love it - it's a perfect blend of Caylus, Puerto Rico and Agricola.

It's much less fiddly than Agricola, has simple rules but deep gameplay, multiple paths to victory and I find it very satisfying.

...Later: After a few more games, I've upgraded the rating slightly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is a sandbox, where you and up to 4 other players compete to exploit every business oppertunity handed to you. The game reminds me somewhat of Puerto rico, in the sense that you are forced to adjust your plan according to what your fellow players are doing, and that your final score depend heavily on your last end moves. However, there is much greater sense of freedom than in Puerto Rico, and also a greater replayablilty as each game uses 6 Special Buildings that alter the business enviroment in Le Havre profoundly. The game comes with 25 Special Building and the 6 cards are drawn randomly, making each game unique. Get it, play it, it's a wonderful box of pure money-making fun!
Oh, and one more thing - don't be intimidated by taking a couple of loans! It's really not that bad!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

(Have not played any of his other games yet)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Meh. I kinda like the idea of the "micro-turns" in theory but in practice I don't know if it really made any kind of difference to anything. The game took a very long time with just three players. Both loans and the food mechanism seemed weird to me. (Who am I paying all that food to? Why don't loans work in anything resembling a real world way?)

Starts out pretty simple but balloons to an extraordinary number of options by the end.

Doesn't seem like the payment for using other people's buildings is enough, especially since it means they can block the owner from using it indefinitely.

The overwhelming importance of ships wasn't made clear to me by the Explainers but I don't blame the game for that. Still annoying to play a game for 3 hours and realize 1.5 hours in that my lack of ship acquisition meant I had little chance of winning.

Felt enough like Agricola that I would probably just play that instead, since it is a shorter game.

RATING: N/A
規則:
*起始資源
長版玩家有5元一煤
短版玩家有5元2魚2木2土2鐵1牛2煤2皮，單人雙人都起始有一木船
*起始補給板塊洗混蓋著放置，玩家踩到才打開，對應資源格放資源
長版2元2魚2木1土，洗好六張特殊建築放上面
短版3元3魚3木2土1鐵1麥1牛，單人有一木船開著
*挑出對應建築物分三推洗勻，打開按數字牌好放在版圖上，選擇正確的記輪牌疊好
*每輪移動玩家船標記到下一格並補充資源
*玩家每回合可選擇一棟工人到建築物做動作，或是拿某一格資源全部
*此外還可買賣建築物(公有或是建築計畫區最上面那張)不算動作，賣建築物半價，船也可買
*船移動到利息格，有借貸不管幾張都只要付一元
*遊戲任何時候付食物都可用錢取代
*遊戲在每七回合一輪結束付食物並生麥生牛，然後最後一輪結束每位玩家可在執行一個動作(此動作可重複)
*工人必須進入建築物才能動作，被買的建築物，上面工人會回擁有者手上，同回合不能同建築物賣又買回來
*建設時，磚可以代替黏土，鋼可以代替鐵
*造船一次只能造一艘
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Nice design.  Lots of things to think about with many viable strategies.  A dynamic game that changes from play to play.  I get more of a feeling of interaction with Le Havre than other games in its category.  That said, it is really heavy for a Euro and a bit long.  There are many opportunities for analysis paralysis, even among more veteran players.  Hard to teach to just anyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Another worker placement game, but unlike Agricola there's no cute theme to draw you in, just the job of optimising a very limited number of moves while gathering sufficient food to feed your workers. This really is a game of ruthless action efficiency. At 2-2.5 hours it's a bit long for what feels like a pretty dry game, but of its type its the best there is outside of the Splotter catalogue. It's perhaps a shame that a winning score is so dependent on coke and steel, a wider range of viable strategies would make for a stronger game, also food shortage isn't the threat that it is in Agricola as loans are cancellable with the right building. Less luck dependent than Agricola, but Agricola is just more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It takes a few plays to "get it," or at least it did for me.  Quite heavy, it is similar to Agricola mostly in the level of detail that it is willing to deal with--only it goes even further--Building things often requires energy as well.  I've always liked the mechanism in Caylus whereby you must pay others to use their buildings; that's here as well, but once again, Le Havre adds a level of complexity by varying the prices. It also adds an interesting river mechanism which controls what goods recover each term--perhaps the cleverest part of the game. So, it ends up feeling very different from either of these games.  There's a lot going on--at first it seemed like too much, especially since it is hard to see all the cards and you basically just have to remember them (surely there is a better way they could have done this?). 

Shipping line is VERY strong, especially in the two player game I played.  With more players, there are more ways to make money.  But I don't know if you can ignore it and win.

After 6 plays I finally managed not to come in last! uh.. so I suck. yes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A good, solid game that will take several plays to appreciate all the possibilities.  The Special buildings should ensure that no two games are exactly the same.  The basic game mechanisms are easy to grasp and follow, leaving lots of time to concentrate on maximising your score, and also mean that it's an easy game to come back to after a while and not have to re-learn - it's a bit like riding a bike.

Initial impressions are good, but I wouldn't be surprised to see a Caylus-like effect happen on BGG - you'll either love it or loathe it and the ratings could rise rapidly to a peak before slowly sinking back into the pack.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Supera algunos fallos de diseño de Agricola (pocas maneras de ganar y cierre de ellas entre jugadores, tiempo elevado en reposición de recursos, azar en el reparto de cartas)con MUCHAS maneras de ganar y reduciendo el nivel de aleatoreidad y la sensación de "se acaba cuando la cosa funciona". Gana en profundidad y duración. Buena mecánica la cantidad de acciones que se pueden hacer con las mercancías: comerlas, procesarlas, embarcarlas, venderlas, quemarlas y conseguir energía...Contras: poco innovador (¿otro más de colocar trabajadores como Caylus?), repetitivo (turno tras turno haces siempre lo mismo),tiende al A/P. (+30 partidas en solitario)

[ENG]

It overcomes Agricola desing´s worst fails (few ways to win, lot of time wasted replacing resources, luck when the cards are dealed). Le Havre has A LOT of paths to victory, the luck has been reduced and the "it ends when it´s working" feeling doesn´t exist. LH Needs more time and has more gamer´s weight. I do love the different ways you can use the resources: processing it, eating, shipping, selling, burning them to earn energy... The main CONS are: not very innovative (it seems another worker placement game), a bit repetitive (turn after turn you´re doing the same) AP+.

(+30 games in solo mode)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Le Havre is a heavy resource management game, but its mechanics are easy to understand.  It's fun to see how your engine evolves, but gameplay can feel repetitive after a few rounds.  Similar to every other Uwe Rosenberg game in that you construct buildings that help you convert resources into other resources.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
totally awesome. buildings come out gradualy only 3 available at any one time. as soon as one is built another becomes available, you can build buildings paying the construction cost or buy buildings with gold. every round you can gain resources (neat mechanic) or go use a building. and in addition you can buy and sell buildings you own. Some buildings have a cost to use and some buildings have bonuses during the game or at game end. by grabbing low hanging fruit and using it efficiently and planning ahead. This game ticks all my boxes. better than Agricola for me as the group shares in the cards that add the random element. the different game everytime makes it more appealing than say caylus.

RATING: 6

The game just takes too long without enough variety, and the very linear progression does not appeal to me - it feels too much like a grind as opposed to Agricola's "holy crap I need to do 20 things and I only have time to do 5" intensity.  I do prefer Le Havre to O&L as I think the complexity got just a little out of hand in the latter case, but given the choice I would go for Agricola over Le Havre every time.

RATING: 8.5
Greater than the sum of it's parts

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is a heavy duty worker placement Euro.  There are many different resources, many buildings that can be built and subsequently used by players.  There is virtually no luck in this game.  As play proceeds, players are presented with a progressively richer array of choices for their one action on their turn.  Le Havre takes a longer time to play(3.5-4 hours) than most of my other favorite Euro games (~2 hours)  Plays best with 3 players.  Le Havre is also a very good 2 player game.  The game can get unmanageable at 4 or 5 players because each player can put their worker on and use other players' buildings.  So trying to scan the whole table at four or five different players' buildings is only recommended if every player knows the game well.  I do love this game.  It is very well designed.  However, the fact that it is such a heavy game and takes a long time to complete makes it relatively harder to get to the table than most of my other games, thus negatively impacting my personal rating of this otherwise outstanding, excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Find that Homesteaders provides the same kind of gameplay with less overhead and faster play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Le Havre is a truly great game. The theme of building up the town of Le Havre, as new advancements in production become available, is wonderfully fluid and allows quite an intuitive connection with the heavy resource conversion strategies that make up the game's core. I like how players are competing to build up their own stake in the town, and by having ownership of the various businesses, the game both pits players against one another while making it necessary to collaborate. It creates a game climate in which everything has such a seamless synergy that it is almost zen-like in exploring the flow of the game. 

The game is also quite brilliant in how it achieves such a dense, satisfying game experience while being incredibly easy to play. Playing the game itself could not be more simple: take a pile of resources, or utilize one of the businesses. A simple choice which over the course of the game blossoms into a myriad of options as the available businesses become more sophisticated. I'm confident that this game could be played by anyone, while being incredibly difficult to master its progression. That to me makes for a perfect game experience: accessibility married with a high skill ceiling. 

Some have said that it lacks variability in gameplay, but I disagree. The businesses that are built will for the most part be the same each game, yes. But the variation comes from the timing of when each business becomes available for use and the availability of resources. In my plays this has meant very diverse paths that each game's trajectory follows. Another way to say it is that while the game's "destination" is largely the same each time, the journey to get there is never quite the same. And the journey is where the strategy and the tactics of playing the game are contained. 

I really love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a great game! 

Much like Agricola, your options continue to increase throughout the game. I really enjoy how your card play in this one gives your opponents extra options as well.

I think I may even prefer the pacing of Le Havre, although time will tell about the replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Le Havre really appeals to me. It is very much a gamer's game, with many decision points, a requirement for planning and the tension of trying to optimise your play with a restricted number of turns. Players interact in a number of different ways, so it is important to keep track of what the others are doing and it helps to anticipate what they may do. The random ordering of the building cards and selection of special building cards makes each play different and obliges you to alter your tactics, if not your strategy.

RATING: 8
Complex, typical 'gamers' game': collect resources, build buildings, use resources, transform resources into others, use these transformed resources to build subsequent buildings which can in turn transform other reources etc etc etc...  

I like this mix very much.

My only gripe is that buildings are not balanced - some are used very often, some - sporadically and some - almost never.  It also narrows the choice of possible paths to follow.  Not good...

[solo mode works, but is not as exciting as in Agricola, pity]

EDIT: 5-player game is bad. Too much is going on and you can't monitor all the other players' moves/strategies. And interaction is VERY important in this game - so I would like to have everything under close scrutiny, which is not possible with 5 players..
I'll be avoiding 5-player games of Le Havre in the future...

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent followup to AG, really solid just a little long and slightly fiddly. Uwe cements himself as a designer to watch with 2 in a row. 

Basically a resource management worker placement game of efficiency where you need somewhat of a food engine and you need to be buying buildings for points and small bonuses for when people use them. Some big buildings and ships need to be planned for which are bigger points and potential bonus points. 

You do see both AG and a little Caylus here just as Uwe says, a very nice game and a good mix of strategy and tactics that with building ownership also sees a little interaction. Without knowing the buildings strategy is limited but once you know them these can be planned for, chalk up the first game for learning. 

The game bogs down in later rounds as so many actions become available and the potential decision tree becomes massive but more play should speed this up from the beginning time frame of 1 hour per player, meaning 5 players is out, 4 is pushing it, 3 probably best just for the time until more familiar then 4 will be a great tight game (after 2 games at least).  

I really don't find this much heavier than AG, just longer and it is not a complex game either, very straightforward, its just that there is a fair amount of actions to choose from in the later part of the game and there is a lot of forward thinking needed to beat good players, so it is pretty damn meaty yes.  Another plus, pretty much zero luck and perfect information.

Rating might go up somewhat when playtime decreases and strategy increases.  

[u]Update:[/u] 8.25 => 7.5 Not sure why but I am finding this to be more like work than fun and I don't think I've ever made that complaint before. I absolutely hate trying to look around the table to see everyones cards (usually have to stand which is ridiculous), these should have been smaller tiles with icons no doubt about it but then the Caylus resemblence would have been a little too much. Lastly, this game possibly brings out the worst AP in me yet, usually I can keep my turns to a decent time but the analysis once so many buildings are in play can really bog someone down. I also find a frustration here that I usually love (AG, ITYOTD, etc) but this time is becoming aggravating, it seems it is very easy to just be one step behind, ie one resource behind what you need to do. So while this creates great angst it is frustrating the shit out of me. I normally like this kind of torture in the right amounts, here it seems to be a big part of the game where the building you really wanted and planned for gets snapped up one turn ahead of you because you needed food or something else or the building you need to use is being blocked and it stalls your whole plan, the blocking is especially annoying here because someone does not have to move at any given time and can sit there indefinitely. At this point I think I need a break from the game, could be a permanent one as there are so many games I would rather play but I will likely come back to this and hopefully when I'm fully awake! 

Edit - I have been thinking about this one lately and the depth the game offers after a long rest and want to play again. The number of buildings and abilities really does require you to know them to be competitive though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]

RATING: N/A
1-5pp
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Tried it solo because I got to the game club earlier than my friends and it seemed worth learning. It was a lot of fun as a solo game, but it seems like the more players the less good it would be. At the max 5 players 60% of rounds you'd get a single action before the harvest, and the other 40% you'd get two. I know that the feeding requirements are severely lessened at more players, but it still seems like it would be really unfun to do so little. I could see this being ok at 2 and maybe not terrible at 3, but it seems pretty much ideal as a single player experience, which isn't something I'm really that into. Still a solid game in that context.

The game itself is pretty simple, every time it's your turn you can either pick up a pile of resources or activate a building, which generally either lets you build a building or convert some resources into other resources. It seems like the steel is very powerful though since it can be sold for like 12 points, so in a multiplayer game I can see it coming down to who can most often use the steel producing and selling buildings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The obvious comparison is to Agricola, given that they share a designer and publisher, not to mention having to feed your people.  In Agricola you always feel like you're having to continually scramble to make your commitments, not to mention having to continually revise your plans when people take your key actions.  In Le Havre, however, it feels much more leisurely - you don't feel like you have to scramble to get to feed your people, and as a consequence you feel like you can take a bit longer view.  I actually like the compression and tension of Agricola slightly better, but this is still an excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Dry but good game. Nice mechanics
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting game with a lot of depth, unlike other top games this one has a best strategy (if there is no competition). 

The solo game is an interesting puzzle, but there is no incentive to do anything other than ship coke/steel unless the right special buildings come out. 

2/3p is where the game gets interesting, you no longer get free reign on coke/steel, and now have to explore different ways of efficiently scoring points. Also more harvests means more grain and cows in the game, making those strategies more viable.

I don't think I want to play this 4/5 player, since it increases the chance of getting blocked, you only get to do 1/2 actions between each harvest, and the number of rounds doesn't increase linearly with 4 and 5 players (I assume to keep game time down). So the number of actions that each player gets to do in the whole game goes down with more players.

No of Actions with different player counts:
1p: 49
2p: 49
3p: 42
4p: 35
5p: 28

Ignoring 4/5 player, my only criticism is how few special buildings come out, some of which are incredibly underwhelming (espcially given how few come out), there are of course fan made variants that try to fix this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Absorbing environment with many more options than Agricola, yet not enough conflict--with a bazillion actions to choose from, chances are nobody's in your way.

I like the build-up of goods, how goods can be converted and how cash works. Ships seem "bolted on."

The rules are elegant enough and stay out of your way most of the time. But expect your first game to be an overload. So many buildings and an exponential amount of combinations and paths. The game can drag at times if the players aren't ready to take their turns -- since the turn order never changes, there are few excuses not to be.

For me, I guess, this is a thick steak. Meaty, reasonably tasty and satisfying, but not memorable.

EDIT: Played again. More comfortable play, but still too mathy for me. Not enough anticipation or intuition for me, just pure income building. Also, I was third to act in a 3 player game and felt my choice of good was lame (other two took the wood and clay, leaving practically nothing.)

EDIT 2: Have had no interest in playing this since the last edit. Downgrading to 5.

EDIT 3: OK, I downloaded the app for the iPad and have played about 30 games and have beaten it at 3, 4 and 5p at the hardest AI level. I get the game now and I like it. Upgrading to 7.5.  The "warnings" above still apply--there is a big overload for your first few games and you may feel like you wasted a few hours. Once you get the feel for everything that's there, it's a well-designed game. There is conflict, if subtle.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Too mathy, not enough confrontation. The ultimate in building your economic momentum, but just not that much fun. Great for ten years ago, slightly above average now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a very pure Euro.  Every turn some additional stuff (fish, iron, etc) piles up on the warf and you get to grab some of it.  Or you can put your rep on a building that you or someone else owns to do something useful, including building more buildings, using the resources that you've collected from the wharf or from a building.  In this manner you maximize your end game points, building up an engine.  It's fun to collect the goodies and build up your collection of buildings.  There are certain paths to victory that you can follow.  There aren't really grand strategies.  It's a very tactical game.  And there isn't really a potential for interesting synergies or new combos.  It's really a game of making the best choice each turn, with a certain amount of trying to guess what the other players are up to avoid getting blocked or to block someone else (only one rep can be in a building at a time).  It's not like Agricola though as each rep stays in the building until moved to a new one so if the player chose to grab resources at the wharf it'll remain on the building, so there's not as much maneuvering since it's not guaranteed that a player will open up a building each turn even if they clearly intend to do something else soon.  It's a cerebral game rather than a tense game.  I'm willing to play it but it's not something I'd suggest on my own.  There is an app version of it which is very well done and playing the computer doesn't seem terribly different from playing humans.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Le Havre features a pretty straightforward set of Euro-style rules, but manages to offer tremendous replay value with it's different paths to victory and little bits of randomization in the setup. It features some really tough decisions, frequently tempting players with multiple interesting options. My only complaints are the difficultly in sensing which players are doing well (in some games this is fun but in Le Havre it is a bit frustrating) and the fairly slow pace the game can hit (I'm not sure if I'd ever want to play it with 4 or 5 players). All in all, it's a solid Euro that I recommend (especially for those looking for something great for small groups).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Have played this once and really like.  I kept thinking of it afterwards so I bought it the next day.

RATING: 7
A brain burning game.  Lots of hard choices.  More differences than similarities to Agricola.  I personally prefer Agricola(on the lower half of my top ten).  In Agricola everything you do more or less makes sense from the first play.  For example, if you make a larger family you need more food.  Or an Occupation is a job you take on that provides benefits.  Le Havre loses this a bit.  Food is again a constant struggle, but it isn't clear why.  In your first play you gather resources to start the game, but it isn't immediately obvious what the point is until later in the game when buildings clarify the purpose.  Finally, the shipping theme doesn't work for me as well as the farming theme.  In summary, a very very good game that has obvious connections to Agricola, but in my mind falls short of BGG's current champ.

RATING: 8
Marvellous game, but very long! Interesting and deep. It very much feels like the offspring of Agricola, with a bit of Caylus thrown in.

Somewhat more a gamer's game than Agricola and not quite as thematic. It does escalate nicely, though, and while the early turns might see you content if you can scrape together a couple of fish in your turn, the endgame will see you building churches and bridges, and you will be selling shiploads of manufactured goods for big $.

So far, I am very impressed. My only fear is that the playing time might result in it not being played as much as it deserves... (Of course, one could always play the short game instead). I think I prefer this with no more than 3 players.

RATING: 8
2012-09-14

Initial Rating : 8.0 (May 2012)

So far, I have liked every game from designer Uwe Rosemberg and Le Havre was no exception. I still love Agricola, but Le Havre has the potential to surpass it, if only I could play it more times :(. 

For me, the theme is very boring. I would have never played it if it wasn’t for its high rating here on BGG. But when I played it I loved it. This is the kind of game I like. It is a very involved game in which you have to think deeply and carefully about your moves. If I though Agricola had difficult choices, Le Havre IS WORST as you have only 1 ACTION each turn (It is indeed A worker placement game :D). The decisions are agonizingly hard and I love that. The playtime is long but as I’m thinking constantly about my moves, I don´t mind as much. I would like to try it as a 3 player game to avoid an excessive downtime but will play with any number of players.

This is a gamer´s game, not recommended to casual or family gamers as it takes a long time to play, it has hard decisions and the rules are not as easy to teach as in Agricola.

I feel the game is a lot harder than Agricola and I can´t wait to play it again, I suspect that the rating will go up with more plays. This is one of the games I really wish to explore further. A winner in my book.

Current Rating: 8.0
[hr]
2014-06-26

After more plays, I continue to love Le Havre, still I was wrong about it surpassing  Agricola, which is THE king of the worker placement games for me. Both games are very good and now Le Havre is a must have for me.

It is best with 3 players.

One of 2008´s favorites.

Current Rating: 8.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An incredible game with very tough decisions.  one of my favourite things about Le Havre is that the rules are incredibly easy to learn but the decisions are very complex.  I find this offers a great balance between being able to pick it up quickly but requiring multiple plays to achieve mastery.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is pure resource porn.  Seriously, eight different resources, all of which can be refined?  I suppose I need to thank Hanno and Uwe for one thing; after playing Le Havre I'll never need to buy Roads and Boats.  All of the crazy resource conversions are there without the more tedious logistics, and though I'll happily play the Splotter game, I'll probably always want to play Le Havre more.  Even if I break down and buy this game eventually that fact might still save me fifty dollars.

It seems as though replayability is one of Uwe Rosenberg's strengths, with the myriad different special buildings and variable resource refresh setups.

The game feels like it just narrowly avoids being a march through the same few tedious strategies.  Timing and efficient use of the special buildings can be key to really high scores.  If I have three, or even four, I'll nearly always suggest Le Havre.

- Lots of choices on your turn, but there's generally only ~3 things you really want to do there and then, plus there's the 1-2 things you should do to block your opponent(s)...

- Setup and tear-down is a little painful, recommend using containers with lids vs. baggies.

RATING: 7
Fantastic game. Wife hates it though cause of the need for animal killing. I understand her point. I still really enjoy the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The most difficult part about this game, the first time you play it, is the set up (way easier, even incredibly cool, when you understand it). With a variable set up based on the number of players the game set up is different on every player count. 
The actions you take each turn is so simple.... move your ship and add two supplies to the dock. Then take one major action; take all the goods of one type, or move your single worker to a building (card ) and follow it's description. From these two actions the game evolves into an amazing sense of escalation and complexity. From such simple beginnings of taking a few goods and struggling to aquire enough food; to huge moves at the end of the game buying luxury liners. 
From having a few common building to owning a huge industry is very satisfying. 
What's so cool throughout the game is every building is available for use by anyone, even the ones your oponents own (although you may have to pay them an entry fee to use them), the only building(s) that you can't use are the ones already occupied by other workers. 
I can't wait to play this game again!!! A must play keeper!!!

玩這個遊戲真的很像在港口工作的感覺阿...，每次玩起來策略都不同，只可惜實體設置煩瑣，時間過長，但是還是非常棒的遊戲
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What stands out for me in this game is the unique gameplay: players only take one action per turn. However, actions often use a building which another player owns so the active player must pay the other player to use it. This nicely means there is a lot of player interaction and part of the game can be about getting the building that other players will need to use.
Also love the conversion of goods into other goods which also all feels pretty logical and so is easy to remember, e.g. use fish and fuel in the smokehouse to get smoked fish.
Combine with art by the same guy who did Agricola (same game designer, too!) and we're onto a winner. Love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Agricola is a good game, but I'm one that can play it every few months and be satisfied; no 2-3 times in one day for me!

Le Havre, though.....[b]that[/b] I could play over and over again.  I find Le Havre to be more accessible, more forgiving and the theme more interesting than Agricola.  I've read several people saying the opposite, though, so take it with a grain of salt.  You can tell that Agricola and Le Havre are related, much in the same way that Tikal, Mexica and Java are related.

I've played it with 1, 2, 3 & 4 and enjoyed all of them immensely, though they each had their own flavor.

RATING: 9
The amount of strategy and planning in Le Havre is almost overwhelming. There are so many choices and buildings you don't know where to start. However, once you get the hang of it the game is a blast to play! No luck here, strategy is your best friend.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Different enough from Agricola and Caylus to stand separately from those great games and not diminish in comparison. It borrows the action development of Caylus and the immediate vs. long term decision making of Agricola, but the object of Le Havre focuses solely on the act of making the most money, which gives it a very different feel than the "balanced development" the others focus on. 

Strategy is heavily influenced by the changing order in which buildings become available from game to game and the choice of "special buildings" that are available. Future small expansions that change this mix of buildings could provide tremendous variety and staying power. The game can feel a little repetitive at times and I wouldn't exactly say that the game feels "fresh" following on the heels of Agricola, but it is an excellent, strategically rich game nonetheless. If you enjoy Agricola or Caylus, there's an excellent chance you'll enjoy this too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Este juego es realmente bueno, se merece estar en el Top10 de la BGG.

Tiene mecánicas similares a Agricola (Cosecha, procesado de materiales,...) pero es un juego muy distinto, quizá incluso mejor.

En cada turno puedes conseguir materiales ó usar un edificio, y ademas puedes comprar/vender edificios y/o barcos y también pagar prestamos anteriores. Los edificios y los barcos te darán puntos al final de la partida. Los materiales no te darán nada al final pero los necesitas para poder construir nuevos edificios y barcos, tambien para alimentar a tu gente. Los barcos y algunos edificios te ayudarán a alimentarlos también.

No necesitas construir un edificio para usarlo, siempre puedes pagarle comida y/o dinero a su propietario para usarlo. A veces es una buena manera de bloquear el edificio de un rival, porque solo un jugador puede estar en un edificio. 
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2010
[/color][color=blue]
This game is really good, it really deserves its place inside the BGG Top10.

It has mechanics similar to Agricola (Harvest, material processing,..) but it is a very different game, maybe even better.

Each turn you can get materials or use a building, and additionally you can buy/sell buildings and/or ships and also pay a previous loan. Buildings and ships will give you points at the end of the game. Materials will give you nothing at the end but you need them in order to build new buildings and ships, also to feed your people. Ships and some buildings will help you to feed them too.

Since you don't need to build a building to use it, you can always pay food and/or money to its owner for using it. Sometimes it is a good way to block an opponent's building because only one player can be at a building.[/color]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played three times, preliminary rating of 8 but that might go up with more plays. It feels a bit like Agricola, but different and longer, but I think both games are worth owning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

As much as I admire the design, I usually find myself seeing what other games might hit the table rather than jump into a game with four or more.

RATING: 6
This is a game I snagged in the fall 2008, played alot for the first month or so but now it just seems to be gathering dust on the shelf.  Why?  Not sure, but I think it's a bit of the Through the Ages factor, i.e., the short version of the game is way too unbalanced, but playing the longer version takes way too long, particularly if playing with a full table of 4-5 players.  Also, if you make a mistake and get behind early, the game is somewhat unforgiving.  On the positive side, though, there are multiple ways to victory, and when I did play the game more often, liked it better than Agricola.  However, I feel both LeHavre and Agricola, like Caylus, are all way overrated here on BGG.

RATING: 7.5
Lots of similarities to Agricola here but its just more fun.  Does not require such a tediously long string of actions to do anything.  Its worker-placement, but with just one worker, which is a great idea when there would be all sorts of temptations to have multiple workers.  I really like how the 'market' works with the ships bringing the basic stuff in.  On the down side, I don't like how some of the buildings work thematically - for example, how come when you smoke fish you get the smoked fish PLUS money?  Where does the money come from?  Also, when you smoke fish, how does a fish which provides one food suddenly provides TWO food after it is smoked?  Weird.

I have played this about 20 times and after the first five the fun wares thin.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rating Upgraded to a 9 after 6 plays (2/18/09). Upgraded again to a 10 after a remarkable 7th play (2/25/09).  

Le Havre embodies the joyous union of Abundance, Free Play, and Planning. The game gives you eight commodities that can be refined into more valuable resources, shipped for profit, used for construction, or burned for energy. And the stuff just piles up. You have to maintain your workforce at the end of each round, which provides just enough of a spur to keep your planning razor sharp. The game is a contest of ingenuity. It's about knowing when to lay claim to a stockpile of resources, how to turn them to advantage, and when to pause and interfere with the plans of another player. Like Glory to Rome, this is a game that pounds into the home stretch. No other game quite captures the spirit of productivity as well as Le Havre. 

Advice to prospective players/buyers: Play with three the first time. Heed this advice. Also, going in you should know that the system here is open-ended enough to confound new players. I love Le Havre, but on my first play I gave it a mystified 7 rating. I don't think I really "got it" until my fourth play.  

See my review for more details.

RATING: 7
Played Solo a few times now and the game is deserving of at least an 8.  I really want to play with more people but have concerns for length.  I think this game begs for AP more than any other game I have played before.  Looking for the most optimum play can be difficult with so many possible actions.

Update: Bummer, I played a 3 player game and it took 4 hours to play. Mind you our group is not overly AP prone and typically we play games quicker than what the game box suggests.  The game just went on and on and really left a bad taste in my mouth.  In and off itself it’s a good game, but the time to play vs payout is just too steep.  We could have played 2 four player games of Caylus in the same amount of time it took us to play 1 3 player game of Le Havre.  I don’t see us shaving much time off either.  The guys I played with caught on really quick.  I will gladly play it again, but it just doesn’t stand a chance for table time when compared to our other options.
