=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So far I've only played the basic game, so my rating is subject to change.

I'm extremely wary of the play time and try to exercise caution, as a long, drawn-out game is sure to sink Le Havre's prospects for long term play.  In general, it's easy to get people to try it, as I've taught Agricola to many people, most of whom have enjoyed it.  And in a way this game is simpler to teach.  But the game must be played quickly, as anywhere over 2 hours would simply be too much for me.  

The theme is much less compelling here than in Agricola, but it also seems like there is the potential for more strategic long-range planning.  There seems to be a nice amount of options while still forcing you to keep on your toes to meet your food needs.  So a worthy follow-up, but not yet as good as Agricola.  We'll see how it goes.

This game has the distinction of being the 900th game that I have rated here on BGG.

Agricola's coming of age. This has greater freedom, replayability, balance, strategic and tactical depth and reduced fiddliness, reading, card management and inexplicable mechanics. RATING: 9
Played twice (once shortened, once regular game).

I would recommend the shortened game for the first go around.  It gives you the general feel of the game and help you figure out possible strategies for the second game.

The regular game is longer, but is much tighter (and more interesting) at the beginning. 

I think my ratings will move up if the play time for the regular game shortens to under two hours.

RATING: 9.5
Absolutely brilliant 'heavy' eurogame. My favorite euro right now. I fell in love with it after 5 minutes of playing. It has a significant learning curve and a lot of strategies to explore. It is utterly strategic on the one side and on the other side the special buildings make every play different. And taking into account that there are 30+ special buildings in the game and only 5 are used each time, the game doesn't get boring after many plays and you always discover something new.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I had some concerns about Le Havre: the necessity of counting backwards from the end, the swinginess of the last stages, and the difficulty of gauging correct or incorrect plays. But in the end, I'm won over by the richness of the gameplay and the attention to detail found in the design and presentation. I'm only bothered a little by the wild range of usefulness among the special buildings. Playable from 1 and up, although you'll probably want 3-4 for best results.

Thrifted on 21/2 2018.

RATING: 7
2014-11-16 - Very strong 8 after two two-player games. One short, one full length.

2015-09-20 - 8->7 - It's a good game and I like to play it but it quite rarely hits the table for some reason. I think I prefer Tzolk'in or Terra Mystica when it comes to a little heavier euro game. Le Havre sometimes lasts a bit long and can be punishing when you will not take care of food in the early stage of the game which can lead to tiring play.

2015-09-28 - 7->7,5 - Quite suprisingly I played with three players today and I prefer it with 3 than with 2. It has more interesting choices and more cool buildings. However our game took 2,5 hours with quite fast players. So it is something around a maximum time limit for me and for this particular game. I would prefer if it was a little bit shorter, but it is a solid game and I like it.

2015-10-19 - 7.5->7 - Back to 7. It's just a little bit too long and it's the main reason I don't want to play it as often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I always am up for a game of Le Havre (although usually with 2-3 players). The use of one worker is very unique and even though it seems like you can't get much done with one worker, by the end of the game you're flooded with resources.

Every turn there are many options presented to you, there seems to always be an array of good options. Want a whole stack of clay? Done. Want to make your cattle into tons meat and leather? Sure!

The variable board state that depends on the order the cards come out (and the special buildings), really keeps each game different and lets players experiment with different strategies from game to game. I love seeing all the new combos of actions people chain together or use buildings in ways I never thought to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(SPK)

感想：
1. 出奇地係好易學的GAME
2. 特別建築牌的隨機抽取影響很大，因為每場GAME大約出現6張，但其能力對於場上的影響不小，要如何處理這個變數對玩家是考驗，但同時對於重口味的玩家可能認為不可取。
3. 傳統的德式，基本上沒有主題性可言。玩完的記憶中，除了有木船、鐵船、鋼船，遊輪，和越食越多飯的工人外，也就沒有其他了。
4. 網上曾經見過有網友評價說此作是設定比較花時間，但實際玩來又沒有太大感覺，可能玩家本身的收納有很大程度的影響。
5. 不過永遠記得朋友一路一路說，點解D工人要食咁多飯的！！

RATING: N/A
2,3*,4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Surprised to find myself liking this so much, as my initial impression was that it was "more" Agricola. However, the Caylus elements actually make it much heavier and often more interesting.  I particularly enjoy the interactions of upgraded goods, especially how they have so many different functions: building materials, food, trade goods, and even fuel (my favorite innovation from this game, especially how wood can be used as fuel or for building).

The luxury liners seem swingy, though, so it might take more plays to see how they actually work in games with experienced players.  I also wish that shipping played a larger role -- for instance, having another shipping card available -- for both thematic and strategic reasons.  Or maybe I was just miffed I got blocked out of the shipping center in the last few turns when I really wanted to put my fleet to use unloading unused grain and cattle.

One other minor criticism: this game took MUCH longer than expected.  I think it took us about four or five hours with three people.  That's a very long game, even for the first playthrough.

Overall, I really liked Le Havre and I think I'll be angling for a copy in the near future.  I'd love to get more plays in, although with the complexity and length I'm not sure how often I'd be able to get a group together.

RATING: 5
Update after more solo play.  The solo game doesn't provide much challenge, as there's no competition for the ships, buildings or goods.  I'm not sure I like the game enough to bring it out at my limited face to face gaming time, as there are many games that I enjoy more.  Also, setup takes a while as there are many goods and cards to place on the board.

Initial rating based on solo play.  Interesting game, I can see where having more players would be better.

I like building economic engines, and you can see that there are several combinations and paths to victory.  Not as many fussy bits and card combinations as Agricola, and I like the theme more.  My rating could go up with more multi-player games.

RATING: 9

It seems "tighter", "cleaner", more manageable, easier to get a handle on.  I like the artwork a lot better too.  After playing Agricola I was thinking about buying it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolute freedom compared to Agricola. Fluid and clever gameplay. I really like that the group's play dictates the gameplay directly. If the group is highly skilled Le Havre's buildings will be all available during midgame and it's all about scoring later on. 

Upate:
What sets Agricola apart from Le Havre is the integration of the theme. While Agricola is lovely and you really care for your farm, Le Havre is more abstract and the "caring" concept is strictly abstract as worker feeding is just a mechanic and not realized during game play.

Update:
I now love the theme and its integration. It absolutely rocks. But I highly recommend to use some boxes on the board for the ressources. It enhances the experience significantly! Otherwise there's only one small problem: cokery and steel ships are too dominating in the end game.

3/1234
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Too much, too long, lots of fiddling with the game bits.  

5 years later and I have played this again (#4 total).  I've raised my rating from 5 to 6.  It is a good game.  But not a great fit for me.

The constant attention to moving the boats and setting out the tokens gets old.

The game grows and grows.  Seeing and remembering all the options becomes more difficult as the game develops.

The focus of attention is not the game board, but the cards in front of all of the players.  I prefer a game where I can concentrate on the board, rather than searching for the information scattered across the table.

None of my criticisms are necessarily bad dings.  They are just indications why this game misses my sweet spot.

RATING: 6.5
2017-04-25
[6.5/10]
A dry optimalisation game with very few (optimal) paths to victory and non-existent theme.

I like the synergies between buildings and general complexity but hate how the worker placement mechanic was implemented. It's a strongly deficit-driven game which can lead to feeling frusrated and unfulfilled.
The hunger mechanism is also quite restrictive, narrowing possible paths to victory even further.

2017-11-23
[6.5/10]
I got really accustomed to hunger and constant deficit mechanisms playing games like Agricola. I thought that with Agricola being one of my favourites I could re-visit Le Havre and raise my rating.

Sadly my verdinct stands. In different form mind you (and passed with a much wider boardgamer perspective this time around), but my inability to like this game hasn't changed much.

Reiterating:
+ Lots of choices, each game can be different. A true euro-sandbox.
- A dry optimalisation with overabundance of options.
- The most chaotic and paralysis prone game I own. Having 25+ buildings spread in different orientation around the table doesn't help.

To sum up - my brain doesn't seem to work well with Le Havre. My scores are just below average which I consider bad. Even a 2 year break doesn't justify this.
Perhaps I'm just not smart enough and this is what frustrates me, but I tend to score quite high in other medium-heavy games, so it's not the best line of defense for Le Havre.

Maybe in 2 more years...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only played with three players.  Definitely takes a long time, but the game has many decisions, and every decision is important.  I like that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Lots of tension, difficult choices, and multiple options make this follow up to Agicola a big success for me. Some randomness is injected via Special Buildings and the order of the Standard Buildings, but mostly a perfect information game that plays great with 2, 3 and 4 (I think 5 is too many). I like the progression from food consumption being the focus in the early game moving mid way through the game to a vp focus and a big finish. Although each round is set up with small incremental turns (with 4 players, every 4th round you only get 1 action), there are several good options for long term strategy. Can be long (especially for 4) but if each action can be cut to around 1 min each, it does not wear out its welcome.

Le Grand Hameau
Essen Promo Cards

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[size=12][b]Top 100 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Le Havre:[/b][/size]
+ I like how the fishing theme integrates with a few of the mechanics to make the game more intuitive.
+ The game has high replayability with the variable normal card deck set-up and the special building's deck.
+ The game allows for meaningful decisions.
+ The game is easier to teach than most games with a similar weight due to the limited number of decisions a player can make on their turn. In other words, I coped with the complexity of the game. I have also taught this game to a non-gamer and they did alright. 
+ There is little downtime between turns in a two player game. The "feed your people" phase at the end of each round also keeps things interesting over the games long duration. I have hence made an exception for the duration. 

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Le Havre:[/b][/size]
/ The game board is a bit small so fitting the goods tokens on their allocated space is somewhat difficult. I instead placing paper cupcake holders on the resource spots and storing the appropriate resources inside. 
/ The game is missing player boards. Somebody on BGG, fortunately, addressed this issue. 
/ I am concerned that the strategies for the game will get repetitive after a lot of plays. 

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Keep & Usually willing to play this game[/size]

Very good game but trouble getting to play it. It is easier than Agricola in the sense that it's more of an open environment. The "harvest" pressure is much less. At the same time, the openess makes it harder to learn and figure out what to do so new players can be overwhelmed quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Resource management at its best. Lots of resource gathering, lots of interaction, lots of buying things. Place a worker piece on a building to use its ability or gather resources from a central pool. Taking a specific resource denies others of that resource. Resources are used to convert into victory points, buy buildings (which provide victory points and further abilities) or feeding your people. The only downside of the game is that towards the end there is a lot of counting required in order to find the best way to accumulate the maximum victory points, but some people like that in a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In Le Havre, a player’s turn consists of two parts: First, distribute newly supplied goods onto the offer spaces; then take an action. As an action, players may choose either to take all goods of one type from an offer space or to use one of the available buildings. Building actions allow players to upgrade goods, sell them or use them to build their own buildings and ships. Buildings are both an investment opportunity and a revenue stream, as players must pay an entry fee to use buildings that they do not own. Ships, on the other hand, are primarily used to provide the food that is needed to feed the workers.

RATING: 6
Playing the full game made for a very long game.  Most of the time, the time seemed to fly by fairly quickly.  You are basically trying to be the highest valued merchant by either constructing (or buying) buildings (although buying a building is generally not the most cost efficient method and often may be a waste) or shipping goods out via the shipping line which is also dependent on the number of ships and their capacity.  While you are seeking to gather resources to build these buildings, you also must harvest enough food to feed your company AND acquire enough energy to power the higher level buildings.  For those prone to AI, the vast number of options as the game deepens in the later rounds may cause this game to last even longer.  After a couple plays, this game is continuing to grow on me and I've upped it from a 7 to 8 to 9.  I really like it as a two player game as well.

Vitrine (grande étagère)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We have been huge fans of [thing=31260][/thing] and [thing=39683][/thing].  In fact, Agricola is one of our favorite games and we've gotten in over a hundred plays.  Despite that, we had avoided getting [thing=35677][/thing] for a while since we were intimidated by its increased complexity and game length.  Still, after a long time of trying many light-to-medium weight games, my wife said she wanted something more "meaty" instead.  Luckily, we ended up finally getting a copy from our Secret Santa.  Thanks Secret Santa!

We gave it a spin and we immediately enjoyed it.  We were wrong to wait so long to try it!  Each turn is fairly simple---add some more resources and then either take resources or use a building action.  However, the sheer number of resources makes the game interesting.  There are building resources, energy resources, food resources, with many of the resources having values in all of the above, and they can all be upgraded.  Building actions give you special abilities.  There are a lot of interacting factors involved.  Unlike Agricola, where you feel like you're barely making out until the very end, Le Havre lets you cut loose.  By the middle of the game, you should have a decent engine going and then it's time to prime it and let it run.  What Le Havre loses in tension from Agricola it makes up for in possibilities.  What's so addictive is that it feels like there are many different paths to victory that you can try out---do you try for lots of ships?  Ship lots of goods?  Build a lot of buildings?  Perhaps some strategies will become more obvious with more plays, but for now we're enjoying playing in the sandlot

At first, we were afraid that Le Havre would lack the variety of Agricola with its Improvement and Occupation cards, but that doesn't seem to be a problem.  The semi-random order of the buildings as well as the resources can subtly bend each game and make the outcome surprisingly different.  Even things like the special buildings can dramatically change your strategy.  We haven't felt like having this much to explore in a game in a long time.

At this point, I think we can say that we're huge fans of Uwe Rosenberg's games.  For some reason, his style really resonates with us.  All of the games work very well for two players, so they're all games that we will enjoy for a while.  Agricola scratches the "tense" itch, while Le Havre scratches the "possibilities" itch.  Both are great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I wasn't able to stop thinking about this game ever since I played it at BGG Con Spring.  It was my most memorable play. So I bought it of course.

I love this game.  The funnest thing about it is that you feel like you're picking, each turn, between many good--and several great--options.  The game progresses with you being able to do more and more with a single turn.  I also like that each turn you are just picking one thing--it feels much simpler that way.

Love the replayability straight out of the box with all the special buildings, and how the standard buildings will also never come out the same way twice, which means the whole landscape of the economy will be different every game.

The round cards seem a bit ridiculous...would have been way simpler to have one double-sided card for each of the player counts, and that card tells you on each round what comes out, and the ships are separate cards.  Granted, their method used as few cards as possible to get the desired result which is kind of neat...but ultimately feels like a needless complication in learning the game.  Works great once you understand it so this is a quibble only.

Personally I like the art, although it's no Laukat game.  The art is kind of simple; uses straight black lines filled in with solid pastel colors, and the buildings are drawn at not quite a bird's eye view but at an angle. 

The handling of loans is interesting.  I won a game after taking out lots of loans.  Counter-intuitive.  Now I see why they don't allow you to take out a loan unless the game requires you to pay and you can't...seems a little weird that the best course of action could be to purposefully not feed your people so that you have to take out a loan so that you have extra money so that you can buy the thing that you otherwise couldn't have bought because you can't just take out a loan when you want to.  Very weird indeed.  Another quibble.

RATING: 10
This game never ceases to be fun.  I've played it at least 90-100 times by now, and that's saying something for a 2.5/3.0 hour game [edit: games take more like 2 hours these days].  Somehow manages to feel fresh every time, always a new opportunity, a new combination of available resources and buildings, something new to try.  Unlike many other games, there is a wealth of GOOD choices to make on a turn.  Very often you have to decide between making three excellent moves.  Have played almost exclusively with two players, playing with three feels like a different (and exciting) game entirely.

RATING: 10
I'm going to hate this game.

I'll hate it so much that I'll buy the German edition so I can play it before an English release. I might even hate it so much that I do full color paste-ups.

I KNOW I will hate it enough to buy the English edition as well.

Update:

It's Agricola's cousin Sally; the HOT cousin. She likes you, and you'l love her right back.

The actions are buildings, and while there are some centralized actions, the majority are spread between the players as they "build" them. It can be a bit tougher to know what your options are at a glance, but there are MORE options, MORE synergy, and MORE avenues to victory. There are also more bits in this one than Agricola.

Play time is relatively the same, though I think the learning curve longer.

Update Update:

Ewe is 2 for 2. Amazing. Fantastic, multipathed system. I'm enjoying this one just as much as Agricola.

RATING: 10
What is it about Le Havre?  The game simply casts a spell over me.  It's weird... it's not like I care about the theme.  The art is good/cute, but nothing special.  It doesn't look especially pretty sitting on the table, with its messy piles of chits.  It's not even like I especially care about resource management as a mechanic or style of play.  The play itself tends to feel a little repetitive, though I haven't yet played so many games to render that conclusion.  And yet strategically, the game spreads out in all directions; its breadth is marvelous.  And because of that, there's always a good direction to go.  The pace can be slack sometimes, but it just hits the sweet spot in terms of how far I like/need to plan ahead.  This game makes me swoon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another Uwe gem.  Resources accumulate each round at the harbor and on your turn you can take resources or place your one worker on one of the buildings.  You also freely buy buildings if you have the money.  At the end of each round you need to feed your workers and it goes up steadily throughout the game.  You can mitigate this by buying ships.  

Many different ways to win with different industries, shipping, special cards.  I really like all game Uwe so this is a must own game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]Le Havre[/i] was supposed to be a solid winner given the success of [i]Agricola[/i], but it very nearly turned into a big disappointment. In our first game (just the two of us), my wife hated it. And I mean "hated". She said popping bubble wrap was more enjoyable. Fortunately I convinced her to try it with one of the other couples in our group and she enjoyed it more as a four player game, but I still think she enjoyed organizing the bead box we got for it more than she does playing it. For me, [i]Le Havre[/i] has topped [i]Agricola[/i]. [i]Agricola[/i] is about getting a food engine working and then getting a little of everything, [i]Le Havre[/i] is about getting a food engine going and then specializing in something. Finding that something is the interesting part.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is not agricola - it feels very different.  While it shares some elements, it is not the same.

There are many possibilities to get buildings and ships that interact with one another, with no one clear path for which to compete.  

You need a mix of points from buildings and points from shipping, or goods that produce $ with special buildings (6 random are selected, so will vary each game).

I am interested in playing this more to explore those strategies (or see what others might come up with...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Include Le Grand Hameau expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Agricola is definitely worth buying first.

Seems like a heavier AGRICOLA (which is already a heavier PUERTO RICO). I don't have the group of dedicated gamers necessary to engage this game with any regularity worth purchasing. 

TV says that this plays great as a 2 player game. One of his favorites. 

Seems to be a longer game than AGRICOLA.

Vs. Agricola as a solo game: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/470218/le-havre-or-agricola-better-solo-game
Vs. Agricola in game length: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/508744/game-length-and-comparison-to-agricola-and-pr

BOTTOM LINE: Get through PR and Notre Dame first. THEN try Agricola. THEN perhaps try this. NB: We still need to play more Stone Age.

One review on Amazon said: "Feeding your people is a tremendous upkeep cost. The way the game is balanced, you must spend about half of your actions feeding your people. That means that on some turns, all you are doing is placing workers to get food so you don't incur the punishments for not feeding your people. This aspect of the game is entirely too tedious. There are plenty of other worker placement games that do not have such a ridiculous upkeep. Take "Pillars of the Earth" or "Kingsburg". Neither of them has an upkeep cost like Le Havre. If the food upkeep in Le Havre is such a wonderful idea, would Kingsburg or Pillars of the Earth be better if a food upkeep cost was added to these games in aa future expansion? I think not."

I did read somewhere that this game could be played fairly quickly with 2 players. Perhaps as quickly as the 2 player Le Havre Inland Port. 

This may be with trying!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
+Puertico Rico on steroïds.
.A building and shipping game in its core, it has very deep strategies and no luck. If you didn't like Agricola only because of the randomness the cards added, this is the game for you.
.It's an  upgrade from Puerto Rico because you can not only build but also sell buildings. The economic chain is much more worked out. Every game is different because of the unique mix of the 3 proposal building stacks who differs every game. The ability of taking loans is very challenging ; how many loans can you afford ?
.steep learning curve ; you must have a good understanding of every building.
.best playable with 3.

- 
game is very long with  4 players. 
with 5 gamers the strategical scope diminishes (only tactical decisions) and game is too long.
less variability in strategical decisions in comparison with agricola but far more possibilities when you compare with puerto rico

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Awesome game; one of my favorites.  Have only played in iOS but playing it on my iPAD has made me want to purchase the actual game.  What is brilliant about this game is the player turns are SO simple - on your turn you either pick an available resource, or you build or buy something. That's it.  But yet the strategy is enormous, and more and more of it gets revealed the more you play it.  You may thing there's not much to it, but the REALLY is. There's also the Agricola/Stone Age-type tension involved where you have to feed your family while building things so it requires a delicate balance of growing and maintaining.  
Cool theme too, it just works.

RATING: 7
This game is fun, but I lowered my opinion of it for a while when Uwe Rosenberg geek-mailed everyone who rated it a "10" asking for votes in some German game competition. (And since I like it much better than Agricola, I felt compelled to lower that too. I never felt compelled to raise Agricola back up again.) I like Le Havre much better than Agricola. The rules are a bit difficult to decipher, but well worth the effort. Once you learn it, it takes about 3 hours for a four player (long) game, but turns are quick and it's actually fun. The short game isn't worth playing, because you don't get time to develop a strategy. Finding players for the long game became too difficult.

RATING: 3.7
I just don't see the joy in these Eurogames that all have the same damn mechanics that feel limiting for the duration of the game. Each of these games (Puerto Rico, Agricola) all have the same feel, almost the same damn mechanics and all leave you feeling frustrated and unsatisfied even if you win. These games presume to be more than they are, more in depth, but they are simply constricted decision making. If there were a little more resolution of action, strategy, decision-making in these games, then they'd live up to their hype.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
+  Essen Promos
+  Tablet

[q]- Solo game: Marketplace max. 4 goods
- Coal Trader: limitation to max. 5 times
- Construction Site: you can't choose Dunny or Football Stadium [/q]

[q]
Full solo game:

- start resources: 5 francs, 1 coal

- supply resources: 2 francs, 2 fish, 2 wood, 1 clay, 0 iron, 0 grain, 0 cattle

- starting buildings (town): B1, B2, B3

- other buildings: 1, 3, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20, 22, 23, 25

- special buildings: 6 randomly chosen

- ships/turn cards: S1, S4, S10, S13, S14, S16, S20


Short solo game:

- start resources: 5 francs, 2 fish, 2 wood, 2 clay, 2 iron, 1 cattle, 2 coal, 2 hides

- supply resources: 3 francs, 3 fish, 3 wood, 2 clay, 1 iron, 1 grain, 1 cattle

- starting buildings (town): B1, B2, B3, 1, 2, 13

- other buildings: 3, 5, 8, 9, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20, 22, 23

- special buildings: no special buildings

- ships/turn cards: S4, S13, S16, S20

- ships: 1 wooden ship on the plan (S2) and 1 wooden ship already built by the player (S3)[/q]

RATING: 8
Fun euro.  Lots of options at any given point, though it doesn't seem as completely overwhelming as O&L (although it is close).  Enjoy this much more than O&L; I don't think either will come close to topping Agricola.

The long game can drag out at the end.  The short game is actually nicer, because it doesn't drag out, plus the beginning is faster because you start with more resources.  We now just add some special buildings into the short game--the best of both worlds!

Have played with 1, 2, and 3.  

[I]*Own Le Grand Hameau expansion.[/I]

RATING: 9.5
I wish the food requirements weren't quite so harsh, but at the same time, I wonder if that isn't part of what makes this game so great. You have to be thinking about the end as soon as you begin, and there's always more you want to do than you can possibly complete. I've heard that the game is scripted because you have to ship to win, but that's not true. Building an engine of buildings and exploiting them is a viable winning strategy.

(Also own Le Havre: Le Grand Hameau.)

RATING: 8
Played two "short" games so far.  Both came in at over four hours with 3 experienced gamers.  I get the feeling that there is an optimal path through this game and that removes the sense of lots of different strategies for me.  And at four hours a game it's difficult to get excited about playing because if somebody has figured the optimal route then the weaker players have no chance. Having said that, I did enjoy the two games and would definitely play again, time allowing.

RATING: 8
A great eurogame, maybe a step better than Agricola.
The turn structure is fixed but each turn you'll have to make hard choices on what to do: harvest goods, use a building or build a building or a ship.
I like the way the goods can have several uses: money, food, energy, construction, wealth...
I've seen on pictures that the cardboad version uses a lot of space; I have the iOS version and it's perfect.

Read my review here: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1141716/review-of-le-havre

RATING: 8
Played a couple of times vs my girlfriend, never with more than 2 players. A fun and easy to learn game. It lacks different kinds of actions in my opinion. For example in Agricola you can sow, plow, build fences, stables, rooms etc. In this game all you do is collect resources and either turn them into something else or build boats or buildings.

Simple but fun! I'd like to try out a 3-player game some day, I'm sure it'll get more competitive that way.

RATING: 9
I _LOVE_ this for 2 or 3 players.  I have not played with 4 or 5 but I don't think my typical group will enjoy it as much due to the greater time between plays and fewer plays per round.  Being able to take loans and pay them back (vs Agricola beggar cards) and the food-for-money exchange enables less of the "how am I going to feed" scare and more room for strategy in my opinion.

Possibly a little long for some people, but as we've played more it has gotten to moving along quite quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Delightful economic puzzle. While there are a lot of moving parts, it isn't really a complicated game - collect resources to turn into other resources to buy buildings which produce other resources, etc. 

It has the perfect amount of interaction for a Euro - there's quite a bit of blocking and taking something lucrative before someone else, but there isn't the outright screwage which makes deep planning futile.

Also, while the puzzle is theoretically the same in every game, how other players take things and which building cards happen to come up make each game completely different. Definitely one you'll be thinking about after you play, which I can't say about many games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
1 - 5 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is bit heavier (ughh, but yes.. really) and bit less replayable than Agricola (only couple of randomized cards per game), but is worth the effort and looks as great. The theme is pretty immersive, and surprisingly enjoyable. Sure, farming is more obvious and interesting, but managing shipyards is kinda cool too, especially with this kind of artwork. It's not a cube pusher. I don't want to play often, but when I do I enjoy it.

2-Player Comment:
* Like most Uwe games, Le Havre is great with two.

Expansions:
+Essen promo cards
+Le Grand Hameau expansion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Egy nagyon igényesen kivitelezett magyarított verziót volt szerencsém kipróbálni, ennek ellenére maga a játék az utóbbi idők legrosszabb játékélményét nyújtotta. Első (rövidített szabályok szerint játszott) játék, tehát nyilván nem vágtam a helyes stratégiát. Nem vettem hajót a játék elején, csak épületeket, bízva benne, hogy azt majd kajáért/pénzért használják a többiek + én ingyen használhatom őket + a játék végén pontot hoznak. Ezután kb. a játék közepétől arról szólt minden köröm, hogy a körönkénti nyavalyás 2 akciómból (3 fős játék) valahogy kihozzam az egyre magasabb értékű kör végi kajáltatást. Az utolsó 2 körben ez minden igyekezetem ellenére nem sikerült, fel kellett vennem egy halom kölcsönt, ami hozott 35 mínusz pontot a játék végén... Ebből az jött le nekem, hogy a játék első felében nagyrészt fix a stratégia, muszáj hajót venni, enélkül kilátástalan az ember helyzete. Mondhat bárki bármit, ha egy játékban az elején ilyen szinten be lehet ragadni, akkor az nem egy jól megtervezett játék. Ha nincs B terv, amivel ki lehet kecmeregni a rossz pozícióból, akkor az nem játék (= szórakozás), hanem szenvedés; lásd a Catant, ahol a kezdeti pozíciók elfoglalása a kulcs, ha ezt elcseszi az ember és a dobások sem jönnek ki jól, akkor nincs B terv, csak min. 1,5 óra bosszúság és szenvedés. Még mindíg nem találtam a Stone Age-nél szórakoztatóbb és jobb worker placement játékot.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After one play, it seems that getting coal, converting it to coke, then selling is the best play. But, once everyone knows this it can likely be slowed down or blocked, making the fight for other sources of points in the interim more important. My gut feel is that this is likely best with three. Eager to play again.

In our second play, the coal producing building, coal-to-coke converter and shipping line all came out late. This changed the game such that constructing buildings was a stronger strategy as well as using a special building that converted an iron and three meat to 16 (or maybe it was 18) bucks.

It appears that between the varied special buildings and the order of appearance of the standard buildings there will be plenty of variability from game to game, even if certain strategies are generally best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
01/16/10 Played a three-player "short" game. Enjoyable overall, but having to worry about food 80% of the time is a drag. What I don't get theme-wise is what this increased demand per turn represents, as we have no "workers" per se. If we did, and we gradually got more, I could understand the steady increase of this food tax. As it is, it seems to be an artificial constraint to keep players from spending all their resources/time on constructing buildings.
It seemed many of the buildings didn't surface in a three-player game. That put more constraints on us. I see this game is rated best with three. So I wonder about that.
10/03/10 Played another three-player "short" game. A very different affair, as we built all the available buildings. 05/01/11 Another three-player "short" game. 09/17/11 Ditto. 11/17/12 Ditto. 02/26/13 Ditto. Strangely this outing all buildings were built by the end of turn ten, making the last two turns quite anticlimactic. 12/12/15 Played another three-player "short" game (#6). I have still not played the long game. And I'm not sure I want to, as I find two hours of the short game plenty.

RATING: 7.5
A far, far, far better game than Agricola.  In fact, what Agricola should have been in the first place.  The cards and the actions are the same for everybody, it's just a matter of which order you will execute yours.

It's also a more calculatory game, so if it's not your cup of tea, stay away.

I found the interactions between the players to be quite strategic and very decisive in the game.  The cards offer a variety not equaled in Agricola too.

All in all, a very involving game with tons of choices....difficult choices.  

After playing this, I see Agricola going down in my ratings.  It's still more beginner friendly in the family version flavor than Le Havre though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Heavier on the brain than Agricola, but less fun: to me it's a bit more multiplayer solitaire, since you're more busy working out how to get to all the possible goals than in Agricola.

But it has some of the same pros as Agricola: Nice buildup of tension through each round, planning stuff and the need to constantly adapt, etc.

So far I have played Le Havre 6 times in almost 6 years. Agricola got on the table 37 times in those years. Says enough.

Still a nice game, but there are so many better games out there that I wonder why this is rated so high.

NL: Pittiger spel dan Agricola van dezelfde maker. Ondanks een aantal vergelijkbare spelprincipes toch een totaal ander spel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The reviews for this game have been very good on the Geek, but it really doesn't appeal to me.  I'll probably revisit this score as we play it more, but for now, I feel like I'm playing mechanics, rather than a game.  Since anyone can use a building regardless of who built it, I feel like the entire game simply involves buying victory points based on an arbitrary selection of goods and acquiring food for an increasing number of invisible workers.  This just doesn't represent compelling gameplay for me.  I also feel that it's too long; I usually get bored about 80% of the way through the game, and I'm just happy for it to end.  The short game is much better in this respect, but I feel it changes the overall feel of the game since you start with far more resources and food seems to be less important.  Perhaps I just need to play it more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the ultimate economic engine game.  There's a ton of variability from game to game, a plethora of viable strategies and even though careful planning is well-rewarded it somehow doesn't drag A/P wise as much as one would expect.  

I really like the tactical play in this one too.  You can play on other players buildings for a small fee (near the end of the game the options are endless).  Unlike other engine games the tactical play and flexibility allows for a mid-game comeback.  So you're not stuck half-way through with a crappy engine knowing that the stronger players are just getting stronger and will eventually defeat you.  

A brainy exercise for sure and certainly not for everyone.  The toughest thing about the first play is figuring out how to feed yourself without wasting too many actions.  Once you figure that out the rest of the game opens up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

***** UPDATE AUG 2009 *****

I continue to enjoy this.  Not sure that I fully grasp (or like?) the loan aspect.  I think paying 1 interest for every 2 loans (rounded up) might work to prevent a massive loan outtake.

I really want to play 3 player.

***** UPDATE OCT 2009 *****

I still enjoy this, but think it is going to settle into the 8-9 range.  2-3 players is still a really good game that I will enjoy from time-to-time, but I believe that this will fall short of "Brett's Hall of Fame".  I still do not really like way loans work and think that there should be a bit more of an interest factor.  I also think that the way scoring really ramps up in the latter rounds is annoying to me, but that is probably just me.  Keep in mind that these are really minor nitpicks and I do like Le Havre and encourage everyone to give it a go.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Played two shortened games and two long games.  This game is very similar to Agricola in that players compete to collect resources, which are then converted (by buildings) into better resources, which are then used to get victory points (which are actually just straight money) through a variety of mechanisms.  But, as always, there's conflict: only one player can use a building at a time, and there's a limited number of items you can purchase with resources that get you victory points, leading to much competition.  

This is a long, involved game that gets its fangs into you.  I thoroughly enjoyed all the games, though it's clear that the game takes multiple plays to really get a feel for.  

There are tons of things to balance on each turn: you need to acquire resources, you need to get food (which is either resources or modified resources), you need to use buildings to modify resources, you need to use buildings to buy things (other buildings or ships), and you need to watch what everyone else is doing.  And you only get one action each turn.  

One thing I love about the game is that it's entirely balanced play-wise: players start with the same resources, there are no rule-breaking cards people can obtain that only apply to them, and anyone can use any building, even if it was built by another player.  Yet there is enough variability to make the game worth replaying: the game changes greatly with the number of players (as the number of actions each player will get changes), the order the buildings come out in is somewhat randomized, and the order the resources come out in is randomized.  

And even things like running out of food isn't _too_ painful, as players can take out "loans" which can be repaid without much monetary penalty (or even forgiven, if the right building is out).  The game does have its unforgiving elements, though; as with Agricola if a player doesn't get a food-engine up and running, they'll be in a downward spiral by the end of the game.  

I started by playing two of the "short" games; in these games the food required at the end of each turn ramped up extremely quickly, and thus the game felt like a frantic rush to get food (which didn't let players have enough time to use most of the buildings or get the high-point-value items).  

The long game is a VERY different game, and I think it's _far_ superior.  Players start out with far fewer resources than in the short game, and the food requirements ramp up slower (so its easier to get a food engine up).  The long game lets players develop a variety of strategies, and the game progresses beautifully (and has distinct beginning, middle, and end phases).  

I can't wait to play more!

I originally gave this an 8.25, then a 9, and it's now a 9.25, with the only consideration that it's a long game (3 hours for a 3 or a 5 player long game) and thus can only be broken out when there's enough time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Does not replace Agricola and Agricola does not make le Havre obsolete.

In Le Havre you can buy the available action spots (the buildings) or build/buy new ones.

It is a bit frustating to learn: at the start it is hard to estimate the relative value of a recourse or to know what building is a good one to build/buy and after a few rounds you loose the complete overview especially in a 4 player game with a lot of buildings all over the place in my case. I think it is better to learn the game with 2 players just because of the simple fact that there are less buildings in play. Besides that a first play that takes 3 hours and 20 min of pure playing time is a bit too much :).

To fully enjoy this you need to know at least all the private buildings.

BUT I am going to play this again: the mechanics are cool, it looks nice and I like the positive interaction: come to my awesome building, just pay me some food and use it!

Played it now three times: my brain still hurts

RATING: 8
Agricola-alapokon nyugvó termelős-gazdálkodós-erőforrás menedzsmentes, olykor agyégetős (de még épphogy nem nagyon), klasszikus euro.

Akinek az Agricola tetszett, ebben sem fog csalódni, akinek nem, az meg inkább hagyja ezt is. Nem hiába Rosenberg tervezte mindkettőt.

RATING: 10
SOLO CAPABLE

150 Min.

Agricola meets Caylus. I've only played solo and I think I like it better than Agricola, which is saying a lot.

Update: WOW!!!! If there is a better economic game (for me) I'm not aware of it. Given the play time to fun ratio, presently, I would actually rather play Le Havre solitaire than most other games multi-player. Okay, maybe that's an exaggeration... but... just... wow.

One of the things I love about Le Havre that I wasn't expecting - just the cool tactile nature of those little tiles. It works on a visceral level - your little stacks of resources - it absolutely adds to the enjoyment in a way that Agricola doesn't really do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Played today at RinCon... four hours of my life I will never get back. I am really disappointed because after the 'Gric, I had high hopes for this one, but in the end it did not deliver. Convoluted rules, marred further by the horrendous grammar in the rulebook, a mish-mash of game mechanics (think Gric + Caylus) that made things more complicated, less intuitive, and more tedious, and decisions that just failed to ever feel meaningful. I had a hard time giving a crap about anything I myself, or any of my opponents did, and in the end, I just felt like the whole experience was a drag. Collect some tokens, turn the tokens over, turn the tokens in, collect some more tokens, rinse repeat. Hey look, I have some more tokens. Hey look, I am trading in more tokens for other tokens. Hey look, I am trading in those tokens. Yup here I go collecting more tokens. At its heart, that is Le Havre. A pointless exercise in token manipulation and wood fondling. I hate this game so much that I want to punch it in the face.

Amusingly enough. Today (6/1/09) I received this email from the designer, Uwe Rosenberg:

[q]Hi Matthew!
Thank you for you criticism. I think we have to control Melissa.
Best wishes, Uwe [/q]

Which makes me feel bad about the strong language I used above. Still, I don't disagree with it. 

I will say this: I think Uwe is definitely one of my favorite Euro game designers - Bohnanza gets a TON of play around here, and I really enjoy Agricola. If you want to play a great game, check out one of those.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like Agricola, I never thought I would play this as it seemed fiddly, economic, and thick. Having enjoyed Agricola so much, I gave this a try and I'm very glad I did. I've only played it with 2 and I think that may be the ideal venue. Le Havre is engrossing, fast-moving, and interesting  from start to finish. The game kind of takes off on you. I like games when I still feel like a beginner after a dozen or so plays, knowing that there are multiple paths to victory yet to be discovered. It is just a tad long so I don't often have the time to play, but if I have a free 2 hours and want a deep game, this is it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Really didn't like this at first, but iOS implementation is growing on me. It addresses some of Agricola's shortcomings: variability is in the buildings available to all rather than individual hands of cards, and it seems possible to focus rather than being forced to do a little of everything every time. The buildings system here is similar enough to Caylus that I pretty much don't see ever playing the latter again, though it's annoying that the Special Buildings are randomly revealed through out the game. In addition, I'm not sure this is anymore "strategic" than Agricola, as you can't really plan much till the goods are revealed, and even then you have to react to the random buildings and choices of other players, it seems more a game of mid-range tactics, putting together mini-plans you hope to pull off over a few rounds. It's quick on iOS (25 minutes for short game, 45 for long), where it's a pleasant puzzler to pass the time, but I'm pretty sure I'd need my arm twisted to play this for 2.5 hours face-to-face.

RATING: 9.7
I love Le Havre with 2-3 players.  It's easy to teach and has deep, engaging strategic and tactical gameplay. It is tight and interactive throughout and it feels more open-ended than Agricola or Macao (the other 2 games I've rated above 9).  If you get small square storage cups for the resource bits, the game is easy to setup and not at all fiddly.  The only downside is that I don't like it with more than 3 players.

RATING: 9
My first experience with this game was a five player game that seemed to last forever. I didn't like the long play time and I didn't like how player's tokens could remain on a building for multiple turns to block other players from using that building.

Fortunately, I played that game again with three players and had a great time with it.  My daughter and son-in-law love this game.  The three of us played it over and over to the point we had to take a break from it.

Prior to playing this game we were playing Agricola over and over.  So we went from obsessing about one Uwe Rosenberg game to another.  Agricola is more family friendly while Le Havre seems a bit more strategic.

RATING: 10
My favourite Rosenberg design has players strategically grabbing resources from the dock to allow them to purchase buildings, and using each others buildings to further their goals, locking others out until you decide to relinquish that spot. It's smooth and challenging, exciting and well paced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A brilliant game that is just heavy enough without feeling like there is too much micromanagement. Blends the good bits of games such as Caylus plus, Roads and Boats and Agricola.  

A few tiny nits I have against against Le Havre:
- it becomes progressively more difficult during the game to see who has what building in play, although this problem does reduce with familiarity with the standard building card set;
- downtime is an issue if players (like me) are a bit prone to analysis paralysis, and the effect is cumulative with each such player (this is the main reason that I can't give a 10 rating); 
- the game length is long at around 150min+ for 3 players with 4+ players pushing this out to 180+ minutes; 
- its tough on newbs. The strategies and tactics for successful play won't become evident until about the third or fourth play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a 3 player game (i have yet to play other versions) this plays extremely well. The action is quick and there is plenty to think about.
Despite the obvious comparison with Agricola, I much prefer this game as it removes the uneven random element of the Agricola cards which can unbalance the game.
Recommended.

RATING: 9
A real masterpiece. Le Havre is deep and thinky with remarkably simple rules and mechanics. The variability with the cards, player counts, and the long and short versions of gameplay provide a ton of range for the game. The player count can change the overall feel of each session. The short version is great for a quicker experience and really helps to learn the game. It allows people to play a more casual, quicker game when starting, but expands into something incredibly deeper in the full version.

RATING: 9
A very nice surprise. Best game from Essen so far.
I was afraide that it was another Agricola, but no. Much better game than its successor. An intelligent application of Caylus style with one or two innovate mechanics. 
I like Agricola, I think it is a great game, but this one is more difficult, more challenging and without all the luck gap between players in the beginning of the game.
This one is for sure a gamers game.

1) I had play it twice and enjoy it a lot. 

First time play with 5 players (two of them with a lot of AP) 3h30

2) 2nd play - 4 players - less than 2h30.
It plays best with 4 players.


3) 3rd & 4th play - solo Play - 45 to 60 minutes for game.

4)Really love this game. It became one of mine top 10.

5) After a 2 players short game: I prefer the full game but this one was enough to take my rating to a 9.

This one took 60 minutes long with explanation.

6) A 3 player full game. This game is awessome.
full play - 2h30 hours with one first timer.

7) Solo play max score - 313 points

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Well I think Le Havre has done it. It's surpassed Agricola and Dominion to become my absolute favorite game.

My god, the fun you can have with all those different resources! It takes the best parts from Agricola, and the only part from Caylus that I liked (owning buildings that others can pay you to use) and combined them into an absolute masterpiece! I am so excited to play this over and over again.

It's flaws - a bit too long, not for me, but for people who I'm trying to teach it to. Going along with that, everyone I've shown it to so far either doesn't like it at all, or seems to like it a little, but prefers Agricola. My theory is that if they played another game or two, they'd see that this is the clearly superior game, but at it's length, I'm not sure that some of them will give it another try. Still, a definite 10. Beautiful game!

UPDATE: Hmm... not as replayable as I thought it would be? I still love it, but it just doesn't belong with my other 10s anymore!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
Very absorbing, many possible strategies but hard to feel in control of the game due to difficult choices. Love it.

Important to try to get cash early, to buy buildings and ships with. Remember you can sell buildings too. Buying a building (rather than building it) means you can be first to use it. You want 3 ships by mid-late game if possible.

This game just keeps getting better, with any player number.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating could change, but at 3-player count, this is the most satisfying of all of the Uwe games that I have played.  Produces that classic "4 things you need to do, you can do 1 of them" feeling; the resource accumulation mechanic is soo organic; the pacing out of turns (2-2-3) on top of the ratcheting up of individual rounds (b/c of the food issue) provides wonderful crunch; minimal icon-learning and ultimately a very simple ruleset... Needs players who are into engines and resource conversion, but man, what a design!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In La Havre, France, one is accumulating goods and livestock to earn Francs. There are a fixed number of rounds, and 7 turns per round. (In a three player game, there are 18 rounds). On a player's turn, they either collect goods, build, or go into a building to take that action. Optionally, they may purchase buidings, if they wish to do so. Buildings are seeded in three columns, and you can only buy the lowest numbered building in a column first, before being able to get at the rest of the buildings. At the end of each round, one has to pay food or Francs, and there may be a harvest where players may gain a maximum of one grain (from one grain) and one cattle (from two cattle). Food requirements can be reduced by owning ships.

Like Caylus, if you use someone else's building you have to pay them a fee. A small number of special buildings are randomly mixed in to make each game different. 

The mechanics are simple, and the game is very tense. It's a good game, with lots of choices on how to optimize your economy. Near the end, everyone wants to get the same goods or the same action, so it gets tricky trying to do everything you want.   I am fully engaged each time I play.  

There is only one drawback, though. If you want to play succesfully, you must use loans. In fact, loans are overpowered, and the designer has given a house rule to make attempt to balance the loans: you pay 2 francs if you have X or more loans, where X is the number of players in the game. I'm surprised there hasn't been much discussion about loans at all. Sure, you can argue that everyone takes loans, but that takes away one option of trying to play the game without loans. I haven't played this game as often as I like, but knowing that loans are the only way to go has slightly turned me off.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Only one play, and only the shortened game. But it's safe to say I'm addicted.

God this is a tough game. Mechanically simple, but it's advanced yoga for the brain!

RATING: 5
If nothing else a good reminder that love cannot be planned in advance and is not decided by tick-boxes on a piece of paper. In theory, Le Havre has everything I most love and look for in games: economic theme, strong production element, resource management, card driven. I love Agricola and Power Grid both games you hear in connection to Le Havre. But the fact remains I dislike Le Havre-immensly. It is too fiddly, an element I dislike a lot but can forgive if other elements are in place, it is looong - which is fine if it would be more strategic and less tactical, but it is not: it is very tactics-driven which feels put of place with the theme. I hate how you have little visual oversight of your opponents cards, I don't want to memorize all cards, esp. in a game that feels like pulling teeth.

RATING: 8
Superb resource management game. It offers many different paths to victory. Really exciting and fun to play. It takes the best of Caylus and Agricola, bettering both of them. It manages to be original even using known mechanics.

A masterpiece. 

UPDATE 7th Nov 2012
I still consider it a wonderful game, but I moved down the rating to 9 because I like more "Ora et labora" that gives a similar experience, but which I like much more.

UPDATE October 2015
Rating lowered to 8. I prefer Fields of Arle, and also Ora et Labora and Caverna. This should be reflected in my ratings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating after one play.  There is a lot of engine potential here, and it feels like there is always something you should be doing.  That, coupled with snappy turns, makes the game feel much shorter than the actual playing time.

That said, it seems like there is a premium put on knowing what later buildings are coming up when and positioning yourself to be able to snag them as soon as they do.  That's not bad, perse, but I would hate to find out that good play amongst experienced players might necessarily hinge on that.
----update----
After more consideration (and not based on any more plays) I suspect the concerns expressed above are going to turn out to be fairly minimal, and the sheer quantity of currencies and things to do with them do make for a very compelling game experience.  But is it fun? 

---update---
Another game in the books.  Definitely interesting.  Definitely moves at a nice pace, but it is difficult to justify the time sink with the amount of fun.  As an efficiency activity it is worthy.  And there is no doubt that the game plays well.  But I can't see wanting to play it more than a half-dozen times a year because of the length.

Rating will fluctuate between 7 and 8.  I'd still like to play it with 3.

---update---
A couple more games and this one is settling in on 8.  I'm still not good at it, but the game remains compelling.  Still, the learning curve is steep so getting more casual players to play this with me will be a challenge.

And I STILL need to play again with 3.

---update---
Five games in and I'm starting to figure this one out.  Also, played with 2 - really fun!

RATING: 7
When we first played Le Havre, we made the mistake of a 5p game.  Note to Future Players: DON'T DO THAT.  ESPECIALLY FOR YOUR FIRST GAME.

Then, years later, we looked past the scar tissue and we played with 2-4p.  Completely different game.  Night and bloody day.  It still feels a little more like "work" than "play" but at least it finally feels like play.  It's a tight resource management and efficiency engine workout and if you like this kind of thing it's more of it.  Its sweet spot is definitely 3p.

What this game desperately needs is a Strategy Guide: a full-blown document that explains to the newbie the benefits and disadvantages of the myriad of options available to them.  The "Where do I get money?" insert helps.  It's not enough.

RATING: 8.4
The easy flow of this game, reminiscent of that of Puerto Rico, is its greatest virtue. The subtle variations from game to game in terms of order of building and resource availability are a further mark of gifted design. 

Yet the lack of strategic variety keeps it from true greatness: every player must amass ships, construct buildings, and sell goods, with players' strategic focus differing only in their relative emphases on these goals. For what it is, the game also runs a bit long for my taste.

RATING: 8
Good, but intolerably slooooowwww with 5 players, it is clearly too many for this game. With 3 players it has a lot less downtime, and it is much more enjoyable. Nothing really new in this one, but at least unlike Agricola it is balanced and it is a well put-together worker placement game. It does not have the same tension as Agricola though. Maybe because of the multitude of options, and no matter what your opponents do, you can do something that is efficient. Need to learn what lots of different buildings do before you can think about strategies. Need a dedicated group and the game may start to shine. My rating is for 2 or 3 players, for 5p it would be a 3, for 4p a 7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After several solo plays (2 short version, the rest full version), it is apparent that the economic engine is finely tuned.  When you start a game with 5 money (Francs) and 1 coal (net worth of 7) and end up with a net worth of 283 in 7 turns, the power to make money is there.

This game is the best one I've seen at imitating a production market.  The incorporation of loans not only adds to the game itself, but enhances that feeling (it takes money to make money).  I absolutely love the feeling of starting with almost nothing and through your decision making process, work your way to wealth.

If you are looking for quick results, this is not your game.  It gathers momentum as it progresses.  It is so rewarding to make 70+ Francs over the last three turns when you were struggling to make 3 for so long!

I was worried about finding a "Solution" to the solitaire version.  No fear - the mix of Special Buildings (you only use 6 and see 3 per game) along with the order that goods arrive in the harbor really does create a different challenge each time.

Why this is not a 10:
-> I need variety in my gaming experience
-> While rewarding, it is a mental exercise - I need a break occasionally

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

After one play Le Havre seems promising. I like the elegance of Le Havre, the gameplay is super simple to grasp while still providing a hefty dose of thinking and strategizing. Can't wait explore this game more.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Another classic worker-placement game. I prefer Le Havre to Agricola due to less food pressure, less blocking and more building options. You feel like you are growing something rather than trying to keep up with feeding all the time.

There is a little bit less combo goodness because the buildings have mostly obvious pathways, but being available to everyone removes potential imbalances.

Blocking is close to non-existent; perhaps this is why I like it best among "classic" worker-placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Good worker placement game. What you have to do is pretty straightforward, you just need to figure out what a good path to use is. After one play it seems that you need to have decent food production, but getting ships is good, since it'll give you more actions that don't need to be spent getting food. Steel is very important, so start planning for that early. That means energy, coal -> coke, and iron. Seems like there is s fair amount going on, would like to play again.

2nd play: You need to get boats. Really. They are important. Not vital, but darned important. You can ship much stuff and it reduces your food needs.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I nearly stopped reading the rules right there in the opening paragraph because of the mechanism of paying to the owner of a building gives so strong Caylus vibes.

Luckily the payment is not that important a part of the game, and there are original elements included as well. A player turn is very simple, so there's surprisingly little downtime, even though the game is very long and decisions have long-lasting consequences. 

The best part of the game is that there's an omnipresent tickling turn angst, which is created by having very few turns per player and by always having to plan at least four or five turns ahead. Apart from that, I would not recommend the game to anyone else than hardcore production engine optimization freaks.

With five players, avoid at all costs.

RATING: 8
A great game that is more balanced than Agricola.  

My one slight complaint would be that various strategies are made worse by changing the number of players and it seems with 5 players that the boat/shipping strategy never really comes into play.  

However, a well done game overall.

Well worth playing, especially if you like Agricola.

RATING: 8.5
Uno dei più bei giochi in circolazione.
C'è chi lo definisce il fratello brutto di Agricola, chi al contrario il fratello bello.
Personalmente vedo la parentela ma non lo considero così simile, tutt'altro; in Agricola c'è più interazione, Le Havre si caratterizza per l'asimmetria del turno di gioco.

Infatti visto che in un turno ci sono 7 (numero primo) fasi a prescindere dal numero di giocatori (da 1 a 5) c'è chi giocherà più fasi e chi meno.

Difetti? E' un gioco molto lungo, e la durata aumenta di 30' per giocatore. Evitate i pensatori, specie per partite in 5!
Pregi? Semplice da giocare ma con strategie profonde e spesso a lunga scadenza. Come per Porto Rico strade diverse portano alla vittoria, l'importante è non farsi ingolosire dal voler far tutto.

Se devo esprimere la mia opinione lo preferisco ad Agricola!
Da giocare e rigiocare.

RATING: 6.8
Long, hard work with unclear objectives that are too hierarchical to be called 'multiple routes to victory'. Cluttered cards, a central mechanism that doesn't turn over or interact well enough, and cartoony graphics that don't befit the theme.

I'm sure Le Havre is a very good game, but it's a lot of work that I don't think I want to put in.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While it has the pedigree of Agricola and the inspiration of both it and Caylus, I feel the game is most similar to Roads & Boats, just without all the road building. You collect resources and convert those resource to better resources so that you can exchange them for victory points (money). The game is fairly simple and turns move along at a brisk clip, so there is virtually zero down time with a small number of players (with more, there can be a little).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
I was having great hopes for Le Havre game before buying it. Because I saw that it has lots of different resources can be used in game. Lots of resources remembers me Sid Meier's Colonization game. And I spent lots of my childhood with that game. After my first game, I was a bit dissapointed. Game ended in three hours and I was feeling a bit tired after game. These were negative points for Le Havre. Also I felt like it has lots of rules, but actually I was wrong. It seems like a complex game but it is not that complex actually. I can see that after my second and third games. Game is cool, but even after you get used to game it can make you a bit tired when game ends. When it is your turn you can do lots of decisions. It's like Chess or Caylus in that view, there are lots of ways player can select. All are good, problem is which one is best. After fourth game I become sure this game is not a bad or medium game. It is very powerfull. Clever and experienced player wins 95%. If you are weak you have nearly no winning change. I like that kind of games. But my opponents give up playing with me after some time. They get bored after consequent loses with huge score differences. Game has both fixed buildings and special buildings. And included buildings changes according to number players. Special buildings and very good designed building queues make every game different. In some games you get shortage from food in some games there become lots of good X. Every game is different. Thats very important design point. Congratulations Uwe Rosenberg. You made really cool game. If you like strategy games buy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

Superior game design makes for a superior game.  Will never turn down a chance to play. Among my favorites.

RATING: 8
A really good game - build an economic engine and let it run. The cards are clear and rules reasonably easy to pick-up, but the complex choices generated are extraordinary. RATING: 10
[b]Le Havre[/b] was traded away for Fields of Arle . 

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]I still actually really like Le Havre, but it was extremely difficult to get to the table and I got offered a great trade. The play time and table space was a major factor in how few times Le Havre got played. I only mention this because I think Le Havre is an excellent design by Uwe, but I like some of his other games more (Agricola, At the Gates of Loyang and Glass Road) and they all play much quicker (usually an hour or less if it's a 2p game).

Since I am not a collector I don't feel the need to own every game created by one of my favorite designers so Le Havre left my collection. There wasn't ever a time that I would choose Le Havre over one of the other Uwe games I own. All that said I'd happily play this again, I still think it's a very good game.[/i] 

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]- Lots of decisions to make/paths to take to try and be successful in this game.
- Variability among the buildings which leads to multiple strategies you can pursue.
- Resource conversion: I know this may seem like work to some, but I love this in games (Glass Road is another favorite of mine).
- I really like the artwork and the components are top notch.
- Plays really well with 2.[/i]

RATING: 8
心得:
煤礦路線似乎很強勢
不過人多時不太可能可以專心只搞自己的
所以還是要觀察場上的互動來決定行動
雖然別人可以卡你
但是就變的目標都是快速朝這個方向前進的樣子
規則:
*起始資源
  長版玩家有5元一煤
  短版玩家有5元2魚2木2土2鐵1牛2煤2皮，單人雙人都起始有一木船
*起始補給板塊洗混蓋著放置，玩家踩到才打開，對應資源格放資源
  長版2元2魚2木1土，洗好六張特殊建築放上面
  短版3元3魚3木2土1鐵1麥1牛，單人有一木船開著
*挑出對應建築物分三推洗勻，打開按數字牌好放在版圖上，選擇正確的記輪牌疊好
*每輪移動玩家船標記到下一格並補充資源
*玩家每回合可選擇一棟工人到建築物做動作，或是拿某一格資源全部
*此外還可買賣建築物(公有或是建築計畫區最上面那張)不算動作，賣建築物半價，船也可買
*船移動到利息格，有借貸不管幾張都只要付一元
*遊戲任何時候付食物都可用錢取代
*遊戲在每七回合一輪結束付食物並生麥生牛，然後最後一輪結束每位玩家可在執行一個動作(此動作可重複)
*工人必須進入建築物才能動作，被買的建築物，上面工人會回擁有者手上，同回合不能同建築物賣又買回來
*建設時，磚可以代替黏土，鋼可以代替鐵
*造船一次只能造一艘

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

Le Havre is simple (either gain resources or use a building) but not elegant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Clearly a quality game. It offers the perennial choice between taking resources or building. And between those, do you take resources that helps you stay alive (food) but can't help you build, or resources that help you build buildings. And if you build, do you build something that helps you feed (ships) or to progress your VP engine. 

There's the added charm of making all buildings available to all players, if they pay a fee to the owner. It's about doing things more efficiently than the other players through your resource takes, using your own buildings more than the others (to limit fees, so it is important what you build) and getting an efficient food engine going without sacrificing tempo. 

There is an issue with downtime with more players as there's a LOT of options to explore on a turn. And players on their turns may take your options so your strategy is continually changing. Causing more downtime. This lessens with experience. Which is a good thing because there's a lot to explore here and a lot to like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game.  If you love tight and tense Eurogames, you will appreciate this too. I only play it as a 2-player game.  Some say it is best at that player count.  I don't have anything else to compare it to, but I can imagine it being a different, albeit fun, experience as a 3-player game.  Judging by how the turns and rounds work though, it would be hard for me to see this being best at 4 or 5 players.  But like I said, I haven't tried that yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A really stunning design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre feels a little like Agricola's "big brother"--you're constantly trying to acquire and upgrade your resources in various ways while being under severe time pressure.  While the need to feed every round is decreased because you can take not-very-expensive loans, the end of the game will sneak up on you and curtail your grand plans.  The complex tree of converting resources is much deeper than Agricola in that there are many more different types of resources, and getting the end stages takes many more steps.  The buildings in Le Havre are (mostly) the same from game to game, providing an experience with a lot less variability, and helping to solidify various strategies.  This is a game where you really have to know what buildings are available and which buildings will be coming soon to be able to plan and do well--new players don't have much of a chance versus experienced ones.  I do enjoy this game quite a bit, but to some extent it has been replaced for me by the newer Ora et Labora.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 8
wersja z dodatkiem Le Grand Hameau
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very solid game but it's never grabbed a hold of me like Uwe's other games. The randomness of the buildings and the surplus of goods is fun, but I feel like some strategies are better than others. The special buildings allow for more variety though and including in the expansion leads to a TON of special building options each game. Food isn't quite as punishing in this one, but you do need to keep up with it if you want to do well. I'm unsure of how this plays with more than 3 since I have yet to do it, but I am intrigued since the final round of a 5 player game requires only 6 food (!).

The biggest drawback for me is the damn filling of the goods every turn. It's not difficult, it's just fiddly and annoying after a while. Especially when some turns last only a few seconds and you're already grabbing for goods.

I find between this and Ora et Labora, I'd rather play Ora instead. Still, it's nice to have the option.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Probably one of the best resource management games. It breaks the typical "5 resources" by providing 16 different resources in the game! Typical gameplay is broken in two phases, where players are initially constrained by the limited resources, trying to set their infrastructures up and subsequently constrained by time, trying to earn as much money as possible in a few turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
TRY Jun/09.  Early impression was that this was an 8+, and that was from a 2-player short game.

3er game (short), and still wondering if charcoal has any reasonable use.  Feels underpowered compared to other options.

Played another part-game of a long 2er.  Am getting less thrilled as the game feels much the same over & over.  Not very random, other than what the other players may do.  Rating has dropped significantly, as I'd rather commit the time to playing many other games instead.

Keen to try with 4 - probably the short version.  Not keen to play with less than 3 again.

July/09: Played long solo twice (201, 266).  I quite liked this option, but I find the scoring is heavily dependant on which special cards come up.

RATING: 10
One of the best resource management games around. There are 8 resource types that all can be processed to next level and used in various ways to gain other resources, to build new buildings/ships (points) or to get money (points). The special building deck keeps the game fresh for repeated plays.

Rating went from 9 to 10 after eight plays

RATING: 10
I'm not a big expert on strategy games; besides having played some pc strategy games, I've started in board gaming with Catan, Republic of Rome, Civilization card game (the one that came with Civilization Chronicles (apart from Risk etc.) so Le Havre is my first jump into a deep Economic board game.

It gets better everytime I played, and also my friends are enjoying it a lot. I also love the Special buildings that really forces you to change strategies taken on previous plays. Plenty of options, very open, and very balanced.

Le Havre has deffinately gotten me into the Strategy board game (just adquired a few other because of the great experience Le Havre has been).
