=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Heavy efficiency game. Heavier than Agricola and at least as heavy as Caylus, the game that inspired both. This is actually much closer to Caylus than Mr. Rosenberg's previous effort. There are a lot of resources to be collected, refined and then used to build buildings, which allow new actions to be performed, or ships, which allow goods to be exchanged for money. In the end, the richest man wins. 

The number of options available grows exponentially, as players build buildings, there are a lot of different ways to achieve one's goals and almost zero luck.

Solo mode is actually very interesting. 

I think this can be a real classic. Not so appealing to non gamers as Agricola, but a real challenge for those who like these types of games. 

Rating may go up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Feels like Agricola, but without the variability, stress, and tension. That might be more appealing to some, but I ultimately prefer Agricola over Le Havre.

RATING: 8
Three plays: 2 and 3 players shortened version. Solo full game.

Le Havre looks crazy complicated upon first look and especially upon first setup, with all the sorting and stacking and whatnot. But when the game starts rolling, it is pretty straightforward - the gameplay that is. The timing and the strategy department will burn some cortical fat.

It looks good, it plays good; it is easy to play and difficult to master. The ownership of buildings adds a nice layer of interaction. The only real downside is playing time. It's on the long side. Apart from that - another winner from Hr Boll - sorry Hr Rosenberg.

RATING: 8.001
After one game, the Jury is still out. It seemed like a pretty good game, but we had a couple of rules wrong that made it feel broken. I think fixing those will make it a lot better. At least I hope they do.

My wife and I both are looking forward to playing it with the fixes though.

Update: Wow, fixing our rule mistakes made the game a lot more fun. It was much tighter. We still made one mistake and ended the game one round too early. I also miscalculated at the end and it allowed my wife to pull out a win. This second play brought the game up from a seven to a 8 though and I can see it climbing higher with more games. The 2 hour play time is a bit long, so I do not see it getting played as much as I would like, but the two hour play time coupled with solid game play makes me want to come back to it.

I think that when it is all said and done this will pass Loyang and rival Agricola for me.

RATING: 10

I also appreciate that there is both a long and short game. Unfortunately, my partner dislikes most games with a heavy resource conversion component, so this one is less likely to see the table than I would prefer (At the Gates of Loyang is her favorite of the harvest triology).

RATING: 6
I own the IOS version of this game. I am glad that I get to try this game for $1. This is a worker placement game that has many rules that will probably require more plays to get it down. So far after one play I can already tell it is too heavy for my taste. The theme doesn't help either. Building ships? For a euro that can have theme pasted on, they chose one that I am not so interested in. Agricola? Sure, I think once or twice in my childhood I have wanted to be a farmer. There is a strange sense of tranquility when I play Harvest Moon. However, I have never dreamed of being a dock master trying to build ships. The theme of this game could really be anything when that many complicated mechanics are involved. The mechanics do make sense, mind you, but too much math in the conversions of materials.

The next heavy game that I have enjoyed is Yedo. In that game even though my brain was burned but at least I felt like a Lord of Ninja clan in feudal Japan.

RATING: 6.6
Agricola but with more going on. Of course, part ot the impressiveness fades having played Agricola which is quite similar in mechanics.
Its funny that people talk of "strategy" when other players are constantly taking actions dependant on everyone else's luck: will you get the necessary wood to build X building before someone else takes the only copy? If another player build's X building, what remains of your strategy? If the other players always take key resources before you, will you be able to do more with your dwindling money stash?
I own the App version and I can only thank the lord since set up time must be even longer than Agricola and there are many rules/board adjustments to take into account at every turn for every player. Games are also pretty long and tend to resemble each other after 4-5 games (hence all the expansions).
Seem to spend way too much time feeding your workers in games with four players and not enough gathering resources and building. I rather pay 4$ for the app than 60$ for the boardgame. Better value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I just love the elegance of this game. Your goal is to get VP via the construction of buildings and the selling of both raw materials and (by preference) processed goods.

The rules are as simple as it gets. In your turn, you either take the available unit of one type good from the market or move your worker piece to a building and do what it says. That's it.  

And yet, your options are huge. It's all about the buildings and what they allow you to do. And the special buildings - of which only five out of a deck of 35 get into play in each session - give you almost limitless replayability.

A master piece!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
note: iOS only
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great depth to rules ratio
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty heavy resource management game where the players build up their businesses in the harbor city Le Havre. Players acquire resources and build up their tableaus of buildings. These buildings can then be used by all players by paying a fee to the owner.

The most striking thing about the game is the sheer number of actions the players take during the game. Every single action is small, gaining resources or using a building, so even what feels like a fairly short term goal can easily stretch over five to ten actions. This is especially noticeable toward the end of the game where the players have to get everything together just so to get their goods shipped. Managing those most precious resources, actions and building access, is the hardest part of this game.

The game also has a feeding mechanism somewhat like Agricola but not nearly as punishing as you can take low interest loans to cover lack of food.

This is a challenging game that take a few plays to get to know. It might be a good idea to get to know the game by playing the shortened variant a couple of times first, just to get a feel for the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This is a loose, bloated, sprawling game with over-thought, over-loaded design. It could have been a decent game perhaps if the number of cards and the number of resources were about half as many.  Games are supposed to be fun to play not torture. Lots of redundant supposedly "options" exist which don't add to the game, but make it a chore. 

Each player will end up owning several building cards. On your turn you have to constantly look around the table and try to read the text/symbols on the cards to see which ones you may need to use, plus other building cards or ship cards that you may want to buy or build. Also check to see if the building card that let's you perform your intended move is available. This is tiring. A lot of the cards will sit there and never be used. The last couple of rounds it gets more chaotic and one or two players can get lucky to score big and others end up with lots of wasted resourced.

There are lots of better, tight, elegant resource management games, including Puerto Rico, Caylus, Stone Age, and many others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Even coarser than Agricola. Played once using the shortened version which ran almost 2 hours for 4 players. Good, but fell a bit short of Agricola, which I think is coarse enough. It felt like the game was too short and the strategic options too limited, which might be a result of playing the short game. Would love to play again with the full rules.

Edit: It took a while to understand the game, which is mostly learned by experience. Le Havre is one of my favourite games, and my favourite in the resource optimization genre.

Edit: Coal/coke strategy is dominant. Once all players know this, the game is still good, but it makes the game pretty hard to be worth investing its 3 hours in with new players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Rating after 1 play - 2 player game. Although the theme and mechanics are not as brilliantly unified as Agricola; Le Havre's mechanics are easier to explain/understand and, perhaps counter to expectations, it offers a greater variety of difficult choices and interesting opportunities. Far less friendly to the casual gamer yet with a similar but more forgiving feeding scheme. The first game, which at 2.5-4 (or more) hours is no small investment and must be considered as such, an investment, as the progression of buildings and their use will not be clear until (perhaps) several plays. This game seems to reward selective specialization where Agricola punishes it. Not since Agricola have I had such anxiety over difficult decisions; however, in Le Havre I felt that way every turn!

Obviously Agricola is an easy starting place for comparisons to this game. Le Havre is the superior game for serious gamers and my preference. Agricola is a very good game for leading casual gamers down the path to more serious games. As such I don't think Le Havre's popularity will overtake Agricola. There is definitely a place for both in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[floatleft][ImageID=392682][/floatleft]Le Havre is the best game in the Uwe Rosenberg's harvest trilogy. Where Agricola seems confining, Le Havre feels open ended. Le Havre is the most grueling game of the harvest trilogy with ever increasing feeding requirements. The tension of survival is palpable. 

The design of Le Havre is to use resources to construct buildings for points and more resources. Because of the design structure I am concerned about replayability of Le Harve. I am worried that after multiple plays the game plays will start to feel similar. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Well designed game, but there are a few points that bothered me:

1. It's too long. Just when I started to think the game was almost over, I looked at the deck and realized we were only 1/2 way.

2. The number of cards grows during the game, so that each round seems to take longer and longer as players try to maximze. 

3. Worker placement with just one worker. 

On the plus side, there are a lot of decisions to make, and the building deck is big enough to keep things interesting from game to game. 

I'll give this another chance. it's possible that the building mix that came up was a dud.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
the game is perfectly fine. It's mostly turning resources into other resources like we've now seen in many games. The graphic design is somewhat poor in that the central board has a lot of wasted space and the colors are garish. The troublesome part is that the game's big draw for me is that players can buy these building cards, which add worker placement spots, but give the owner of the building some benefit when it's used. This is a mechanism I enjoy, and am drawn to in many other games, but in Le Havre it seems especially hard to tell what the buildings do from across the table. 

There's also a strange design decision where each player gets an uneven number of turns each round. By the end of the game it all works out to even turns, but when preparing for a feeding phase, you sometimes have enough actions and sometimes you don't. It just feels uncomfortable.

I would play this again in theory, if someone felt strongly that they wanted to play it, but I don't think I need to own it.

:nostar: Art, Iconography and components functional
:nostar: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:star: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Raw enjoyment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite of the harvest trilogy.  It feels much  more "open" than Agricola - so many choices.  It's not a choice between good and bad, it's a choice between good and optimal.  I love the mechanic where you visit another players building and pay them resources, feels more interactive than Agricola where you just try to "block" people.

RATING: 4
Le Havre is another game of gathering and spending multiple resources, but with the added complication of multiple ways to convert resources into one another. This type of fiddly optimisation game (like Caylus) doesn't appeal to me much and I felt like it went on at least 50% longer than it really needed to. There's not much elegant or organic about this design, it relies on lots of cards with slightly tedious effects to achieve replayability rather than subtleties of player ineraction. I'm sure the second play would be much better but I doubt I'll prioritise that as a use of my gaming time.

RATING: 7.5
Agricola on steroids. No, not really. More a derivative refinement. The buildings act like round cards and there is a much more dynamic tree of choices (plans for buildings which, once built, everyone can use - Caylus like). Interesting design element is the asymetrical action points. Each round in a 3 player has one player getting 3 actions and the other two 2 actions. The extra action works its way around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've only played Le Havre a couple of times at the time of writing this, but I've enjoyed it. I really like how there's always something that you need to do to stay in the game, and it really encourages you to have a long-term (but flexible) strategy. The game always keeps you absorbed, and once you get the hang of the mechanics a turn can be played through very quickly (with the right people, of course). My only complaint is how fiddly the game can be: too many little counters. But it's a very minor complaint.

RATING: 3
A standard number of steps between harvest rounds means the game scales poorly with the number of players.
Looks like the game revolves around learning the valuable building combinations - how to get out scrabbling for food. Building the economic engine so you can cash in later - much later. Every action seems very incremental.
Since everyone has the same penalties there is no mechanism to restrain the leader helping those in the rear catch up.

Ultimately I found the game to be repetitious and tedious. One that I can pass.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Created by the same person who gave us Agricola, this is in the line of that game, and in my opinion, more enjoyable than Agricola. Unlike Agricola, all the player have the same setup and cards are available to all. The race is tight to feed your population while trying to develop at the same time. The choices each turn increases and it become realy hard to maximize you moves. So the learning curve of that game is realy steep. the rules are realy simple and easy to explain. The time duration of the game can be a turn off as it tend to increase significatively with the number of player. This is also the kind of game where players will get AP. So if your playing with people who tend to be proned to AP, the game will seem long and boring. 

Créé par la même personne qui nous a donné Agricola, ce jeu est dans la même lignée. Par contre, contrairement à Agricola, tous les joueurs ont le même arrangement de départ et les cartes sont disponibles pour tous les joueurs. La course est serrée afin de nourir sa population tout en développant en même temps. Les choix augmentent à chaque tour et il devient difficile de maximiser ses coups. La courbe d'apprentissage est donc longue. Les règles sont claires et faciles à expliquer. Un point négatif est le temps de jeu qui augmente significativement avec le nombre de joueurs. La Paralysie Analytique peut également être un facteur dans ce jeu. Si vous jouer avec des joueurs qui sont réputés être des adeptes de PA, alors le jeu vous semblera long et ennuyeux.

RATING: 8
Have the iOS app and that's the only way I have played. Really enjoying this one and would love to play in real life someday.

Update: I now own a copy and have gotten it to the table a few times, and it's a real pleasure at 3-4 players. It's a bit longer than some of Uwe's others, but it's great fun. 

I don't think it's quite as great as some of his others though--the strategy is there but unfortunately seems to be pretty centered around getting Coke and Steel with other routes not that valid or possible. That's not a huge issue--Agricola is a fantastic game but everyone has to fight for family growth--but for some reason Le Havre feels like a game that entices you by all these options when really only a small minority of the paths are really useful.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
What on earth am I [i]doing[/i] in this game? Am I a mayor? A dock owner? A shipping magnate? Who are these workers and why do I need to feed them? 

I get that this takes the potential card imbalance problem of Agricola and makes the special powers available as common buildings, but that introduces more problems than it fixes for me. So rather than pay attention to just the few cards in my hand that synergize, I need to instead memorize the components before I can play well? That's hardly an improvement. Neither is the fact that many of the buildings will be facing away from me, upside down, during the course of play. Also not ideal. 

But finally, what really killed it for me was the game resources were too abundant for me to care about them; if instead of taking a shitload of wheat I can take a shitload of fish, where's the tension? Agricola was interesting because navigating scarcity is difficult and promotes a sensitivity to wastefulness; navigating abundance is simply annoying. It's component bukkake.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Pros:

[1] Very low luck factor
[2] Seems to have the same heaviness and depth of Caylus, but the theme is far better implemented in this one, and the rules are much easier to digest.

Cons:

[1] It's still another worker placement/economic engine game. Really nothing innovative.

[2] It is way, way too long considering how repetitive and mechanical it is. Compare this to Puerto Rico: In that game you're doing lots of different things and in a different order. In Le Havre, there are much less things to do: either get resources or do a special action. Then some special event (harvest) happens on a very regular basis.

[3] Very, very prone to AP. There is *a lot* of information to digest during your turn. Every special building is face up for inspection. However, not every building is available for purchase (the building cards are laid out in three face-up columns; only the top card of each column is available, so AP-prone players will spend lots of time simply trying to figure out how to get cards buried down in a column.

Worse, because it's a worker placement game, players can prevent opponents from doing a particular action by doing the action first. So if some opponent does that to you *and* you weren't prepared, you'll have to totally rethink your strategy.

RATING: 9.3
Every time I play Le Havre, I like it more.  The same designer created Agricola, and the two games share a number of themes.  The ever-growing supply piles and the constant need for food drive both games, but I find that I much prefer Le Havre.  I really enjoy the building mechanic and the ability to visit other players' buildings for a price.  The lone shortcoming to this game is its incredible length.  Every game we've played has taken 3 hours to complete, which is stretching it for our group.  We like to play multiple games in an evening, and Le Havre has the tendency to absorb an entire night.  In fairness, I don't think we've played a game yet in which we weren't teaching a new player, but even with the length, I still greatly enjoy this game.

RATING: 7
Well, let me just say I really respect the design of this game. I had a good time. But here is where the rubber meets the road. I'm giving this one a 7 because if someone wanted to play this game I would be happy to. But, I will more than likely put this one up for trade because I don't think I would ever look on my shelf and choose this one over about 20-30 of my other games. It is just a bit too long for what it is. It's pretty tedious as you continue to put the resources in the offers and feed your people every three or four actions. It's just a bit repetitive, and I felt like I was working instead of playing a game. I say all of this a bit aggressively, but honestly it was fun and I could see through multiple plays you could grow in your strategy, but my wife didn't like it, and I won't be reaching for it on the shelf, so why keep it? Glad I got to play this classic though. I could see many loving this one, so give it a try.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
**Keep in mind I've only played solo two player games on the digital edition.  I don't own a hard copy of the game.

The game was really fun at first; I'm a big fan of town building games.  However, this one quickly died out.  There's definitely a meta-strategy that you can employ to win nearly every game.  There's one for player one and another for player two and they work every time.  

Like I said, I've never played with 3 or more players so hopefully the larger games have more replayability, but after a strong first impression I was slowly let down by this game.  I'll still play if the people in the group want to.  I just won't suggest to play it.

RATING: 7.8
I like this one, but it drags a bit.  Not sure why.  I might just need to play it more.  Considering ios version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's hard not to compare Le Havre to Agricola.  They are from the same designer, the art style is the same right down the the artist's extreme attention to details.  Each player owns their own little factory town, or rather their own block in a larger factory shipping town.  The game starts with having few options available (yet there are more options than at the beginning of Agricola) and expands to having tons of options.  The actions are fairly simple: put out the specified supply tokens and then either take one type of supply tokens or enter a building and do an action.  But there are a ton of different ways to go about getting the food you need while you build up a complex of buildings. It is very unlike Agricola.

The only aspect of Agricola that I missed was the feeling of satisfaction as I looked at my farm.  But the game play of Le Havre itself was so much more enjoyable that I am willing to give up that small point.  

I like that there are a ton of options and that it's really difficult to get shut out of useful actions/items.  If you want to go into the wharf to build a ship but someone is already there, you can take a big stack of fish or whatever.  There are always useful things to do so you never feel helpless.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
First play was very smooth.  I think this game was much easier to learn than Agricola, and much more enjoyable.  The little bit of randomness in Le Havre is for everyone to see and plan for, not like Agricola where each player has their own card draw.  I also really like how the interaction is a bit more direct in Le Havre (not much more, but a bit) as players not only have to try to plan what other players will need for resources, but have to plan to have food/francs to enter each other's buildings.  I can see myself enjoying this game more after more plays!

RATING: 9
Bought this game blind based on Agricola pedigree -- Le Havre shares some mechanics, but is a much heavier game with a more complex economic system.  It surprised me how the goods management started to feel similar to Roads and Boats in sheer complexity, sans the transport network fiddliness.  The time commitment feels a little long for what the game is, but turns are very fast and you're always kept thinking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
JugamosUna
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It is a fantastic heavy economic/worker placement game from Uwe Rosenberg. The second in the so-called harvest trilogy. And on heavy I really mean it. The constant evaluation of your options vs. your opponents' options as well as finding an early solution to feed your workers are critical. The struggle to build critical buildings in a way where you benefit from it first makes it a very tense chess-like puzzle. The more than 30 buildings and the somewhat random starting position of these makes every game slightly different. The special buildings can lend each game a different angle, and utilizing these options is very important. 
Another big dilemma is the instinctive lure of opportunism of a good big stack of wood or fish vs. long-term planning. 
I also like how the game evolves from the early resource collection to mid-game resource conversion to late game shipping. 
Like the hidden (??) social commentary (??) of waste produced by modern econimies. 
But: AP prone and I would never recommend this game for more than three players. Also, sometimes its weight is its own enemy: there are ocasions, when you feel just too damn tired to start such a game.
I also like the app, that makes the administration so less fiddly.
Update #1: It's fantastic how you are still learning nuances after 10 games. Usually nobody cares about Charcoal Kiln, but yesterday in a two-player game I refused to build the Cokery, grabbed the big pile of woods and covered my energy needs from that, all the while my opponent struggled to get the energy needed for operating the Steelworks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

After first play I was really liking this game. Second time around not so much. I have a hard time grasping the plethora of options and deciding which is better. Very good game, but ultimately not for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have only played 3 games of LeHavre, so I have  not finally decided if I like it as much as Rosenberg's other harvest games Agricola and Ora&Labora (definetely much more than Loyang). To me, LeHavre is a stream-lined and more focused version of Ora&Labora (strange to say this about a predecessor), with less complex product conversions. But I am not sure, if LeHavre is as deep as these two and offer that much replayability.

With two players it is really tactical (do you have to take wood now or is it still there in your next turn? Can you get the ressources for a ship before your opponent does?) I really enjoy the shift in gameplay: You begin with getting enough food for your workers and this gets even harder as they need more every round. But after you get some ships and made a huge batch of bread or beef, you focus more on getting steel (either for ships or to ship it).

I often heard the following phrase, but I agree: In your turn you always have several very good options and you just try to pick the best. Even though I am sometimes AP prone, I was not overwhelmed by these options at all. Playing LeHavre feels more light hearted than Agricola, since you accomplish something every turn and you are not forced to do a certain thing.

RATING: 9
A robust economic game with a broad strategic horizons, and a great narrative arc. From plucking up small piles of resources, to acquiring more and more buildings and ships, to sending off richly-laden ships - each stage of the game flows naturally and builds drama. This is an efficiency game, but an effiency game that can reward flexibility, rather than the cramped puzzle format of other efficiency-engine games (I'm looking at your Agricola). Components are also top-notch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
I need to play this a few more times, at which point it is likely to be promoted or demoted significantly. The reason is that there is a substantial learning curve in memorizing the large number of options in the game.
The game has 3 currencies and (if I counted them right) 14 commodities, though it remains at heart a victory points optimisation euro. The problem I have is deciding if that additional complexity adds anything.
I also have some doubts that the game doesn't involve a relatively straighforward set of optimisation decisions. This is partly because the game disguises the long range progress.
It is certainly thinky rather than fun, and in an odd way (though the games have nothing in common rule-wise) it reminded me much more of Civilization than its Euro cousins in feel. 
I retain an open mind but I'm inclined to think that this falls into the category of in-elegant and could have been produced with a much narrower range of components but all the same essential ideas.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome game. Heavily drawing on your ability to make long-term strategies, but punishes you for sticking too hard to it. There is no easy way to win in this game. Has no chance factor, which makes a victory so much more rewarding and a loss so much more humbling than in any other game. It's a man's game. 
I like it, even though I lose most of the times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife got this for Christmas quite a few years ago (2013 I think, but it may have been 2012), and despite both of us liking most of Uwe's other games, for some reason we never got round to trying this until we played a 2p game today (May 1st 2016!). And it's a shame it took us so long, because we both really liked the game - it has a fair bit in common with Agricola and (in particular) Ora et Labora, but I think I prefer it to O&L (it's much more streamlined, and turns fly by, barring the occasional boutt of AP caused by the huge number of options later in the game). I'm not sure it's better than Agricola or Caverna, because of the huge replayability of the former and the insane amount of options and strategies in the latter, but I don't rule this out either. I can see this one getting quite a lot of play in the future.

RATING: 9.5
DEC 2008: Very nice game. Shares Agricola's variablility due to the plethora of cards of which only a small subset are used each game. Even though it uses action mechanisms similar to that of Agricola, the play feels different. The use of the buildings by all players makes the game feel a little more interactive. With a large number of resources and their upgrades, there are an enormous number of viable strategies for each game. Production and art is stellar. I need a few more plays but it might even be better than the Gric.

RATING: 9
rating after 1 game - 7
ratings after 2 games - 7
ratings after 4 plays - 8

i LOVE the painful decisions u get each turn. i LOVE the face u only do ONE thing on ur turn. 

i DISLIKE that this game takes 4+ hrs with 4 people.i DISLIKE the complete absence of theme. i DISLIKE the lack of a sense of achievement at the end.

if there was a game with the same choice intensity that played in 2-2.5 hrs i would play it a LOT.

if there was a game that took 4 hours and had as painful decisions but that had a map and fighting and a sense of epicness i would play it a LOT

played a few times 2pl (2-2.5hrs full game, 1h15 short) and it works really well both full and short

rating after 8plays - 9 - i just love the choices this presents and i prefer it to agricola - no other gane that i know of forces u to evaluate differing amounts of resources like this one does

update - turns out we were playing the loans rule wrong - we played 1 coin per loan come interest time - so tried it the proper way and HATED IT - it took all the wonderful feeding stress out the game - u just took lots of loans and u realise that once the food tension is removed there's not a lot left - won't play this way again and i recommend others dont

rating after 12 plays - dipped to 8 then back to 9 - the choices are just so damn delicously hard

RATING: 9
The rules themselves are fairly simple. The strategy is really deep though. There are so many choices in this game. It lets you do some really cool things that are hard to see. Selling some of your buildings to get an important one or taking out loans (and repaying them later) to focus on buying buildings.

The temptation in this game is awesome. There are so many GOOD choices that you will get frustrated because you can't take them all. It's very difficult to find the "best" choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The game is ok, but it is more complex, fiddley, and mathy than I like.  It has depth, but at the cost of a huge number of arbitrary rules that must be remembered.  It feels like every balance tweak game with an entirely new mechanic, and the end result is a game that functions by brute force not cleverness, elegance, or precision.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
*EDIT (03/11/09): I have real concerns about two things.  First, the way loans and interest work make no sense whatsoever from a theme point of view, which annoys me badly.  It is becoming clear that actions spent just to feed and avoid a loan are losers.  Second, as you might expect from an engine-building game, there's VERY little capacity to catch up to a leader, which in a game this length often means 1 1/2 to 2 hours spent playing for second (or just trying to avoid last).  It would be nice if some of the "late game" cards such as the steel production cards were not put together in such a way that only those already doing great can use them.  Still, for me, more fun than Agricola.*

I feel very little need to play Agricola now that Le Havre is here.  Both are probably a little long, but I don't consider that an ender in a "main event" sort of game.  I still struggle with analysis paralysis (as do some others in my group), but it never seems to get aggravating.  I don't want to play a big game like this all the time, but I still find myself amenable when others bring this one up.

Would like a copy of my own so Marissa and I could play 2-player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First 2 games. I'm starting to understand. It's a simple and complex game. I think this game will be one of my favorites. I wish to play it again soon.

Board: 3P Completa, 18 turnos, 2h 20m. Con Is y Sten. Sten 168, Ju 148, Is 110. Ningún jugador ha usado préstamos.
Cada uno con una estrategia muy diferente. Is con un gran motor de alimentos pero sin barcos (consiguió un único barco en el último turno); yo con 4 barcos (desde el turno 14 con toda la comida cubierta) y basándome en conseguir edificios que den muchos puntos, no he cogido nada de reses, maiz ni cuero; Sten con muchas reses, pescado y carne. Tenía muy pocos edificos pero mucho cash (85f en cash), tenía 2 barcos. Fantástico juego!

+ ESSEN Promo cards (http://lookout-spiele.de/afrika/farmers-help-farmers/)
+ Le Grand Hameau, GH00-GH30 (http://lookout-spiele.de)
+ Le Grand Hameau-Rattletrap car, GH31 (BGG Marketplace)
+ Le Grand Hameau-Wholesale Bakery, GH32 (BGG Marketplace)
+ Le Grand Hameau-Tablet mit App, GH33 (Included in Le Grand Hameau)

RATING: 5

I admire it but didn't like it as much as I wanted to, ultimately.

RATING: 7
Good game, but lacks the theme of building something like Agricola has, which can really draw in non-gamers.  You just end up with a long line of building  cards and a stack of money to count.  The most interesting aspect is seeing what special buildings come out and how you can best take advantage of them, but the player who gets to go first just after a special came up has a big advantage, unless they get screwed by a bad one (they're all pretty good, but some are not so good if they come out too late in the game). I've only played 2 players, so I'm sure there's a lot of game still left for me to experience, but I think I would always vote to play Agricola over this.

RATING: 6

My rating will likely go up with repeated plays. I think it will be a while before I would want to attempt it with 4 or 5 players.

-----

One play. Three-player. I felt the repetition here. I don't mind long games that engage me but the type of management required here had me looking at how many cards were left in the 'ship' deck quite often. This type of game needs to be shorter and I'd like to try the short(er) game option.

Certainly not a bad game and I would play again (with 2 or 3 players).

RATING: 8
This game is among one of my favorites. In this game you are investors building buildings and ships to ship goods in order to make the most money. The game has a unique worker placement aspect where players use each other's buildings to improve their goods and make them more valuable for shipping or for building more valuable building in the port town.  This Gaame is so much fun.

Pros: fairly simple game play but with deep heavy decisions that get more and more difficult as the game goes on.Fun theme. No harsh worker placement. 

Cons: long playing time. Game may take a while to setup.

RATING: 8
This game has grown a lot on me.  Packed with strategy.

Does it have a lot of chits? Yes.  Does it give you a bad case of analysis paralysis? Yes.  Is it easy to get lost on what you were trying to accomplish? Yes.  However, I am able to overlook its annoying qualities because the gameplay is fantastic.  There is no denying it anymore, I am a fan of a game designer - Uwe Rosenberg.

For me, a completely different experience from Agricola, but I'm sure there is no coincidence why I rank them both so high.

On the other hand _Le Havre_ (so far, at least) seems to provide the full complement of game fun in the time allotted.

RATING: 9
In Le Havre players collect resources and use various buildings to develop them into advanced (and more valuable) resources all of which can be used to build buildings where different activities like developing resources can be done. This is the next big game from Uwe Rosenberg after Agricola and at least in my books this is a better one. The game is exactly the kind of game I enjoy playing. Maximising opportunities within a certain longer strategy and figuring out good combos of actions you can do. The only fault is that it takes quite a long time to play. It doesn't matter to me personally but it's hard to find people willing to spend the time to invest enough time for a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I originally played Le Havre back when the game came out, and liked it alright. It felt a bit slow and a little long for me at the time, and it was right about when my enjoyment of euros was starting to wane.

Recently I got the game in a trade, and for whatever reason I find myself appreciating it once more. It's a very challenging game, with a lot of small decisions that add up over the whole stretch of the game. I like the level of luck here too, as it shifts when the same buildings come out from game to game. Perhaps most satisfying, the scope of the game ramps up really well. The players start with just a little bit of money and a lump of coal, and by the end they are shipping boatloads of goods all over the place. With 3 people it's hard to do better in this genre.

There are still a couple of downsides. It's on the long side, especially for this weight class. The closest comparison here is probably to Caylus, another solid game that is probably too long to really play a whole bunch. It also is punishing to inexperienced players, meaning that a single group that plays over and over again will get the most out of it. 

In the end, there are about forty hojillion heavy Euros that dwell in the same space as Le Havre, but for whatever reason it has managed to hold its own over several years. I still prefer Agricola, but Le Havre is a great game in its own right.

RATING: 9
Just so much better than Agricola.

The sameish mechanics take advantage of what I liked about Agricola, but the addition of a (to me) more interesting theme, and a much more forgiving game makes it more engaging. No longer are some actions just plain better and able to be spammed and blocked (I'm looking at you, family growth), and the special buildings are far less game changing than some of the Agricola cards, but still provide enough uniqueness to make each game slightly different. 

Generally, what's good is if something is hard, it's hard for all the players rather than the luck of the draw meaning one player is screwed whilst the other's rock.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Intense, engaging and quite fun and satisfying putting it all together. This will reward future plays. Although there are certainly similarities with Agricola, it's thematically and mechanically unique enough to own as well. There are so many paths you can choose from game to game, and there are tough choices to make turn to turn. Best game I can think of for three players. I'd recommend new players start with the short game - it should get them back wanting more.

Every game is like a fluid puzzle, where you're trying to get your town up and running, buying buildings, feeding people, shipping goods, building ships. There's never enough turns to get everything you want done, so you have to choose where you're going to suffer and where you're going to thrive. The difficulty is working all these plans around the plans of your opponents. Dealing with all this is fun because your opponents have to deal with all your shenanigans too. That's where it's similar to Agricola. Everywhere else it feels like a different experience entirely. All buildings are open and special abilities are there for all to see. Because the building order changes from game to game it's a different experience each time. It's a puzzle I'd like to get to the table more often so I can really explore strategies. There's a lot of replay value here for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

Another case of unjustified buzz, this one motivated by the prior success of [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/31260]Agricola[/url][/i], from the same designer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
It took me too long to get a chance to play this, but when I finally did, I liked it a lot. 

The game is very open with all the action choices, but not so open that you can't plan and decide. I really like the fact that the actions are so simple, but also very complex: take some resources or use a building. That's it. But it takes a lot to really decide what to do. After a good few thoughtful minutes, it's somewhat funny to just take the fish, for example. "What? You sat there for 5 minutes, and after all that, you are just taking the fish?!" But a lot of strategy went into taking those fish, planning that included future turns, too.

The way the buildings are purchased and used and potentially sold back is interesting and unique. If you own the building, you use it for no direct cost. If you build a building, you get the cost displayed as points at the end of the game. If someone is using your building, you can't use it, too. but you can sell it back, which means it is available to use again. Cool stuff going on that creates complex effects.

This one is ranked high for a reason. Great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a masterpiece.

RATING: 9
The mechanic is so deceptively simple yet rich, rich, rich.  Owning/building the buildings will usually return your investment in the long-term while saving you entry fees (and force them on other players) in the short-term.  There's no true multi-worker-placement, but there are plenty of 'feeding' obligations and a million ways to accomplish your goals.  If gaming is really all about making painful choices, this game has a bright future for my tastes.

RATING: 7
With five players -- two of us playing for the first time -- it took just over three hours, and that didn't feel too long for the amount of decisions made along the way. My playing felt reactive, in that it was difficult to plan more than a turn or two ahead and actually get to follow through on the intended plan; either I'd get blocked, or some unanticipated opportunity or more desperate need would arise first.

I was confused initially by the subtlety of buying buildings, building buildings, using a building, and just squatting in a previously-used building. This amounted to some poor decisions early on, where I didn't get much benefit out of my selections.

While I enjoyed playing this one far more than I did Agricola, it did share some of the opacity in scoring. Even though the value of things is more apparent here, it's hard to tell how well one's opponents are doing comparatively, and hence all five scores out the end turned out to feel like a surprise. That means it's hard to know if you played well until it's over, and all the small successes and seemingly good choices along the way can still come to naught.

Having said that, I'd play again, preferably with four players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorites.  Anyone who wants to play will always find me as a willing participant.  Three players is definitely the sweet spot on this one.  I can't imagine playing a five player game of this unless you have 4 hours set aside.  Lots of tough choices to make, but none of them are bad.  You don't feel like you are getting jipped if you HAVE to take the fish offer.  I like the dynamic of some turns you will get 3 actions and sometimes you will get 2 and must plan appropriately.  It's cool how if you build a building, someone else can still use it, but they might have to pay you a fee to do so.  You can block, but you can't use the same building twice in a row, so if you block a building by leaving your worker there, it prevents you from using that particular building for another turn.  There are so many cool little nuances that you only really appreciate after a couple of plays.  It's outstanding and worthy of its high rating on here.

After further plays of this, I have to say that it can be a little samey and I have downgraded it.  It would rank behind Agricola at this point and possibly be on the chopping block.

RATING: 9.25
tons of action possibilities but thankfully as the game progresses many of the actions become obviously less useful, so this prevents excessive analysis paralysis.  This is (so far) the king of resource management / building games.  Somewhat flawed due to the dominance of the coal/steel strategy toward the endgame, but I still like this better than Ora et Labora since it has some randomness in game setup whereas O&L does not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
The game that made me realise we're not in the same hobby after all. And that recommendation forums suck. 

It's an optimisation exercise in which the number of options increase as you go along - there's so much stuff to do! Yet every choice is the same as every other choice with net result being driven to AP and apathy by the sheer number of irrelevant choices. It's like grocery shopping the game - this canned tuna or the other, this brand of olive oil or one of 20 others, or maybe margarine? So not only you're doing solitarish optimisation, you're also overburdened by choices nobody cares about. And once in a while, staring at your shopping list, you occasionally bump into another shopping trolley. Are we having fun yet? 

In Agricola you make a strategic choice about the food engine and you have to stick to it to reap profit - so you're both risking that it will work, plus it takes about half of your actions away, meaning your brain can focus on other stuff of some importance. 

Le Havre in a way is a forbearer of victory point salads and Caverna - games that think choices, no matter how irrelevant, are a good thing. Nope, they're the way consumers in today's capitalism are paralysed and taken advantage of. 

It's a game I can execute for a rate of 12 eur per hour. Look - this is work, not leisure time. The game works because you work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played twice with 3P. Le Havre is, by all accounts, a very strong design. The game is mainly about tracing the most efficient path to crank out the necessary resources, which are eventually shipped or used to construct buildings. Its expansive resource network contains various resources, each serving a niche role in the game.  

There are plenty of positive aspects here. The game gradually grows as wharfs get modernised and buildings built. Those who enjoy a game with strong strategy will be pleased as there are only minute amounts of luck involved, yet the arrangement of buildings guarantees that each game will feel different enough.

Despite all that though, it comes down to a matter of my preference in games. Constantly calculating the value of moves and converting resources are not my favourite activities in a game, and while I'll gladly participate in it for a 90-minute game, continuously doing so in a 3-hour long game stretches the concept of fun a little thin for me. And as the decision tree invariably grows along with the number of available buildings, downtime can become a pressing issue.

OK, I'm actually interested in trying this at least once more, although the playing time is a huge deterrence. (I have also purposefully avoided any comparisons to [thing=31260][/thing] as they have little in common, aside from being designed by the same person.)

RATING: 6
[2 plays] 1st comments: This stands a chance to improve its rating to a 7 or an 8, but it would have to shine much brighter than the first play, and that isn't at all certain. Contrary to some other people's opinions, I found this denser, less thematic, more punishing, and far less pure "fun" factor than Agricola. I didn't enjoy the game beating up on me, I didn't like the cramped little board covered up so that you couldn't enjoy the already sparse artwork, I didn't find the mechanics that interesting, or the iconography helpful to understanding.

I didn't play smartly, so I will give it a chance again definitely.

Update after 2nd play:
Still like the theme and mechanics of Agricola much better, but I now have a better understanding and some respect for the design of this game. For me though, it just lacks a personality compared to Agricola.

Most recent play 1-15-10 with Donovan and Carter.

RATING: 8.5
My final thoughts on le havre 
Overall very good game, I would not play with 5. Maybe 4 but 3 is best. 
The components are ok,  The tiles are small, bigger tiles would have been better, better money quality would be nice. Someone can easily make a mistake or cheat by flipping tiles over.
The game is a little on the long side, maybe 14-15 round would have been good. 
I like that there is a lot of for you to do, many good choices. 
Now that I know how the game works I can have better strategy for the next game. (must focus on food, ships, iron and energy late in the game and buy good buildings) 
Outside our group my friends would never play this game, so this is not a game I would buy, but I would play agaom. overall I give it 8.5 out of 10.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Very long. Very complicated. Players need to memorize cards to find out working combos. Its also unforgiving, which is not itself bad, but in this game it does not quite help because the game takes too long to play a few times just to get the hang on it.
Theme seems strangely implemented. Some elements are obviously carried over from Agricola and feel out of place (you have to feed your workers? Grain and cattle can be harvested?? You pay food to use ressources???)
I can see how this game would sit well with a group who does not mind long games, who likes complex analysis, who has no problem with inconsistent themes, and who plays often enough to really study the game. A game for *hardcore* Eurogamers. Thus not for me. For me it takes all the things that I did not like in Agricola and makes them even worse. On the positive side, Le Havre has made me like Agricola better than before - now I know that all the things I find slightly annoying could have been much much worse.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

There always seems like there are great options available but determining the best one is part of the fun. I think it's pretty easy to learn too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le havre is an excellent game - with a shelf life.

A year into owning it, I don't see myself playing this very often in future. Certain strategies (coke/cows/bread shipping) are definitely dominant, and sadly the special buildings and other products do not provide a viable alternative for scoring winning amounts of VP.

That said, the plays we have gotten out of it have made it more than worth the purchase cost, and this is still something we break out occasionally as a two player or three player game.  

Update: We've recently started playing this again, using the variant where you have two specials built already at the start - its a small change, but it gives a chance of pursuing new strategies and for us, it's gotten the game to the table again :).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[2011-08-13]
Még egy top játékot kipipálhattam a Le Havre kipróbálásával. Sok véleményt olvastam róla, de ezektől teljesen függetlenítve magam ültem le játszani 2 másik játékossal. A rövidített változatot választottuk és nem túl gondolkodós 12 forduló alatt is sikerült a szabálykönyvben leírt két órát egy féllel megtoldanunk és a negyed-fél órás szabályismertetés után 3 óra alatt lejátszanunk a játékot. Azt kell mondanom a Le Havre-nak úgy néz ki ez az egyetlen hátránya az irgalmatlan hosszúsága. Bele se merek gondolni meddig tarthat egy öt fős, profi változat gondolkodós társaságban. A témája, kidolgozottsága jobban bejött, mint a szerző másik játéka, az Agricola esetében. A szabály meglepően egyszerű, a játékosok köreik elején a 8 alapanyagból 6-ból, plusz a pénzből választhatnak, amelyből körönként egy egyszerű metódus alapján mindig kétfajta töltődik eggyel. A játékos egy adott alapanyag vagy a pénz kiválasztásával mindet elviszi, ami addig ott töltődött, ahogy az Agricolában is van. Ezen túl épületeket vehetünk vagy építhetünk, amelyek használata számunkra ingyenes, játékostársaink számára bizonyos árért cserébe vehető igénybe. A játék hosszát főleg a fordulók adják, ugyanis minden körben a sok választható épület akciói közül mindössze egyet választhatunk, így tulajdonképpen annyira nem is félelmetes maga a játék gondolkodós része. Persze rengeteg a lehetőség, főleg, ha minden lehetséges épület leépült, de nagyon könnyen kizárható elég sok akció. A játékban lényegében nem sok út vezethet a győzelemhez, de az utak a sok alapanyag és az abból képezhető nyersanyagok miatt azért részeiben eltérnek. A sok forduló egyértelműen azért lett kitalálva, hogy minél kiegyenlítettebb legyen a játék. De én abszolút el tudom fogadni azt a véleményt, hogy ez már sok. Én kibírtam, sőt kimondottan élveztem is a játékot, bár a felénél úgy éreztem nem lesz esélyem a rossz helyzetemen lényegesen javítani, ez nem volt így. Jobb játékkal, akár vesztes helyzet is megfordítható a sok forduló alatt. Jó játék a Le Havre, igazából nagyon jó, komoly játékosoknak nagyon ajánlott, nem véletlen a pozíciója a BGG-n, talán meg is érdemli. Azonban a hossza miatt sokszor nem valószínű, hogy előkerül a legtöbb helyen. A játékot tulajdonképpen hibátlannak érzem mechanizmusok szempontjából, nagyon tetszik, hogy összesen 1 akciója van mindenkinek a körében, így 9 pontot érne a játék. 1 pont mínusz a hossza miatt.

[2013-04-15]
Végre sikerült egy teljes verziót játszanom a játékkal. Így már bőven van lehetőség különböző dolgokat megvalósítani, több utat kipróbálni. Továbbra is nagyon jó játéknak tartom, de a hossza miatt nem gyakran tud előkerülni.

[2017-08-28]
Végre kipróbálhattam 5-en a teljes verziót. A szabály 3 és fél órára saccolja így a játékidőt és meglepő módon bele is fértünk ebbe még úgy is, hogy két újoncunk volt és gondolkodtunk bőven. Ahogy korábban írtam, a teljesen reménytelen helyzet is javítható a sok forduló miatt, most is igaz volt. Másik játékos körében már lehet előre tervezni melyik akciót akarjuk választani, így rövidíthető a holtidő. Bátran ajánlom 5-en is. Emelek is a ponton.
8->9

RATING: 8.2
This is the right amount of inspiration... As much as Le Havre is derivative of its predecessor [thing=31260]Agricola[/thing], it still shines on its own merits. Great resource management and engine building game.

I wish Uwe stopped replicating his own ideas at this point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really appreciate that Le Havre has a short and long form. Most of what gets cut out of the short form is a slow buildup of resources in the opening turns. The additional buildings available in the long form are fun, though. And the long form tends to give you a more satisfying final round or two where you're finally done scrambling for food and can really use the economic engine you've built for points. Both versions are worth playing, depending on time available.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First Roseberg game we played.  The genius of this game is the flow of play - everything happens so naturally. even though it would be considered a heavy Euro, I feel we merely skimmed the rulebook (which is only a couple of pages long) before our first full run-through, after which we had a good handle on the mechanics.  Everything you need to know about what does what is on the relevant cards or components so there is no need to return to the rulebook.  VERY Well designed!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
If you like drafting and dealing with a bunch different cards with a ton of information on each one, then you might get some joy out of this.  In addition to having to know the true value of all the buildings (and all the buildings coming up), you need to learn how to get out of the food death spiral.  It seems that there is a big learning curve on this one.  

I think if you played this quite a bit it would become more rewarding.  You would know how everything works together, creating valuable combos, you would know how getting one building will aid in getting some other building later in the game, etc.  You would also know how to move away from wasting every single turn trying to feed.

Sometimes there aren't any worthwhile moves to make, often times there aren't any exciting ones.  The switch from cubes to chits gives the impression that there is more theme, but what you are actually doing with these themed items is rather dry and uninteresting. 

It is an engine game, so once you get behind the curve it is pretty tough to catch up, but this is exacerbated by the fact that all players must pay out the same amount every turn, so the players that are ahead aren't hit nearly as hard by the turn penalties as those that are behind.  That said, I can see being fascinated by the puzzle to get yourself out of the hole you start in and want to come back to the game to play more efficiently.

But that just is it.  It really is more a worky exercise in efficiency than anything fun to me. Really though, if this wasn't just a pure drafting game I might be more interested in playing this again (sometimes there is just nothing worthwhile to draft and others have great fortune in timing) as I can see playing with the engine could be fun.  

I am a little risk averse now though because at hour one I realized I was going to be spending another two hours solely in a mindless subsistence mode watching the other two players move ahead, actually making decisions on their turns. 

If I'm going to spend three plus hours on a game, I'd rather play something deeper and more rewarding and less processional like 18AL or just play Caylus and Agricola (the two better versions of this) back to back and have a much better time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is a blast. 

Not only is the theme really unique and interesting, but the production value and artwork is really good too.  Though there are a lot of pieces, if you throw everything into a Plano tackle box it isn't a really big deal.

Your actions are limited, so you have to make them count. Planning wayyyyy ahead is a major part of the game.  And you have to make sure to have enough food at the end of each round.

This results in some really intense game play as you scramble to squeeze in your strategy into your actions and make them count!

Each game session is very different, even if you plan on executing the exact same strategy.  The unpredictability really keeps you on your toes. Every turn counts!

RATING: 9.5

RATING: 9.5
I quite enjoyed playing this game solo. It took me about an hour to set up and learn the rules but going forward I think I could teach this one pretty quickly. Seems like 3 might be the optimal number for this game but its going to take upwards of 3 hours. Fun hybrid of Agricola and Caylus. I like the fact that there are only 36 buildings and 5 types of ships. Not as steep a learning curve as Agricola and cuts down on the randomness as you always know what cards are coming out in the standard deck. Makes for more planning. I also like how you can switch from taking resources to leveraging a building in town or owned. My one point of confusion was around build vs. buy. [Edit: I played it wrong. Buildings and ships can built OR bought. Looks like I ended up with way more points than I thought!] Looking foward to another pass at this game.

RATING: 8
Played the once with 4p, took a while, but was enjoyable. So many options on where and how to play, simple enough concept, either take resources from an ever increasing pool, or use a building (once build or purchased) from yourself or another player to attempt to increase your money pool, with the ultimate aim to sell goods by shipping it. All players were new first time, so probably slowed the game down, but the myriad choices definitely was a brain burner

RATING: 9
Has taken over from Power Grid in my view as the crème de la crème of the board game world. This is exactly the kind of game I like: long-ish, meaty, economic without needing an XL spreadsheet to work out what do to (contrast with Container!) and a huge number of different strategies one can pursue. A good selection of buildings which you can build or even buy, the timing of the arrival of which varies with each game - and some random special buildings too.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Le Havre is easily my favorite Uwe Rosenberg game. It's a resource management game with no less than 16 resources to manage. Resources can be used to build buildings, as food, as energy or to be sold for money.
Le Havre biggest strenght is it's simple turn structure: either take some resources or use a building. Downtime is kept to an absolute minimum in this game, which is remarkable as it's a very deep game.
Interaction is indirect where you can take stuff another player needs or keep blocking a building to mess up someone's timing.
Like Agricola, there is a need to feed your crew but with Le Havre it's not as restricted. It doesn't warp your gameplay decisions too much. Sure, you have to pay attention to it, but you can still mainly focus on your big plan.
Another great feature is that it offers a short and a long game and for the first time the short game feels challenging in it's own right. Of course, I prefer the long game where there are more building interactions in play, but the short game doesn't feel stripped down at all. It is a good way to learn the game or to play when you don't have time or energy to play the long game.
Be warned, the game is very fiddly and you have to come up with a storage solution. The game wants you to put all resources on the board which makes it a giant mess. I use a big plano box instead.
The game feels very thematic and all the resource conversions make sense. Especially in the long game the interactions get a lot of fun. Yes, I'd like to sell sandwiches with smoked fish or build furniture with wood and leather. All of a sudden the tier 2 resources can become a viable strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite euro-style shipping game.  It has deep strategy without being confusing, and is surprisingly fast paced for a three hour game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Better than Agricola, although this just means its a great game, but not my #1.  I like the shipping theme a lot more than farming (although I will admit that the theme is thinner in this one), and it's really cool how you can turn resources into finished goods.  The number of actions stays constant, but I think it's slightly less tight than Agricola, making it tense without being frustrating and also avoiding the disappointing feeling you get in Agricola at the end where you feel that you're finally able to get somewhere but too bad the game is over.  I also give it high marks for player interaction, since you use (and block) other players' buildings.  The only downside is that it is a bit on the longer side.

UPDATE: While this game does seem to take quite a while, I do really enjoy it more and more as I feel it's a series of interesting tactical decisions and adaptation of your plan.  This is among my top games at this point.

UPDATE #2: It just continues to get better and better with age and in my opinion, it is Rosenburg's magnum opus.

RATING: 3
Too fiddly and too long. Also, it suffers by comparison to Agricola. Le Havre might offer more choices and more depth, but Agricola is deep enough for me. And because there are fewer choices in Agricola, there's more importance and more tension on each one. Everyone has to care about what everyone else is doing. Consequently, Le Havre lacks some of the narrative and sense of accomplishment of its older brother. It's also tedious in the same way as Through the Ages. Fans of one will likely enjoy the other. I need a better reason to play than the challenge of optimization through resource conversion.

RATING: 10
After game 3:

* Loans are OK, but more important is to have free food/coins to spend on visiting others.
* Its great to sell all your resources in a sequence of shipments - just make sure you don't end up selling junk.
* Buying the bank for 40 is not worth it.
* Steel (and Coke) is the most important resource. Get it from the start.
* Buy only steel ships - the iron ships are not worth the steel.

After game 2:

Brilliant game. Strategy - get the marketplace + 4 'home' buildings, and start collecting stuff, plus don't bother with food - take loans.

Won the game by shipping loads of stuff, but surprisingly Doron was too close with buying the later, more expensive buildings and ships.

Next time: Get loads of steel.

RATING: 9.5
A great worker placement resource management game! Play time is somewhat long, but you feel engaged the entire time -- it seems to move right along! A little less frustrating than Agricola and some other games, as you can often benefit from several actions (you don't need THAT particular one that the player before you just STOLE from you!!) -- the challenge is in figuring out how to make the most efficient plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like this game, it is a well-balanced, exciting worker placement game with a decent amount of depth that should bring with it a good amount of strategy.  Unfortunately, there are just so many outstanding worker placement games out there right now that this inevitably gets compared to them and that's where I find the biggest problem with this one.  There isn't enough variety to keep people from "solving" the game (in this case ship steel and coke) and to keep the game exciting through many plays.

But Le Havre is still an excellent game and for the occasional play (especially against newer players who haven't "solved" it and with whom you can try new interesting and fun strategies) I can't help but really enjoy it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
BestWith:3>2>4_not5. Never play with 5. Also Have: 12 Le Havre Special Building Cards (2008). Someone suggested to avoid having the Wind Farm in play.

Notes to Self: Recommendations by others to remove Special Buildings:
Remove from Solo Game, either because the buildings are intended to be interactive, or because they are overpowered in Solo mode: 014 Harbour Watch; 035 Zoo; 041 Pirates' Lair; 043 Dive Bar; 044 Picket Line; 045 Tobacco Factory; 046 Cattle Drive.
Remove generally (any player count) if you find buildings that encourage aggressive tactics annoying: 041 Pirates' Lair; 043 Dive Bar; 046 Cattle Drive.

RATING: N/A
14/11/08
Played with 4 players
I admit that this is a good game but it takes too much long and it's very repetitive. It's a very deep and strategic game and I like that. I supose that this rate could improve but I have to test it with fewer players. Maybe 3 players.

edit:
Played with 3 players and again with four. This time the pace of the game was much more interesting because players were familiar to the game. It improved a lot. I now know that I prefer this game with 4 players because although we have less actions than with 3, the truth is that the demanding for food is much more balanced allowing players to do different things. 

I still think the game is a bit too repetitive and long but it improved a lot. By now I really think I like to play it and that I should do so more often.

After a few more plays, I really like Le Havre. At first I didn't get it but after playing it with more care I realized that this is a very good game with lots of difficult things to combine as decisions to make: what building to build, when to build or buy, how to get food... always different decisions because the way buildings are organized makes each game a unique game and so does the way players play the game.

More aggressive play happens after players know the game better and best buildings are known. Being the butcher seems to work pretty fine and learning the exact timing of when to take a supply turn or an action turn is a key issue to success. 
I like to play it as a 2 player game too. Maybe it's how it works better because it doesn't have any down time and the number of actions per turn is much more interesting in order to make things workable as a small economy.

(G)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hmm. Is this the game that's going to make me like Caylus? First impressions not so great - The actions / building connections are not as intuitive as Agricola plus there is loads more of them, AP will be a problem. The actions are simple it's just the possibilities seem limitless. Feels far heavier than the 'Gric and not one i'm likely to try with non-gamers. Quite possible that i'm comparing with Agricola which is unfair.
2nd game impressions  - and like it a lot. Lots of very difficult choices, never quite enough resources, food requirement provides tension. 
The semi-random way the buildings come up gives the game great variety (and challenge) in the game experience - perhaps more so than Agricola.
1 4 Player game to pscore 160 (wharfs did not turn up early). Next 4 players game wharfs built early and top score 237. It's a lomg game but little downtime and feels far quicker than its 3 hour play time. My wife prefers this to Agricola.
The more i play the more i like. Agricola with specialisation and everyone having access to the same special actions. The timing of the wharfs being built combined with the special buildings determines the direction of the game.

Huge variety in the way the game evolves. 

Progressing up the exponential arc of the game feels like tightrope walking - a wobble means you spend a lot of precious time regaining balance. The game requires patience, its very easy to overextend in mid game with what seems a good build, only to find its too early.

Nothing in 2009 or 10 (August) has bettered Le Havre. Ditto July 2011. 

ipad version. Lovely interface AI not great but I enjoy trying out new things against the 'pad.

------------------

20th Play in 2015 and my tastes have changed. Admire the design but find the goods churning conversion not as entertaining as in 2008.

RATING: 8

Maybe it is because of my first play, but I really do not like not having a market where goods can be traded.  It does take too long to play.  I can see the play time being significantly reduced on future plays, but in order to be even marginally competitive, you need to plan for minimum 4 actions ahead, which takes some time and way to much concentration.

RATING: 9
Awesome worker placement game. Lots of angst trying to get everything you want to do done. Numerous paths to victory, along with a varied card mix makes this a fun and different experience each game. I really like that while feeding your workers is necessary and it's important to get ships or an engine to feed them, the penalty for not having enough now to do so isn't back breaking like it is in Agricola.

Side note - Having storage trays with lids that are shaped to fit on the board during game play make set up and clean up a breeze. Without these, it is tedious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After my second play, I don't think it's that good after all. I played the shortened version with two. It was both too long and too short: we played pretty fast, but it took an hour anyway. But it still felt very unsatisfying. Most of the buildings hadn't been used at all, and we were mostly busy getting enough food. Steel and cokes never entered play, not did we manage to ship goods.

I think Le Havre tries to do too much. Lots of different buildings to use, but too little time to explore even a substantial part of them. So even when you play a couple of games of the full version, it's still hard to grasp what might be meaningful strategies.

Despite all its rough edges, sameness and imbalances, I vastly prefer Agricola over Le Havre. Compared with Agricola, Le Havre just feels... redundant. 

--------
One play, not finished. I liked this better than anticipated. The obvious game to compare this with is Agricola, with which it has many similarities. Le Havre is both more gamey and smoother. Individual turns and rounds are over rather quickly, unless you have some serious AP players. Half a game is not remotely enough to see some strategies. Looking forward to my next play.

RATING: N/A
Robert's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Initial impression is, that despite its big complexity this is very neatly balanced game. No idea, how Uwe manages to design such complex games with  a bundle of possibilities and still keep the balance... but he did it again! Fine work!
After the first introductory games you should begin to know the ~ 45 building-cards (which are by the way the same in each game - with the exception of special buildings) and go ahead developing a "master plan". No master plan, no victory points. There is quite a lot of end-game strategies and the earlier in the game, you start designing your strategie around one of them, the better! You should have a close look at what the plans of the other players are and adjust your strategy accordingly.
A lot of interaction, nice game mechanics, a huge bundle of strategies to explore, easy access, smooth learning curve = it all sums up to a very big potential for a new star!
Yes - if you really need to, compare it to Agricola. But the strongest reason for comparing is, that both games were designed by Uwe (which is a quality indicator itself). Indeed, both games play very differently and give a unique game-experience, so it is rather hard to compare them. Anyway, if you love Agricola, you will most probably love LeHavre. Because of the good time it gives you and its rewarding of deliberate strategies.

One of my "Must-Buy"s at Essen!

RATING: 6.5
A very good turning stuff into other stuff (and, eventually, points) game with a long enough arc to allow for genuine strategy and strategic variation. There's some fun room for tactical screwage, too.

Newbies should expect to be thrashed by experienced players.

The biggest obstacle to my play is that I think it needs very regular play to really work: it's harder or slower or both unless all players know what every building does and understand how resource requirements change. Since I tend to be a gamer of the "many games, each played infrequently" variety, this is a high obstacle to play.

Also, good as it is, I think it is strictly worse than Ora et Labora, which feels like a more refined version of the same idea: a more elegant resource system, an additional spatial element, and perhaps more balanced strategies. I don't think I would ever choose to play Le Havre instead.
