=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[Lookout Games 08 edition with 12 bonus cards] {Economic; resources-management, variable-building-powers, loans; optimal 2-4p} {Short Game 7, Full Game 8} Le Havre is a nicely designed economic game.  It's thematic and very interactive.  The building mechanic is similar to Caylus; but it's slightly lighter.  It's multifaceted. There are multiple paths of winning: ship building, goods trading/shipping, special building, etc.  Players have to carefully plan in advance due to limited number of actions and resources.  They also have to adjust the plan wisely, esp. with the Special Building cards.  Resources are really tight (similar to Agricola) and players have to use their resources wisely!  Replayability seems good with the various combinations of building cards.

There is down-time between turns; esp. as the game progresses and more buildings become available.  It's quite unforgiving, if a player planned poorly and cannot sustain a good resource income, he's essentially out of the game.  It also feels a bit repetitive - 20 rounds may be too much.  The hidden special buildings could affect the game plan quite much.  It may annoy hardcore players who prefer perfect-information. 

In all, it's a good game but it's too long for 4/5 players.

The illustration is colorful and cute.  I like it.  The production quality is quite good.  Nonetheless, there are some usability problems. Firstly, the dual face of each counter may lead to confusion when a player hits the table, etc.  Secondly, the iconography on the cards is not intuitive enough; I need to refer to the rulebook to understand their meaning.  Thirdly, they should provide an insert to hold the components.

Lastly! my box arrived severely damaged.  The box cover is crumbled heavily and split.  Even the board and markers are crumbled!  I am very sad.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I can really appreciate the complexity of this game. All of the pieces fit together in very interesting ways. But, I just don't find it to be very fun.

Last played: Feb 2011
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A very interesting brain-burner that has some definite similarities but is distinct enough to be judged on its own worth and not as any sort of copycat or revamp.  Seriously agonizing decisions to be made due to a severe shortage of actions.  Just as in many other games--including Agricola and Through the Ages--there is simply not NEARLY enough time to do what you want, so you have to make due with what you can.  Lots of potential for min/maxing your moves, which makes me wary; that sort of game tends to lead to SEVERE AP problems, the like of which put me off of Caylus to a large extent.  But hopefully people can learn to plan their turns ahead of time--it seems like downtime could become a serious problem otherwise in a many-playered game.  Still, some really neat mechanics going on and a nice, satisfying feeling of having built an economy by the end.  It may be too long for me to want to play often, but I enjoyed my first game of it.

RATING: 9
1-5 / 12+ / 150'
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8


First off, I love any game that is legitimately fun solo.

Second, I can't remember the last game that I wanted to play again as badly after first play(s).

Constant planning (tactics and strategy), variable game play, variable paths to victory, beautiful components, borrows well from Agricola (and many others) while producing several subtle and elegant innovations (love the ships, love the way the building stacks are done, love the buying/building/selling of buildings).

Different feel from Agricola too which was a definite concern going in.  I think I like it better, time will tell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Reminds me of a mix between Agricola (for the upkeep cost of food, the resource collecting, and worker placement part) mixed with Caylus (for the building / purchase of buildings and people using those having to pay the owner of the building). Although I don't like it as much as Agricola, mainly due to the near openness of player information, I still think it is a great game.

UPDATE: After playing it a few dozen times the game definitely feels samey. The randomness in the initial distribution, good locations, and special buildings isn't usually enough to make the gameplay varied. Some special buildings can really mix it up, but those feel far and few between. Wish there was more replayability here, but it is still a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
(2010-12-12) I liked this a lot more than I thought I would. It looks like a resource euro, but plays similar to a card game (like RftG). 

Update (2016-02-09) With only one worker per player and with buildings having non-accumulating effects, most of the options in the game are really just false choices. This leads to a strict dominance of coal/steel strategies in the endgame. It's not a total loss - there are still tactical choices to be made at any given time - but it sure takes off a lot of the shine off this game. Sold and rating goes down to 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Outstanding worker-placement Euro. The gameplay is extraordinarily simple, you either choose to take goods from an ever increasing supply from the board, or you construct a building with the goods you have already acquired. Each building is unique and once built they provide means for collecting more goods, upgrading goods, or selling goods. Victory points are accumulated through the money you have amassed and the value of the buildings you own. This is such a strategic game and the paths one can take to success are numerous as the number of buildings and options increases greatly throughout the game. The balance of play is flawless, which makes 'Le Havre' one of the finest games ever made.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

with the complete set of 12 additional Special Buildings.

With its lengthiness, it won't hit the table often, but when it does I'll certainly vie for a seat.

My brain was ready to eat it self by the end of the game.  I believe I like Agricola better because of the slightly softer feeding curve. **UPDATE** one of the first games I'm actually considering not getting because of the length (because other people have it and because I have Agricola).  This is strange, because I generally don't mind long games. Maybe my rating has room to move down? Want to play more! 2009/02/26

I've played the digital (iOS) version only. I easily have over 50 plays on my iPhone.

This game really surprised me. I knew it was a great game, but I wasn't sure if I would like it due to the worker placement component that I tend to shy from and the dryer theme I wasn't super thrilled about. Boy, am I glad I gave it a try. Each turn is based with difficult decisions, that all lead to a different positive outcome. There's no "bad" moves, just some moves are better than others and it's a great puzzle trying to solve which is which. 

The more I play this game, the better it gets. New cards provide a fresh experience, while playing with different numbers of opponents also changes the game and strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Interesting game, clearly descendant of Agricola: you build up an engine by using buildings and try to be 'ready' for the food collection round, much like Agricola.

The differing gameplay comes from the fact that you can buy these buildings instead of only use them. To me, this doesn't make the game better, as it seems to add another layer of unnecessary complexity to the Agricola system. It potentially adds a lot of Analysis Paralysis to the game, though it ups replayability. However, with all its small and big expansions, Agricola has no problems with that either...

As I own both, but Agricola has nicer components and is more family friendly, I can't see this hitting the table a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Excellent resource management game, with a variable action limits mechanic.  First person in a turn gets the most action limits, and this first person mechanic moves clockwise so that everyone at the table gets 3 actions in a given turn, if I recall correctly.  Endless variety of ways to win, in regards to how you use your resources.   Simple game, easy to set up but does take a stretch of time to complete, with our group usually setting on about 3 hours to play.  I'd recommend this game if you have the time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I stayed away for a number of years because I saw comments saying it was too similar to Agricola, and that the building camping aspect was too mean. Wow, what a mistake. This game stands solidly on its own feet. The puzzle is interesting, the resources plentiful, and buildings make great thematic sense - like how cows are turned into meat and hides. Very cool.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like the diversity and distinctness of the resources in this game -- wood has completely different uses than cattle, etc.  

A few things hold it back for me.  Firstly, the game has the same flow each game;  build buildings early, then transition into getting ships, then get steel and coke, then liquidate everything.  Secondly, the resources are the same for each player in every game (contrast with Agricola where the occupations and improvements give different ways to use resources to each player).  Thirdly, the endgame requires more strict planning than the rest of the game.  You need to know how many actions you have left, and what the best way is to get rid of everything.

I like everything else enough that I happily accept those issues I have!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A tough and slick worker placement game that definitely requires a few plays to fully understand. The available buildings really depend on the number of players and the game feels quite different when playing with two vs three or four.
That being said, I'd rather play Ora et Labora or Caverna for my Ewe fix.

I've been playing it on the iPad a lot and I really like not having to mess with the chits :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I first played [thing=31260][/thing] nearly 10 years ago and it is one of my favorite Euros.  Somehow, I didn't get a chance to play [thing=35677][/thing] until now.  In many ways, Le Havre is a classic [person=10][/person] game.  Worker placement, getting various resources, feeding your people, etc.  There are a few key differences though:

1) You only have one worker.  I really liked the simplicity of this.  Blocking other players has always been one of my lower-ranked qualities of worker placement games, so this mechanic creates less blocking (which I like).  But, you also don't [i]have to[/i] move your worker, so there is still the opportunity to lock down an action if you want to.

2) The resources have basic versions and advanced versions.  Fish become smoked fish, clay becomes brick, etc.  Simple concept that was executed nicely in Le Havre.

3) Turn order varies randomly, but so does the number of actions you get per round.  There are 7 total turns per round and the first player changes, so your number of actions depends on the player count and who the first player is.  We played with 4 and I didn't like the fact that you would on occasion get only 1 action.  But with 2 or 3 players, you would instead on occasion get an extra action.

In my one play I focused on a shipping strategy because that seemed to be the goal of the game.  I felt like I did pretty well, but my opponent that went for a building strategy completely annihilated everyone else.  Also, we got a few minor rules wrong.  Now that I understand the strategy a bit and understand the rules, I need to give this another try (preferably with 2 or 3).  I don't foresee this passing [thing=31260][/thing] for me, but I think it is my second favorite Rosenberg game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
I'm not a big fan of how forgiving this game is, how lacking in direction and how plentiful resources are. It lacks that crunchy, tense feel that I like in a lot of mid to heavy euros. A lot of euros I'm excited about the process, and have a plan of attack or a feel for what I want to do; while I can do that to a degree in Le Havre, I sometimes feel like I am wandering aimlessly through the game. And perhaps that is what makes it accessible to gamers who usually shy away from euros like this. 

Having said that though, there is quite a bit I do like about Le Havre. I like the buildings, the 'feed your people' mechanism which does provide some tension and constraint, and the theme. There are some unique elements to it, and I do enjoy decisions such as when to build buildings and what, and particularly when it is worth sucking it up and using your opponent's buildings. Knowing your opponent will have to use yours is always nice. 

I think Le Havre is a great game, but just doesn't quite hit my buttons like I want it to. But still a joy to play.

RATING: 7.5

If the game didn't take so long I'd like it a lot more, but with so many shorter games that provide an equal or greater amount of fun, I don't think this is ever likely to be in my top 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Billed as a cross between Agricola and Caylus, I don't like Le Havre as well as either of those titles. On the plus side, this is very simple to teach and presents players with tons of options and tough decisions. On the downside, the game is a bit too long and a tad fiddly (using cards with tiny symbols that sit in front of the other players is the most blatent example of this). My rating may go up a bit over time, and I think Le Havre may have some staying power, but I don't envision this ever becoming a real favorite or hitting the table on a regular basis. Update: I enjoy Le Havre much better as a two-player game. It's still a bit fiddly, but it moves along at a much better clip and has some real depth with two players. Rating revised upward to 8 based on Le Havre at a two-player affair. With more, I'd rate it lower. Updated update: Rated as a 9 now, but again almost entirely on its strength as a two-player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Go is my favorite game , well, Le Havre is the second. I really enjoy playing it. In my opnion is the most elegant eurogame that I 've played. It is both tactical and strategic. Chance is perfectly controlled. It is a challenging game but not has prevented me from starting a lot of people to eurogames. It seems far superior to Agricola that even being good game seems overrated. Le Havre is demanding and every game a different feel without losing its intensity.

RATING: 7.5
Playing with others definitely changes the game. So many things to do, so many mouths to feed, but so few actions. This game should work great 2 or 3 player, but 4 might be pushing it. I will not even try it with 5. You get tons of cardboard for your money, a fairly straightforward game with lots of tough decisions to be made. Set up time can be a bit much, but if you get storage containers for the goods, it should be manageable. Player aid/mat is a very nice addition and a great way of sorting the goods. I bought extra Settlers of Catan buildings to be placed on a building that you have built so the building cards can remain in the middle of the table so that everybody can be able to read them and easily access them. It worked really well in the one game played with them. If you're looking for a brain burner, this is an awfully good one.

RATING: 7
Racing to be the most successful (i.e. richest) shipping magnate in Le Havre, France. Many paths to take to making the most money (i.e. points), and it's not about scarcity as much as it is about wealth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
ONE PLAY--SOLO.  Tough to say how I feel about Le Havre yet.  There is a ton more going on in the game than you might gather on the first reading of the rules.  At least my brain sure was swimming.

After a second play, in which 3 of us only got half through in 3 hours, this is a long game.  It takes a long time to get going, and once it gets going, it can become a bit rote.  After all buildings are bought, it is merely a race for shipping and feeding.  

But for some reason, it is a tremendous game in spite of factors that would normally kill a game for me.  Its scope is too large, and there are so many steps to go through to get to where you want to go.  Now, I will readily admit that I suppose real life shipping and dock work is likely much the same way.  But c'mon, this game really makes a player work for what they get.  Is that entertainment?  Is that why we play games?  

The reason to play Le Havre is the sheer challenge of it--to see who can be the most effective businessman.  There are several reasons that I like this game--shared buildings, the accumulating resources, resource management.  And there are several reasons that I hate it--length of game, lack of a compelling theme, mechanicalness of it all.  

But in the end, I find myself thinking about it long after I play.  It is a rare game that can cause that to happen.

FURTHER UPDATE:  Starting to feel a bit rote to me.  Each game plays differently, but man, it can really descend into the depths of the ultra-mechanical.  The last several rounds simply become go-here, convert-this, go-here, convert-this, head to the shipping yard, do it all over again ad nauseum.  It really can become extremely cyclical and, because it takes quite awhile (I don't care who you are, the listed time frames are way out of whack.  They might work for someone who has played this game many many times.  Might.) that is not a good thing.  

I still like it, but I do think that it is overrated, a criticism I had previously only given Race for the Galaxy.  It takes a long time to play.  It can be very very mechanical and soul-less.  

If you like competitive accounting, you will like Le Havre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Well, for starters, I like this much better than Agricola. There's so much more freedom and opportunity to actually have fun.

I don't really like the continual (and, in this case, increasing) "demand that needs to be met" mechanic Le Havre shares with Agricola. Competition from the other players should provide enough impetus for you to push forward in the game. But, in Le Havre's case, it doesn't detract too much because it is much more easily managed.

Like Agricola, there is a lot going on. You find yourself trying to figure out how many turns you have (7*# of turns/# of players+1) and working out what needs to be done and what would be nice. This can get tiring and unfun if you're not careful. Of course, you can't depend on goods being there or buildings being available, so this isn't too much of an issue. I've only played 2 player. With more players, this will likely be even less of an issue as planning will become more difficult.

Overall, this is pretty enjoyable and I don't see any glaring issues yet. I'm not rating Le Havre yet, but if I did, it would be about a 6.5-7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Long game where the end sneaks up on you.  At the beginning it seems like you have a million actions ahead of you, and then all of a sudden you realize you've only got seven actions left in the game.

Playing with experienced players is a real plus, as the first few games can be excruciatingly long (at least if you're playing with me).  I like two-player, since it's quick(er) and it's your turn so often.  Three seems like it could be good, as well.  The four-player games have taken so long, that I'm not sure I'd want to play with that count again.

13 games in, and it's feeling a little samey (at least in two player games).  Maybe it's just that the two of us are stuck in groupthink, but it seems like there are a fixed number of strategies.  I keep playing this, although I'm not sure why.  Seems like a lot of time for only a little payoff in fun/brainwork.

I ended up trading this, and am not looking to play it again.  It feels like there are several better options out there.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A classic luckless eurogame with a paste on theme. The idea is to reward those who choose the best action(s) each round, making the process progressively more complex as the game continues.

In the end, the game is indeed rewarding the best player, but it's a tedious and tiring procedure. Every round is twice as complex and important as the previous one, and it quickly becomes a matter of mental endurance as much as tactics/strategy. For me it stops being fun after round 10-11 when the options are just overwhelming and average players either succumb to analysis paralysis or ignore (intentionally or not) half+ the actions and thus practically ruin their chances for victory. 

A pity, I expected far more from this particular designer.

RATING: 9
So...many...choices. So...many...paths to victory! Le Havre is so simple to play, yet so complex. What I mean is that the gameplay is very simple- you either take goods or use a building action. The thing that makes it complex is that there are a bajillion different resources and a bajillion different building actions to be taken. The economy this game creates is insane, and I love it! Very dry though and hard to get to the table.

RATING: 10
I am a sucker for games that have many currencies which must be reduced down to time and available actions.  It is not quite as distilled as Goa does this, but the layers upon layers of depth and the different ways the game unfolds due to the building order.  Two games in, and I much prefer the lower food requirements in the three player games instead of the two player game.  The two player game feels differently but still quite enjoyable.  The progression in this game from early, middle, and end is truly fun.  I love how this game starts out tight, opens up dramatically, and tightens back up at the end.  I need to play this more and soon.

The game seems extra amazing when the special buildings are special.  I do like that they timing of them may result in a blank for a game change as well.  Its pretty awesome.

The mechanics of your turn are simple to execute, but finding the move you want is excruciating.    Easily my favorite "gamer's game."  Six plays in and I still haven't played with 4 or 5.  With 3 this will always be my first choice.

RATING: 2
3 games down and it's a good game no doubt about that. I really am not sure why people compare it so closely to Agricola as it doesn't feel like that game at all. Sure you have to feed and that's a fundamental element of each round but that doesn't yield the same game. Le Havre is nowhere near as dynamic of a game as Agricola. The standard buildings are constants whereas your hand of Minors/Occupations changed every game. I like this game it's fun and will continue to play it and develop my thoughts on it as time goes by. 

UPDATE: I've got to play this one several more times and there are just some things about the game that I simply don't enjoy...at all. I find the game tedious, not fun. Choices limited after the one you wanted is gone. I've tried playing it 2, 3, 4 and yes even 5 and am at the point now where I can see that the game is a well developed game and that a lot of people are going to enjoy this experience but for me I find it quite miserable. My above comments show that once I had an understanding I had hope for a fun game but one just never developed for me.

RATING: 8.2
3.76
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Le Havre is Uwe Rosenberg’s much anticipated sequel to Agricola, which gives it the same hurdle that confronted Mammoth Hunters when it was Alea’s sequel to Puerto Rico. Given that obstacle, Le Havre is being surprisingly well received, and with good reason. I played Le Havre twice at BGG.CON, where it was in almost constant play, and believe that I enjoy and will continue to enjoy it significantly more than Agricola. I’ve never been especially enamored with Agricola, which I’ve always thought is good (with the drafting variant), but not great. I think the plethora of Occupation and Minor Improvement cards in Agricola is more of a distraction than anything else, and I feel like the short time span of the game coupled with the incessant harvest demands makes it a frustrating experience of trying to build an engine in artificially cramped quarters. Le Havre on the other hand feels like a more wide open playground, and while there are vaguely similar feeding demands in Le Havre, they’re not as overwhelming or crushing as in Agricola because you can always spend money instead of food, and you can always take a loan for more money. Importantly, loans in Le Havre are not nearly as devastating as Begging cards in Agricola so being unprepared for a harvest or two in Le Havre is not a huge problem. The number of options, turns, resources, and methods for creating victory points in Le Havre are huge, which gives the game its wide open feeling. I did feel like the game overstayed its welcome when playing with 4 inexperienced players, but the game claims to play much quicker with 2 and 3 players, so I’m hopeful that I can pack the tense decision-making of Le Havre into 90 minutes with 3 experienced players. The 2.5 hours that it took was too long for what it offered, but 90 minutes would be dense enough to merit repeated plays to more fully explore this intriguing title.

Pre-ordered on October 13, 2008

RATING: 5.5
Just okay. Could grow on me, as one of the problems seems to be that the stuff you need to do in the endgame requires several steps toward longer-terms goals you better have known were coming. This is not so cool the first time you play.
Intellectually, a reasonably engaging resource-pushing optimization problem.
Thematically really uninteresting. What are we building, a castle? A cathedral? Oh, a port.
Seems to have a lot of down time without much reason to pay attention to other players' turns. Dizzying array of options tends to cause analysis paralysis. Left me wanting another game to play in between my turns. Would be keener to try it again if there were fewer players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game involves significant amount of interaction between players. Players need to have some knowledge of the buildings' effects otherwise he can be in a disadvantage position. Active blocking or first-come first-serve is important in this game. 


There are many possible actions to take as the game progresses when more buildings are being constructed or built by the players. Hence, it is important to prioritise the actions required otherwise one may end up taking sub-optimal actions which does not eventually increase the VP.

Replayability may be limited given that the standard buildings , which make up a significant number, are always the same across each game. The only difference is the special buildings introduced, which are quite limited in number.

Haven't given it enough of a chance to properly rate it, because I don't like it enough after a couple of play-throughs to keep bothering with it. My latest frustration is the queue that forms for the Shipping Line in the last two or three rounds. It shifts from engine-building to waiting in line to redeem your engine, trying to jump the queue. Fun if you jump the queue, aggravating if you get jumped and run out of time. I absolutely think it's me, not the game, and I haven't gotten anywhere near good enough at it to properly evaluate it (not fair to give it a low ranking), but I'm done trying.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In Le Havre, a player’s turn consists of two parts: First, distribute newly supplied goods onto the offer spaces; then take an action. As an action, players may choose either to take all goods of one type from an offer space or to use one of the available buildings. Building actions allow players to upgrade goods, sell them or use them to build their own buildings and ships. Buildings are both an investment opportunity and a revenue stream, as players must pay an entry fee to use buildings that they do not own. Ships, on the other hand, are primarily used to provide the food that is needed to feed the workers.

After every seven turns, the round ends: players’ cattle and grain may multiply through a Harvest, and players must feed their workers. After a fixed number of rounds, each player may carry out one final action, and then the game ends. Players add the value of their buildings and ships to their cash reserves. The player who has amassed the largest fortune is the winner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Interesting "action selection" game in the same category as Agricola, but definitely different. Much more than in Agricola, you have to put a lot of effort in establishing a system for producing food. The amount of food you need at the end of the turn increases quite fast from beginning to end (independent of the actions you choose). Halfway through the game, there seem to be so many options that my brain started to freeze during my first play. Rules are not difficult to explain, but it definitely takes one or more games to fully understand what you could to to win. In that sense, the learning curve is quite steep: I cannot see a first timer win from someone who played it once or twice before. This might have something to do with the fact that knowing the cards is a real advantage: Mainly because you will know which options will become available later in the game, and also because it can be hard to read the properties of the cards lying in front of other players (which you can also use). So, all in all a very enjoyable game, but there are not many people in my circle of friends with whom I could play this. Agricola is much more accessible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
October 2016: Sold on Geekmarket. I do enjoy this game, but it just didn't see enough play amongst my gaming group, and doesn't offer enough that's different compared to other euro games. You buy different buildings that each convert goods in different ways, and then you can sell those goods for money.

Enjoy this one more than Agricola. Feels very similar to a lot of worker placements though. Will have to play again to figure out where this one sits.

RATING: 7.5
I like the fact that it's a randomized setup and that there's a lot of thinking/factors to consider-- I felt that I could take the length of the game, which is weird since I dislike Risk, Agricola, or most other 2-3 hour Euros (also see Dungeon Lords). I feel that if someone's running away with the game, it's hard to slow him down-- but that's also a flaw with most other Euros, so I'm not docking this game for that.

I guess I also like that there's just enough other player interaction-- you're not actively going to screw each other over (I don't like the idea of being knocked out for an hour but not able to leave due to balance), but you do have to pay attention to what others do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Fantastic follow-up to Agricola - uses a worker-placement mechanism and has harvest round but plays very differently. Cards provide a lot of variability but as cards are available to all players, doesn't have the potential for skewed games via a bad deal. Only drawback is the game length, which can be upwards of 3 hours with 4 rookies, even with the "short" game - but gameplay is so "snappy" (little wait between turns) and the choices so engrossing that time flies. Also doesn't have the "fiddliness" of Agricola as resources are replenished a little at a time and continuously before each player's turn instead of at the end of each round. Love this and hope to play a lot more. I can see Le Havre becoming a "10" with more plays.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A game that really makes you feel like you accomplished something, regardless of whether or not you won.  More like Roads and Boats than Agricola.  More player interaction, too.  Also, more of a puzzle game than a worker placement game.  Fun game.  Somewhat brain burning.  A little too long for everyday play.  Edit: after several plays we have this game at the 1-1/2 hour range (2 player).  Now we can fit it in during the work week.  Great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Will probably give us many headaches.

Our first game gave us that drooling, slack-jawed, misty-eyed look that meant we had no idea what to do but we were having fun.

After three games this one bears some resemblance to a non-gaming activity--retirement planning.  The game really seems to be about getting the exponential growth curve started ASAFP.  I'm sort of thinking of the game as three phases.  In the first, you plan to get a ship while feeding yourself.  In the second, you've got a ship or two and are weaning yourself off food.  The third is when you no longer care at all about food and are focused solely on the final score.

The increasing cost to feed feels a lot like inflation.  I also like how some of the paths are reigned in by the limits on the cards.

This one really feels like an 8 right now with the strong potential to climb to a 9 in a few more plays.  I like that the game still feels good with both 2 and 3 players but is still different.  I suppose we'll have to try it with four sometime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Like Agricola, theme (and artwork) matches the mechanics very well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The best parts of Caylus and Agricola are brought together in a very well balanced and exciting game.  

The game does run rather long, but rules for a "shorter game" are included, and they are extremely well balanced.  On the whole, it is about 50% longer and 50% more complex than Agricola.  There are no random setup elements equivalent to the minor improvements and occupations in Agricola, and this really gives the game a lot more balance.

Simplicity and ease of play for new gamers are among the qualities I look for in games that I rate 8+.  If I didn't take those into account, this game would be a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
Edit: I played again, a full game this time where the rules were better explained, and I enjoyed it much more! We played the basic/quick game which is *definitely* the way to got for learning the game (just like with Agricola you really want to start with the family game). Big bump in the rating.

Just not my game. As one review said, it makes me want to play other, better games (Shipyard, Caylus, Puerto Rico, Agricola).

I did only get to play the introductory/quick game, and only a half game, so perhaps it gets more interesting as the game goes on. As it was, it seemed like all I was doing was collecting goods and spending goods and occasionally using a building. The game simply seemed very repetitive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm going to attempt the impossible, and evaluate Le Havre first on it's own merits before comparing it to it's hyped predecessor, [gameid=31260]. There's a lot of choices, and I really like the slow buildup of resources. The long playtime, a negative in most games of this type, is surprisingly a strength. It's viable to be opportunistic in the early game to build up large amounts of energy and food reserves that you can exploit later, or you can try to rush out to a quick start. The interplay of buildings and having to pay a player to enter his buildings is a neat idea. This is one of those rarities: a resource gathering euro that doesn't feel dry as all hell.

Now, here's the comparison to Agricola.  More open-ended, and more appealing to me.  Oddly, Le Havre seems to have less emphasis on player blocking than its older counterpart, even though as a game about markets and shipping, there would be more real-life interaction between different companies than there would be in a medieval farming village.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
-Mmm, so good. Played two shortened solo games and it's love at first play, can't wait to see what the full multiplayer game provides. And now a third full-game. This some really tight time management and just lots of fun. 
-Such a different experience playing two-player, no surprise I guess, but neat and different.

-The more I play solo, the more options I see available and the more I see how you can refine your strategy to a sharp exacting point, which creates an interesting dynamic to the much more variable 2-player. 
It's such an appealing puzzle piece, and the components and art are so cute and absorbing, it always make me want to come back, but then I lose interest either because the lack of pressure/dynamic in solo or because I can play as much as I want in a short amount of time, so I need to try 2-player some more before I rate. 1/25/14
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
One three-player game behind, two newbies didn't combine enough points to beat the winner... :)

I was expecting a shorter game, and wasn't very fresh or focused and when the game went on and on, I just wished it to end. I did some "good" moves, but I didn't have a long-time plan, which lead to the situations, where I just had no idea what to do next.

In the game you need to gather resources, build buildings and ships and use the latter two to process resources to better resources or money. There are lots of different resources and different buildings, so it is not very easy for the first timers.

I can see why some people like this game, but these engine building games (at least on this level) are not my favorite games. At least not when they are this long. With some experience, it gets faster of course, but it also gets longer, if there are more players.

RATING: 6
I love the narrative arc in Le Havre- you really feel a sense of development as you transition from the early to mid and finally the late game, and each stage has its own unique feel and challenges. The tactical decisions can be excruciating and (despite what some critics say) there is genuinely a breadth of strategies to pursue. The ordering of the building queue and the special cards really cement this game's replayability. 

UPDATE: After ~50 plays the game has begun to feel procedural. While I will always enjoy playing Le Havre, for its length there are now other games that capture my imagination and interest more.

RATING: N/A
5p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The comparisons to Agricola are just, and unjust at the same time.  On the one hand, there's a farming/building aspect to the game, and there's a worker placement aspect to the game; on the other, the tactics are a little less obvious, and the game requires a stronger focus on strategy than its predecessor.  There's an additional screwage factor in the game, too, since a player token on a building means that no one else can get there if you own it, so you can squat on a good building to prevent other players from using it.  Still, doing so will hurt you more in the long run, since you're not taking advantage of your own turns by using other buildings.  The economic engine is wound more tightly, and isn't as easy to grasp, but I think that, with more experience, I would find myself liking it more.  That being said, I would never play this INSTEAD of Agricola, since the two games feel very different.

1 play: 3 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is every bit as good as Agricola and at the moment, I think I like it more. The worker placement aspect is toned down and there isn't nearly the variety in card play, but I find the resource conversions to be way more interesting. In Le Havre, you can build an entire supply line instead of being limited to just switching one good directly to another. Many resources have multiple uses and they can be combined any number of ways to further your goals. Admittedly, the small bit of worker placement that carried over from Agricola does function a little strangely. Buying and selling buildings to the town to clear them of workers feels contrived, but I suppose real world concepts like multiple carpenters in one town have been nudged aside in the name of creating an interesting competition for resources.

Le Havre is longer and certainly not as cute as Agricola, but once you get comfortable with the resource chains it feels like a much more open-ended game. The endgame scoring is basically cash on hand (plus properties), which is a much more satisfying goal than the seemingly arbitrary point values awarded to the farms in Agricola. I love Agricola's near endless re-playability, but all things considered, I believe that Le Havre is a better overall game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Adrian
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Obviously I like this quite a bit from my rating, so I'll start with what I don't like. It's probably the most fiddly game I've ever played, both in terms of having to perpetually move around the bits and nitpicky rules that are easily overlooked. It also seems fairly long, and i don't know that I'd ever want to try this with more than 3. All that said, I like that there are multiple paths to victory here and that it plays fairly differently depending on which way you want to go, something that can't be said about many other Euros.

Also, this game helped me put together a piece of the puzzle in terms of what I personally like and dislike about games - and, in this case, the X factor that often makes some games a 9 for me and others an 8 (on the BGG scale). I was thinking about this compared to Agricola (a 9 for me), and I think they are very, very different games; in fact, were it not for the "Harvest Trilogy" label, I wouldn't have considered them and Loyang to be much more related than Tigris & Euphrates and Ra. Le Havre seemed closer in feel to me to Puerto Rico (an 8 for me) than Agricola, and I realized that what made the difference was the cards you get in Agricola. Because you have a different hand of cards each time in that game, the game state is dramatically different each time, and thus it tests your ability to react to the specific circumstances rather than straight up efficiency at the game. The hidden information about your opponents' hands also means that you're less confident about their next moves and have to rely more on the meta-game. While Le Havre is not Puerto Rico in the sense that there is much more randomness, you still have close to perfect information about your opponent and, while the order of the buildings are randomized, they're still predictable (the special buildings do help this, but they don't change the game as drastically as the occupations and minor improvements in Agricola do). Basically, in Le Havre and PR, I feel like you could make a mathematically optimal move each turn given enough time assuming the other player is also playing optimally, whereas a game like Agricola allows for more divergent strategies and requires a lot more interplay between the players (not just because of the cards, either, but I think that's the main significant difference).

Again, all of that is not much of a negative about Le Havre; I still rate it an 8, and I can definitely see why it's considered a top-tier game and many prefer it to Agricola. For me, personally, I think the things mentioned in the last paragraph take ever-so-slightly away from it and are probably mostly responsible for that lost point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

I especially appreciate the low rules overhead: you pretty much get straight to the action.

For solo or 2p (or really any count, but lower counts are most in need of help), I've been pleased with a variant changing shipping value of coke to 3F (from 5F). This creates broader options than the numbing main path of coal/coke.

RATING: 5
ios

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i]I've only played this game with 2 players so far. I have to try it with 3, I think there are more viable strategies with more buildings in play.[/i]

Good game from Uwe Rosenberg. I revisited it after a few years and I like it better than I used to (I'm bumping the rating from 6 to 7). It works really well with 2 players, it has a nice pace to it. I love the simplicity of the core actions and the overall sense of development and progress. There's a lot of crunchy, tough decisions to be made in this game. 

But as much as I enjoy Le Havre I still do have some problems with it. There's something wrong with the loan system, I can't really put my finger on it, but it seems you can abuse it in a weird way. Also, the game might feel a little samey due to the layout of buildings: yes, they appear in different order, but they are those same buildings from game to game so most of the time everything comes down to shipping massive amounts of coke late game - there are probably other paths to victory, but this one seems the most viable (the coal-to-coke conversion is free and unlimited). Fortunately the special buildings inject some variety to the gameplay. And although there are only four of them in the 2P game, they still might impact your long term strategy.

One more thing - replenishing resources before every turn is really fiddly and there's no way around it. 

/update: I think that Ora et Labora might actually replace Le Havre for me as a go-to resource conversion game. It adds a spatial puzzle and removes the feeding aspect (which didn't fit Le Havre at all to be honest, it felt forced and disjointed from the rest of the game). OeL seemed overwhelming to me at first, but I think it's just a deeper experience. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
brilliant design, good theme, good artwork, and solid mechanics come together to make one of my favorites A+!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fairly typical Euro optimization game where you turn stuff into other stuff and combine it with more stuff for even more stuff.  Started sluggish, but became interesting as the number of turns left ticked down to just a few.  Similar gaming experience for me as Puerto Rico or Agricola, less the role selection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A solid economic engine game,  but fairly straightforward collect your resources/buy buildings/grind into points.  Add back in the "feed your people" seen in Stone Age/Agricola.

Some nice touches though - the flippable counters allow you to "improve" resources,  and the resupply mechanism means there are some nice tough choices between doing actions and taking resources.

Buildings are a bit of a two-edged sword - it's cool to have variety,  but experience will definitely help with properly planning out the engine.

Got to see the special buildings for the long game, which look cool, but the game as is already runs a touch too long.  I would have rather had more turns cut out while still throwing in fun new buildings.

In all,  a solid economic engine game,  but a very classic Euro design.  

Had a chance to play the long game.  It's definitely lives up to its name - it is a good chunk longer. Not convinced that it adds much - still feels like pretty much the same game.  You start with less and end with more, but that's about it.

The game definitely rewards long term planning - the microturns give the deceptive sense of time when there really isn't much slack.  You should probably look at the buildings and plan what you're going to do and work towards that :P

Some very close games (still can't seem to quite get enough turns :) but even the short game feels too long for what it is.  Or maybe I'm too lazy to do the actual planning ahead (ie reading all the cards)...

RATING: 10
This is my favorite of the worker placement games.  The biggest Rosenberg innovation is the huge deck of variable effects e.g. in Agricola, the Occupations and Minor Improvements and in Le Havre, the Special Buildings.  This game does it much better than Agricola since you’re less likely to get screwed based on what’s dealt out.  The Special Buildings also have a varying degree of impact game to game, and I really enjoy the imbalance of their effects i.e. some are obviously more powerful or useful than others.   Since Marketplace is such a huge part of the early game, the players have a fair amount of control over the release of these buildings.

Ook kunnen ze schepen bouwen en deze gebruiken om goederen te verkopen voor geld. Al met al veel te veel keus en te weinig beurten om het allemaal te doen.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
It is amazing how a game that essentially only has two potential actions that you can perform in a turn (pick up goods or place your worker) can have a weight of 3.8... which is pretty heavy in BGG terms.

In that simplicity belies a very strategic game. I can see why the uninitiated could be overwhelmed but this is a game that you could play countless times and never have the same feel.

Where other games by Uwe Rosenberg could feel overly punishing because other the need to feel your people, Le Havre softens this a bit and doesn't make it feel debilitating if you're unable to in a round or two. In this game you also have many paths to victory or at least many options that you can take during your turn. While someone might have swooped in and taken your "optimal" move, there's generally something else that you can do to help yourself out. Building out your own personal tableau of actions (and points) is appealing... as is swooping in an using your opponents building to perform an action and leaving your worker there so that they can't use that action themselves.

All in all, Le Havre is a great game and one that I think everyone should have in their collection. It's a game that has so much strategy in something that has so few mechanics. It could suffer if a group of people play it with someone new, as that could set a single player up for victory but it's a minor quibble at best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A game with a rather steep learning curve. Le Havre is an economic game at its core, with multiple ways to earning the money required for victory. These are provided by the numerous standard and couple of randomly chosen special buildings. There buildings can be combined and utilised to produce different types of end-products and money is earned via shipping or selling them. Therein lies the main fun of the game: figuring out the most cost effective way to increase your wealth.

Replayability is provided mainly by the different ways of refilling the resources, and different special buildings chosen. However, given that the number of special buildings chosen per game is only four or five, the main flow of the game does not alter much from game to game. That's the only major brickbat of an otherwise fine economic eurogame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Really enjoyable euro  that is surprisingly different from Agricola/ Caverna.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An economic and resource conversion game masquerading as a worker placement game.  I think any comparison to Agricola is unfair as what you are doing and how you are doing it in Le Havre is so very different.  Playing more to get a feel for the long term strategies and to perhaps anticipate my opponents moves better will only improve my opinion of Le Havre.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Playing Le Havre felt like a lot of work, more so than Agricola.  You have to feed constantly; you never get more than one action per turn; and in some cases you only have one turn before the phase is over for you.  Fortunately, it is a lot more forgiving as well.  Although it's easy to find yourself in a downward spiral with loans, the penalty is far less punishing than taking a begging card.  I've seen many people who were in trouble with debt during the game still being able to come out ahead in the end.  To me that's a criticism for Le Havre, especially since loans can actually be a strategy employed to get the money you need for the upcoming round.  To be able to intentionally starve your worker as a way to get ahead is a loophole that can be abused, and the penalty for making such a decision should be harsher, but instead the game is far too generous in the number of ways someone can pay back with just an extra coin premium.

Another thing I'm not particularly fond of is that there seems to be only one sure way of scoring well, and that is through the building of steel ships and/or luxury liners.  I don't think there is another strategy that comes close to the amount of VP awarded.  Maybe a heavy emphasis on shipping could work, but somehow I doubt it.  This of course is a theory that will have to be tested.

Without the burdensome individual cards of Agricola, the replayability of Le Havre comes from how the buildings are stacked each time (in addition to the specials that are drawn).  If all of the more important starter buildings (especially the food production ones) happen to be grouped in the same column, be prepare for a slower game than usual.  Even so, I imagine the play experiences of Le Havre to be less varied than that of Agricola simply because the lack in card varieties.

Lastly, I think Le Havre is much too fragile in terms of the player number and card combinations.  While five may make a tough game in Agricola, it is still very playable and presents a different kind of challenge.  Same with the hand of cards I receive.  If they are bad, I can still get a respectable score (maybe not the winning one).  Not so with Le Havre.  3 is definitely the sweet spot.  With 4 it becomes a chore to play and forget about 5.  I see that more as an exercise in tedium, since you are stuck with only one turn in three out of every five phases.  Not to mention the pacing of the game is very much dependent on how the buildings come out.  If they aren't equally distributed among the three stacks, you'll find yourselves with higher numbered ones coming out early but no one can build.  While the lower cost ones not being made available fast enough.

Even with all of the criticisms for Le Havre, I still think it's a good game and one well worth it to play.  I just don't think it will have the longevity of Agricola and probably will wear out it's newness and novelty factor faster than its predecessor.

Update #1: Bumped the score up by half a point.  The 3-player session was much more enjoyable than my first try with 4.  I had a more coherent strategy and a clear goal, rather than just taking actions for the sake of doing it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
B: 3
C: 3,76
T: 30-150
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
The game itself is pretty easy to play. Not a lot of rules are involved, and most of them are just logical. I didn’t read the rulebook, but my guess is that’s in the same style of Agricola, and that is a well written rulebook. Very clear, and it should be easy to explain.

All of the above makes it sound that this one is an easy game. Well, it isn’t easy, or maybe easy is a wrong word. There are so many possibilities to choose from, and you really couldn’t make a wrong decision. There are just one of two options, that might work out better in the end of the game. Read it well, might.

This is one of the best games we ever played. Just can’t wait to play it when we’re at home. Or maybe we try Agricola first. It’s going to be a difficult choice.

Definitely one of my favourites! This game is a brain burner (sort of) and I really like those. It scales surprisingly well, and gets harder with more players. I like to convert resources into other resources:)
Even the solitaire mode is interesting.
Solo play record: 234 points.

It was 12900 if I remember correctly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Second in Uwe Rosenberg's 'trilogy', along with Gric and At the Gates of Loyang.  IMO the best of the three by far.

Gameplay is tight and relatively intuitive.  Play time is long enough to be meaty but not so long as to be off-putting.  

Le Havre can bog down when the number of buildings gets high late in the game, but if you've planned well your decision tree will actually be pretty small.

My rating has gone up a bit after every play.

Edit: Raising my rating from 9 to 10.  It just keeps getting better. 11/15/12.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game for serious gamers.  Very similar to Agricola, but deeper and with many more options.  Better than Agricola for smaller groups (2 - 3).

After more gameplay, I can accurately describe the differences between this and our beloved Agricola.  Le Havre has several paths to victory, while Agricola is always about building the same "best" farm, i.e. having at least one of everything.  Le Havre is a lot more layered, and you're always saying to yourself, "there are so many options, but which is best," compared to Agricola where I think we can all agree the common comment is, "I need more actions!!!"

RATING: 4
After 1 Play: I was fairly disappointed.  It's not that the game is bad, but I was expecting so much more, seeing as Agricola is one of my favorite games.  While in Agricola I feel I have the freedom to choose between competing strategies, here the game feels very scripted.  

After 2+ Plays: I gave it another chance, and it failed again, so I'm done with it.  Lowered rating from 6 to 4.  4 is probably a bit harsh, but considering the game's length, I would vociferously protest slogging through it again.

RATING: 9
SOLD
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
How can a game with only two basic actions be any good? The secret lies in the buildings and the choices you must make on your turn. As Tom Vasel said, "there's only good, good, good and better." Figuring out the latter is the real challenge. A shame that there are a couple of printing errors, but those have since been fixed in the Grand Hameau "expansion." It reminds me a bit of Saint Petersburg and Race for the Galaxy in the sense that you're drafting cards and it takes a couple of plays to understand them. Timing is essential. Resource management is crucial. The short game is perfect for getting the hang of the flow, but leaves you wanting more, especially when it comes to the upkeep which is killer. Plays best with 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Thinky, tight, smart, and one of Rosenberg's last games to use cards to keep the replayability high. I don't play it as often as I wish I did, but it's still very close to one of my favorite 'feed your workers' types of games.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
Quite impressed. The first third of the game is a crawl; it's a snowflake drifting downwards. Then, without warning, that flake transforms into a hectic avalanche. So much fun to play. I recommend long game with three.

Edit: 9/28/15
It's way too long. I know that's a silly complaint, but the moves border on tedium when each turn feels so similar. If a game is long and consistently enjoyable, that's a huge plus. Long and boring? No thanks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
相对于每局起始随机卡牌变化过大的农场主来说，本人更喜欢有限变化的勒阿弗尔，因为你无需每局花大把时间用在研究卡牌能力组合上，而把更多的心思留在资源的计划和管理上。和农场主如出一辙，游戏中你依然需要为获得足够的食物而奔波，而缺少资金大把贷款证明更是一件再正常不过的事，玩家之间互动相对较多，而最终几个小时的努力无非就为了丰衣足食，殷实家业，还有搭上那最终的豪华邮轮。
【关键词】初始随机建筑顺序，特殊建筑，初级/高级资源，丰收日，建筑种类，木/铁/钢船，船运公司，炼钢/炼煤，贷款证明，建筑物买卖，最终行动轮。

【推荐度】高 【经济建设，中重度德式爱好者

RATING: N/A
Decide si tomas los bienes de una oferta o mueves a tu persona para activar un edificio (procesar bienes, venderlos o usarlos para construir edificios o barcos). Al final de cada ronda debes alimentarte. El jugador con más dinero gana (en efectivo y propiedades).
